questions.text: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) prevents which type of dislocations when landing a jump while moving?
questions.solution:
Option D: Posterior dislocation of the femur  

  • The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) prevents posterior displacement of the femur on the tibia and the anterior displacement of the tibia on the femur, as well.

Option A: Anterior dislocation of the femur

  • A posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) prevents anterior displacement of the femur on the tibia and the posterior displacement of the tibia on the femur.

Option B: Posterior dislocation of tibia

  • A posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) prevents posterior displacement of the tibia on the femur.

Option C: Lateral dislocation of tibia

  • Lateral displacement of the tibia is prevented by the lateral collateral ligament of the knee joint.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy in the emergency department post-motor vehicle accident shows hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status, and signs of pelvic trauma including ecchymoses around the hip region, perineal hematoma, and oedema. IV fluids and plasma expanders are started. Further evaluation reveals bleeding from trauma to Waldeyer's fascia. Where is Waldeyer's fascia located in the pelvic cavity?

choices.text: Fascia of the pelvic wall to the anorectal junction

questions.solution:
Option A: Fascia of the pelvic wall to the anorectal junction

  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient presents with hypovolemic shock. He has hypotension, tachycardia, confusion, and pale cool extremities due to moderate bleeding in the pelvic cavity.
  • Trauma to the Waldeyers fascia is the cause of this bleeding. This fascia arises from the presacral fascia and encloses the sacral vessels. Hence, its injury can result in bleeding into the pelvic cavity, which is indicated by the ecchymoses on examination.
  • The presacral fascia lines the sacrum's anterior aspect, enclosing the sacral vessels and nerves.
  • It continues anteriorly as the pelvic parietal fascia covers the entire pelvic cavity.
  • Waldeyers fascia originates from the presacral fascia at the S2 to S4 level. It then fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum, lying above the levator ani muscle at the level of the anorectal junction.

Option B: Fascia of the pelvic floor

  • The pelvic fascia on the pelvic floor covers both surfaces of the levator ani muscles. In front, it is attached to the back of the pubic symphysis, and laterally, it reaches the obturator fascia.
  • The diaphragmatic part of the pelvic fascia has an inferior layer known as the anal fascia attached above the obturator fascia. Below it is continuous with the superior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm.

Option C: Fascia of the pelvic viscera

  • The pelvic fascia that covers the organs in the pelvis is known as the fascia of the pelvic viscera.
  • The front division is the vesical layer that forms the anterior and lateral ligaments of the bladder.
  • The back division is the rectal layer that forms a loose sheath for the rectum but is firmly attached around the anal canal.
  • In males, the middle division crosses the pelvic floor between the rectum and the bladder as the rectovesical septum. At the same time, in females, it is termed the transverse cervical ligament.

Option D: None of the above

  • The Waldeyers fascia arises from the presacral fascia and encloses the sacral vessels. It fuses with the rectal visceral fascia. Hence, it is an incorrect option.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male with colorectal cancer metastasized to the liver (Segment VII) presents to the hepatic clinic on referral. You inform the oncology surgeon that since the metastasis is extensive, it may require hepatectomy. Which vessels can be embolized to form collaterals, given that they drain deoxygenated blood from the liver into the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hepatic vein

  • The upper group (right, left and middle) and lower group (variable numbers) of hepatic veins open in vena cava as venous drainage of the liver.
  • There is literature suggesting that Hepatic vein embolization helps in the establishment of venous collateral between lobes of the liver in cases of hepatectomies where vasculature is removed.

Option A: Portal vein

  • The portal vein carries venous blood from the gut to the liver
  • This vein drains into the hepatic and not directly into the inferior vena cava.
  • The superior mesenteric vein and splenic vein will form the Portal vein.

Option C: Azygous vein

  • The azygos vein is a vein running up the right side of the thoracic vertebral column draining itself towards the superior vena cava. It connects the systems of superior vena cava and inferior vena cava and can provide an alternative path for blood to the right atrium when either of the venue cava is blocked.
  • It drains superior intercostal veins.

Option D: Superior mesenteric vein

  • The superior mesenteric vein drains into portal veins, which is not helpful in hepatectomy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old cyclist participated in Tour de France competition. While making a sharp turn downslope, the cyclist suffered a fall and injured his right shoulder. In the hospital, an X-ray was taken, and it revealed that the patient had a fracture of the neck of the humerus. Which of the following is the most likely nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Option D: Axillary nerve

  • Axillary nerve (C5, C6) runs freely in the loose fatty tissue in the axilla, then it is lateral to the radial nerve, posterior to the axillary artery, and anterior to subscapularis to pass almost horizontally through the quadrilateral tunnel, where it is accompanied by the posterior circumflex humeral vessels transverses a quadrangular space bounded above by subscapularis (anteriorly) and teres minor (posteriorly) below by teres major medially by the long head of triceps and laterally by the surgical neck of the humerus.
  • It divides the space into anterior and posterior branches.
  • The anterior branch curves around the neck of the humerus with the posterior circumflex humeral vessels, deep to the deltoid, to reach the anterior part of the muscle.
  • The nerve often consists of two or more thin filaments that supply the anterior deltoid at the level of the anterior border of the acromion. It gives off a few small cutaneous branches that pierce the deltoid and ramify in the skin over its lower part.
  • The posterior branch courses medially and posteriorly along the attachment of the lateral head of the triceps, inferior to the glenoid rim. It usually lies medial to the branch in the quadrangular space.
  • It gives off the nerve to teres minor and the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm at the lateral edge of the attachment of the long head of the triceps.
  • It innervates teres minor and deltoid, and the skin overlies the deltoid's lower half on the shoulder's lateral aspect.
  • Dislocation of the shoulder or fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus can damage the axillary nerve.

Effects of damage:

  • The deltoid is paralyzed, leading to loss of power of abduction up to 90° at the shoulder
  • Sensory loss over the lower half of the deltoid.

Option A: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • It is caused by upper trunk compression, which causes decreased biceps reflex, and loss of forearm flexion and supination; also, loss of sensation occurs over the radial and dorsal forearm.

Option B: Median

  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus causes proximal lesion of the nerve
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration causes distal lesion of the nerve.
  • Present with “Ape hand” and “Hand of benediction”; loss of wrist flexion and function of the lateral two lumbricals, opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis.
  • Loss of sensation over thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral three-and-a-half fingers with proximal lesions.

Option C: Ulnar

  • The nerve root value of the ulnar nerve is C8-T1
  • The fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus (proximal lesion); Fracture of the hook of the hamate (distal lesion) from a fall on an outstretched hand, or compression of the nerve against hamate resting on the handlebar during cycling.
  • The proximal lesion causes ulnar claw hand on digit extension and radial deviation of the wrist upon flexion.
  • The distal lesion causes decreased flexion of ulnar fingers, abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei), thumb adduction, actions of ulnar 2 lumbrical muscles, and loss of sensation over ulnar 1 and a half fingers, including hypothenar eminence.

questions.text: Which part of the lung is most likely affected in a 68-year-old male with severe emphysema and esophageal achalasia, admitted to the intensive care unit with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure and right lower lobe pneumonia, where dullness on percussion is observed in the area medial to the medial border of the scapula upon arm elevation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Right superior Bronchopulmonary Segment

  • A broncho-pulmonary segment is a portion of the lung supplied by a specific segmental bronchus and its vessels. These arteries branch from the pulmonary and bronchial arteries and run together through the center of the segment.
  • Veins and lymphatic vessels drain along the edges of the segment. The segments are separated by layers of connective tissue that form them into discrete anatomical and functional units. This separation means that a broncho-pulmonary segment can be surgically removed without affecting the function of the others.
  • There are ten broncho-pulmonary segments in the right lung: three in the superior lobe, two in the middle lobe, and five in the inferior lobe. Some of the segments may fuse in the left lung to form usually eight to nine segments (four to five in the upper lobe and four to five in the lower lobe.
  • This is the location of the apical (superior) Broncho-pulmonary Segment (BPS) of the right lower lobe, a common site of aspiration pneumonitis.

Options B: Right posterior Bronchopulmonary Segment 

  • Upon elevation of the arm, the medial border of the scapula corresponds to the oblique fissure of the lung on the posterior thorax. Medial to that lies the apex of the lower lobe of the lung.

Option C: Left superior Broncho-pulmonary Segment

  • As right primary bronchus is shorter in length, has a wider lumen, and is more vertical hence more prone to aspiration and leading to aspiration pneumonitis.

Option D: Right medial basal Bronchopulmonary Segment

  • Upon elevation of the arm, the medial border of the scapula corresponds to the oblique fissure of the lung on the posterior thorax.
  • So, the right medial basal border is not affected.

questions.text: During an antenatal screening, multiple cardiac defects were detected in the fetus of a 29-week pregnant female, diagnosed as Tetralogy of Fallot. To explain this to the parents, which septa would be involved?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aorticopulmonary septum

  • Tetralogy of Fallot involves the aorticopulmonary septum.
  • TOF is due to anterior migration of the AORTICO-PULMONARY septum.
  • TOF is caused by the anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum.
  • Most common cause of early childhood cyanosis

Option B: Atrial septum

  • 2 Main Types
    • OSTIUM PRIMUM
    • OSTIUM SECUNDUM [Most common Type]
  • Clinical Presentation
    • Small ASD: Asymptomatic throughout life
    • Large ASD: Same as VSD
  • ECG findings
    • Right axis deviation in ostium Secundum ASD
    • Left axis deviation in ostium Primum ASD

Option C: Atrioventricular septum

  • An atrioventricular septal defect is most commonly found in children with Down syndrome

Option D: Interventricular septum

  • Most common congenital heart disease in children
  • Most common congenital acyanotic heart disease in children
  • Most common congenital heart disease affected by infective endocarditis in children
  • 90% VSDs involve the membranous part (10% muscular part)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with progressive loss of voice, numbness, and loss of taste on the back part of her tongue. MRI reveals a dural meningioma compressing nerves exiting the skull. Through which opening do these nerves leave the skull?
questions.solution:
Option D: Jugular foramen

  • The jugular foramen is a cavity formed by the anteriorly petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone posteriorly.
  • Its major function is to act as a conduit for essential structures to pass through.
  • The foramina exist lateral to the occipital condyles when viewing the skull as inferior to superior from an extracranial aspect.
  • Additionally, it sits directly posterior to the carotid canal. The external acoustic meatus, which resides within the temporal bone, is lateral and superior to the jugular foramen.
  • Following Structure Passes through this foramen: Mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve, Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery, Lateral petrosal nerve, and Emissary's vein.

Option A: Foramen spinosum

  • The foramen spinosum is a foramen in the sphenoid bone of the skull. It connects the middle cranial fossa to the infratemporal fossa. It is posterolateral to the foramen ovale and anterior to the sphenoidal spine.
  • The foramen spinosum permits the passage of the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and the meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve.

Option B: Foramen rotundum

  • The foramen rotundum is a circular hole in the sphenoid bone of the skull.
  • It connects the middle cranial fossa and the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • It allows for the passage of the maxillary nerve (V2), a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Option C: Internal auditory meatus

  • The internal auditory canal (IAC), also referred to as the internal acoustic meatus, lies in the temporal bone and exists between the inner ear and posterior cranial fossa.
  • It includes the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII), facial nerve (CN VII), the labyrinthine artery, and the vestibular ganglion.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to a local hospital in the village after an aspiration for a small toy. On examination, there is significant respiratory distress. An emergency tracheostomy is done after seeking consent. Any of the following can get damaged during the emergency tracheostomy, except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior Thyroid Artery

  • Inferior thyroid arteries are less likely to be damaged during an emergency tracheostomy.
  • Tracheostomy is defined as the creation of an opening in the trachea.
  • Most tracheostomies these days are elective, the emergency tracheostomy is rarely done due to the complications.
  • Emergency tracheostomies are usually done in the case of acute upper airway obstruction.
  • The complications of emergency tracheostomy include damage to the midline structures, pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema, bleeding, the creation of a false lumen, and perforation of the trachea.
  • Emergency tracheostomy can damage midline structures that include:
    • Thyroid isthmus
    • Thyroid ima artery
    • Inferior thyroid vein
  • In contrast to the midline structures, the inferior thyroid artery lies laterally away from the midline and escapes injury.
  • The diagram below shows that the location of the inferior thyroid artery is far lateral away from the midline/trachea. So, it is least likely to be affected.

Option A: Isthmus of Thyroid

  • Emergency tracheostomy can damage any of the midline structures of the neck, and the isthmus of the thyroid is one of those structures at risk of getting damaged in tracheostomy.

Option C: Thyroid Ima Artery

  • The Thyroid Ima artery is located in the midline of the neck just at the inferior border of the isthmus of the thyroid and is susceptible to damage by emergency tracheostomy.

Option D: Inferior Thyroid Vein​​​​​​​

  • The inferior thyroid vein is more susceptible to damage in low tracheostomy that accompanies conservation laryngeal procedures.
  • Even a cricothyroidotomy is complicated by hemorrhage after a tear in the tributary of the inferior thyroid venous system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, double vision, the eyeball was looking down and out, the pupil dilated, and drooping eyelid over the last 2 hours. MRI angiography shows an aneurysm of a cerebral artery. Which artery gives rise to the aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Option D: Posterior communicating artery

  • The most commonly damaged nerve in the berry aneurysm on the posterior communicating artery is the oculomotor nerve
  • Posterior communicating artery(branch of ICA) anastomosis with posterior cerebral artery.
  • Oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve:
    • Originate from the midbrain.
    • Sandwiched between posterior cerebral artery and superior cerebellar artery.

  • Arteries making Circle of Willis.
    • 2 Posterior cerebral arteries.
    • 2 Posterior communicating arteries (20% incidence of Berry's aneurysm).
    • 2 Internal carotid arteries.
    • 2 Anterior cerebral arteries.
    • 1 Anterior communicating artery (40% incidence of Berry's aneurysm).

Option A: Anterior choroidal artery

  • Anterior choroidal artery → supplies the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
  • Limbic system: Amygdala, hippocampus, basal ganglia (globus pallidus, substantia nigra, caudate nucleus), and fimbria of the fornix.
  • Diencephalon: The hypothalamus and lateral geniculate body of the thalamus.
  • Midbrain: Red nucleus and crus cerebri of the midbrain.
  • Visual pathway: Optic tract and optic radiation.
  • Others: Tela choroidea.

Option B: Anterior communicating artery

  • Anterior communicating artery supplies:
    • Medial & superior parts of the frontal lobe.
    • Anterior parietal lobe.
    • Optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, preoptic and supraoptic areas of the hypothalamus, par-olfactory areas of the frontal cortex, anterior columns of fornix, and cingulate gyrus.

Option C: Anterior cerebral artery

  • The anterior cerebral artery innervates the anterior limb of the internal capsule, caudate nucleus, and putamen via the medial striate artery (of Heubner).
  • The anterior cerebral artery majorly supplies the medial surface of the cerebrum.
  • It supplies most of the medial surface of the cerebral cortex (anterior three-fourths), frontal pole (via cortical branches), and anterior parts of the corpus callosum.
  • Perforating branches (including the recurrent artery of Heubner and medial lenticulostriate Arteries) supply the anterior limb of the internal capsule, the inferior portions of the head of the caudate and the anterior globus pallidus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with headaches, dizziness, fatigue, pronator deviation, right-sided hemiparesis, leftward eye and head deviation, and disc edema visible on the left side. Where is the lesion located in the cortices?
questions.solution:
Option A: Frontal

  • The frontal lobe is the largest part of the brain. It extends from the front of the brain halfway to the back.

  • Damage to the frontal lobe can cause a variety of symptoms. These can include depression, behavioral problems, and a loss of strength in the muscles. The frontal lobe controls the following functions.
    • Voluntary movements of the opposite side of your body.
    • Sequencing of complex or multistep movements.
    • Speech and language production in the dominant frontal lobe.
    • Attention and concentration.
    • Working memory.
    • Reasoning and judgment.
    • Organization and planning.
    • Problem-solving.
    • Regulation of emotions.
    • Frontal lobe damage can also result in signs like pronator drift and hemiparesis.
    • Frontal eye field: An area no 8.
    • Controls: Lateral conjugate gaze.
    • Destruction: Results in turning the head and eyes toward the side of the lesion.
    • Stimulation: Results in the contralateral turning of the eyes and head.

Option B: Insular

  • Lesion or damage to the insular cortex will lead to loss of present-moment awareness. It may also alter the behavior.

Option C: Occipital

  • It functions as a brain's visual cortex. Damage to this lobe can cause contralateral homonymous hemianopia.

Option D: Parietal

  • It functions as a somatosensory processing unit of the brain, such as pain, temperature, and touch. Damage to this lobe can cause Gerstmann’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with progressive neck pain, stiffness, and inability to move her neck laterally or medially. Which structures are involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atlanto-axial joint

  • This is a case of atlantoaxial joint dysfunction, which is most likely caused due to degenerative changes.
  • Side-to-side movement is due to the C1 – C2 joint called an atlantoaxial joint.
  • Atlas is C1 bone; Axis is C2 bone; the dens of C2 will fit into the atlas bone-forming atlantoaxial joint.
  • Atlas does not have a vertebral body.

Option A: Atlanto-occipital joint

  • Atlantooccipital joint (Ellipsoidal synovial joint) causes yes movement/nodding movement.
  • Atlanto - occipital joint
    • For head nodding
    • Ellipsoid synovial/condylar joint
  • The vertebral artery comes from the foramen transversarium & arches over the superior surface of the atlas vertebra (Posterior arch) & enters the cranial cavity by passing through the foramen magnum upwards.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: C2-C3 articulation

  • C2-C3 articulation allows the flexion and extension of the movement
  • Example touching of chin towards chest and movement of the head backwards

Option D: C6-C7 articulation

  • This helps in giving flexibility to the neck and supports the cervical spine and head.

questions.text: Dense connective tissue primarily stabilizes and supports surrounding tissues and organs. Apart from nerve and muscle sheaths, where else can dense irregular connective tissue be found?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dermis

  • The collagen fibers in the dense irregular connective tissue are densely packed but not arranged in parallel bundles (irregular).
  • The dermis has two layers the upper layer is called papillary, which is close to the epidermis, and the lower layer is called the reticular layer, a deep thick layer.
  • It is a thick layer between the epidermis and subcutaneous tissue.
  • It is attached to the epidermis with a basement membrane.
  • The dense connective tissue cushions the body from stress and strain.
  • It comprises collagen, elastic fiber, and an extra-fibrillar matrix.
  • It contains a touch, mechanoreceptor, and thermo-receptor.
  • In addition, it also contains hair follicles, sweat glands, sebaceous glands, lymph vessels, blood vessels and apocrine glands are also present.

Option B: Lamina Propria

  • Lamina propria is a thin layer of loose connective tissue (not dense) that lies beneath the epithelium in the mucosa. Loose areolar connective tissue is seen in lamina propria [sub-epithelial connective tissue] and the superficial papillary layer of the dermis

Options C: Tendon

  • Tendon and ligament have dense collagen fiber bundles arranged in a uniform parallel (regular) fashion.
  • The connective tissue of skin, bone, tendon, ligaments, dentin, sclera, fascia, and organ capsules (accounts for 90% of body collagen).
  • They provide resistance to force, tension and stretch.

Option D: Ligament

  • Tendon and ligament have dense collagen fiber bundles arranged in a uniform parallel (regular) fashion.
  • They Provide resistance to force, tension and stretch.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was scheduled for strabismus surgery in both eyes. He had not previously received general anesthesia. Anesthesia was induced with sevoflurane 2.5 vol% by mask ventilation in a mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen (FiO2 0.5). 1 min after intubation, the patient's heart rate increased from 160 to 195 beats/min. The oral temperature was increased to 38.9º C within 5 min after induction. Malignant hyperthermia was suspected. Which of the following statement is true of malignant hyperthermia?

choices.text: Increased Calcium (Ca++)transport via T-type calcium channels in T-tubules
Increased Ca++ transport via T-type calcium channels in L-tubules
Increased Ca++ transport via L-type calcium channels in T-tubules
Increased Ca++ transport via L-type calcium channels in L-tubules

questions.solution:
Option C: Increased Ca++ transport via L-type calcium channels in T-tubules

Malignant hyperthermia:

This boy presented with tachycardia and fever just 5 minutes after induction with sevoflurane and likely developed malignant hyperthermia.

  • In malignant hyperthermia, various mutations of the gene coding for the ryanodine receptor lead to excess calcium release during muscle contraction triggered by stress.
  • This, in turn, leads to contractures of the muscles, increased muscle metabolism, and a great increase in heat production in muscle.
  • Patients with this condition display normal muscle function under normal conditions; however, certain anesthetic agents or, in rare cases, exposure to high environmental heat or strenuous exercise can trigger the abnormal release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle cell, resulting in sustained muscle contraction and heat production.
  • The increased heat production causes a marked rise in body temperature that is fatal if not treated.
  • The skeletal muscles have L-type calcium channels located in the T-tubules. These are long-duration channels with a high threshold.
  • Increased Ca++ transport via L-type calcium channels in T-tubules leads to malignant hyperthermia.

Option A: Increased Ca++ transport via T-type calcium channels in T-tubules

  • The muscle fibers of skeletal muscle mainly have L-type calcium channels, as shown in the table above.
  • The T-type calcium channels are in the cardiac sinoatrial node and brain neurons.

Option B: Increased Ca++ transport via T-type calcium channels in L-tubules

  • The muscle fibers of skeletal muscle mainly have L-type calcium channels, as shown in the table above.

Option D: Increased Ca++ transport via L-type calcium channels in L-tubules

  • The muscle fibers of skeletal muscle mainly have L-type calcium channels, as shown in the table above.

questions.text: Erythropoiesis is the process in which new erythrocytes are produced. These new erythrocytes replace the oldest erythrocytes (normally about one percent) that are phagocytosed and destroyed each day. Erythroblasts require folate and vitamin B12 for proliferation during their differentiation. Which of the following functions critical to hematopoiesis requires vitamin B12 and folate?

choices.text: Serve as cofactors for iron uptake
Support terminal differentiation of erythroid and myeloid cells

questions.solution:
Option D: Support production of thymidine triphosphate

  • DNA replication is needed for cell proliferation, and for DNA replication, there should be an adequate supply of thymidine triphosphate. To make thymidine triphosphate, both vitamin B12 and folate are needed.

Vitamin B12:

  • Cofactor for enzymes:
  • Methionine synthase:
  • Methylcobalamin is required to transfer methyl groups (e.g., in DNA synthesis).
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (e.g., in odd-chain fatty acid metabolism)

Option A: Support porphyrin production

  • It is an incorrect option.
  • Vitamin B6 is required for heme synthesis.

Option B: Serve as cofactors for iron uptake

  • It is an incorrect option.
  • Vitamin C serves as a cofactor for iron absorption.

Option C: Support terminal differentiation of erythroid and myeloid cells

  • It is an incorrect option because:
  • Vitamin D3 is required for the terminal differentiation of myeloid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the enterohepatic circulation of bile salts?

choices.text: Na+ Bile salt co-transporter is involved.
1000 ml of bile is secreted every day.

questions.solution:
Option C: 1000 ml of bile is secreted every day.

  • Enterohepatic circulation refers to the circulation of biliary acids, bilirubin, drugs, or other substances from the liver to the bile, followed by entry into the small intestine, absorption by the enterocyte, and transport back to the liver.
  • Bile consists of the bile acids, bile pigments, and other substances dissolved in an alkaline electrolyte solution which is similar to pancreatic juice.
  • Per day, about 500-600 ml is secreted.
  • Some of the components of the bile, especially bile salts, are reabsorbed in the intestine and then excreted again by the liver (enterohepatic circulation).
  • 90 to 95% of the bile acids are absorbed from the small intestine.
  • Once they are decon­jugated, they can be absorbed by nonionic diffusion, but most are absorbed in their conjugated forms from the termi­nal ileum by an extremely efficient Na+ –bile salt co-transport system whose activity is secondarily driven by the low intracellular sodium concentration estab­lished by the basolateral Na+-K+ ATPase.

Option A: Na+ Bile salt co-transporter is involved

  • Sodium/bile acid co-transporter is involved in the absorption of bile salts in conjugated form from the terminal ileum.

Option B: 95% of bile salts are reabsorbed

  • 90 to 95% of the bile salts are absorbed from the small intestine.

Option D: Occurs 6-8 times daily

  • The total bile acid pool of approximately 3.5 g recycles repeatedly via the enterohepatic circulation; it has been calculated that the entire pool recycles twice per meal and 6–8 times per day.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for producing  dicrotic notch on the arterial pulse waveform?
questions.solution:
Option B: Closure of the aortic valve

  • Incisura is the notch seen in arterial pulse tracing due to the closure of the aortic valve.
  • More peripheral arterial pulsations exhibit an analogous notch called the "dicrotic notch."
  • At the end of ventricular systole, there is a sudden change in the direction of blood (protodiastole), followed by the closure of the aortic valve.
  • These events are responsible for the notch, a sudden alteration in arterial tracing. It is followed by a slowly declining pressure wave, indicating ventricular diastole.
  • In normal patients with congenital aortic stenosis, the incisura ranged between 6 and 14 mm Hg.
  • In a normal person with aortic regurgitation, the incisura finishes as the regurgitation severity increases.
  • The incisura is smaller or absent in normal patients with calcific aortic stenosis.

Option A: First heart sound

  • It is produced due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valve.

Option C: Isovolumetric relaxation

  • It is the phase of ventricular filling.
  • In this phase, aortic and pulmonary valves remained closed.

Option D: Third heart sound

  • It is the protodiastolic gallop or also named diastolic filing gallop.

questions.text: A professor explains nephron physiology and the process of secretion and reabsorption. Tubular reabsorption is the process that moves solutes and water out of the filtrate and back into your bloodstream. This process is known as reabsorption because this is the second time they have been absorbed, the first time being when they were absorbed into the bloodstream from the digestive tract after a meal. Maximum absorption of HCO3- occurs in?

choices.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
PCT

  • 80% of bicarbonate reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule.

DCT

  • All the filtered HCO3– in the renal tubules are reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Collecting duct

  • 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

  • 15% of bicarbonate reabsorption occurs in the thick ascending limb of LOH.

Learning Objective

Bicarbonate Mechanism

  • All the filtered HCO3– in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO3– utilizes the H+ secreted into the renal tubules.
  • H+ secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO3– forming carbonic acid (H2 CO3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell.
  • In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H+ and HCO3– . HCO3– from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na+ is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO3– combines with Na+ to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3). Now, the H+ is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na+.
  • Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO3–. The reabsorption of filtered HCO3– is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids.
  • Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H+.

questions.text: All of the following developmental events depend on the production of maternal or fetal glucocorticoids EXCEPT?

choices.text: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

questions.solution:
Option A: Induction of thymic involution

  • Thymic involution has no association with fetal or maternal glucocorticoids. The thymic involution process includes blockage of T-cell receptor gene rearrangement, decreased self-peptide MHC molecules, and depletion of T-cell progenitor. 

Option B: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

  • Fetal and maternal steroids are of great value in the synthesis and maturation of surfactant from type II alveolar cells.

Option C: Functional thyroid

  • Before the second trimester, most of the T4 in the fetus is maternal. Fetal production of thyrotropin (TSH) and T4 begin to increase in the second trimester, concurrent with the development of the hypothalamic-pituitary portal system 

Option D: Functional hypothalamic-pituitary axis

  • Maternal glucocorticoids may have a role in the functional hypothalamic-pituitary axis in the fetus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with impaired consciousness for half an hour by his son in an emergency. His son reports that his father had a sudden, severe headache 2 hours back, which was described as the worst in his life. The patient has a history significant of hypertension and smoking. A head CT without contrast is normal. An emergency lumbar puncture is performed with an opening pressure of four times that of normal and an increased red blood cell count. How can you describe the relationship of CSF pressure to the venous pressure in the superior sagittal sinus in a healthy brain?
questions.solution:
Option A: A few millimeters high

  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient presented with subarachnoid hemorrhage symptoms described as a "thunderclap headache". Risk factors are smoking, hypertension, arterial aneurysm, and polycystic kidney disease.
  • The hemorrhage results in increased blood cells that cause blockage of the small absorption channels of arachnoid villi resulting in a considerably high CSF pressure, as can be seen in this patient. 
  • About 500ml of CSF is formed daily, 3 to 4 times more than the total fluid volume in the cerebrospinal fluid system. The major portion, about 2/3, originates from the choroid plexus in the four ventricles, mainly in the two lateral ventricles.
  • The normal pressure in the cerebrospinal fluid system when lying in a horizontal position averages 130 mm of water. It may be as low as 65 mm water or as high as 195 mm water.
  • The arachnoid villi function like valves allowing cerebrospinal fluid to flow readily into the venous sinuses but not letting the blood flow in the backward direction.
  • This valve action of the villi normally allows cerebrospinal fluid to flow into the blood when its pressure is about 1.5 mmHg greater than the blood pressure in the venous sinuses. Thus only a few millimeters higher pressure of CSF is needed for the flow to the brain in a healthy brain.
  • Under normal conditions, the cerebrospinal fluid pressure does not rise more than a few millimeters of mercury than the pressure in the cerebral venous sinuses.
  • However, in pathological states, the villi may become blocked by large particulate matter due to fibrosis or increased blood cells that have leaked into the cerebrospinal fluid in brain diseases. This severe blockage can cause high CSF pressure, as shown in this patient.

Option B: A few millimeters lower

  • CSF is normally absorbed via the arachnoid villi into the blood of the venous sinuses. It has a valve that will only allow its flow into the blood if the pressure in the CSF is higher than that of the blood. This option is incorrect because a few millimeters lower pressure will not allow the flow of CSF into the blood due to a negative pressure gradient.

Option C: Equal to

  • For the CSF to flow from the arachnoid villi into the blood of the venous sinuses, a pressure gradient is required in that direction. If the pressure in the CSF and venous sinuses is equal, there will be no blood flow in that direction due to the absent pressure gradient.

Option D: Twice the value

  • The CSF pressure is normally about 1.5 mmHg greater than the blood pressure in the venous sinuses to begin to flow into the blood. If the CSF pressure rises still higher, the valves open more widely. However, under normal conditions, the cerebrospinal fluid pressure does not rise more than a few millimeters of mercury than the pressure in the cerebral venous sinuses. In disease states, when the villi become blocked, they can cause high CSF pressure.

questions.text: When even a relatively minor noxious stimulus is applied to the skin, it may activate autonomic neurons and produce evacuation of the bladder and rectum, sweating pallor, and blood pressure swings in addition to the withdrawal response. However, sometimes, it can be used to give paraplegic patients a degree of bladder and bowel control. Which one of the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mass reflex

  • Mass reflex: When a mild painful stimulation is administered to the skin in individuals with spinal cord damage, it causes a withdrawal reaction and irradiation of autonomic centres, resulting in bladder and stool evacuation, sweating, pallor, and blood pressure fluctuations.
  • Patients with paraplegia who have trouble controlling their bowels and bladder can use it.
  • They can be taught to start urinating and defecating on their own by pinching their thighs.

Option B: Magnet reaction

  • Magnet reaction: A reflex in which the lower extremity slowly contracts in response to gentle finger pressure on a toe pad and seems to be pulled toward the examiner's palm like a magnet.
  • It is a postural reflex called a 'positive supporting reaction' shown by spinal animals.
  • Animals without a cerebellum or human infants with an undeveloped cerebellum both exhibit the magnet response.

Option C: Decortication

  • Decortication: Damage to the cerebral cortex causes decorticate stiffness, characterised by hyperextension in the lower extremities and flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow.
  • The hyperextension of the lower extremities is caused by the same alterations that occur after midcollicular decerebration. It occurs due to the removal of inhibition of 'gamma' efferent discharge causing hyperactive stretch reflexes and rigidity.
  • The flexion is explained by rubrospinal activation of the flexor muscles in the upper extremities.

Figure A Decorticate posture

Option D: Decerebration

  • The brainstem can be completely transected between the superior and inferior colliculi, allowing the brainstem pathways to work without input from higher brain areas.
  • The cortex's corticospinal and corticobulbar pathways, as well as the red nucleus' rubrospinal tract, which largely affects the distal muscles of the extremities, are all interrupted by this injury.
  • Reticulospinal circuits that largely affect postural extensor muscles are still intact.
  • Decerebration: Extensor muscles in all four extremities become overactive when the excitatory reticulospinal pathway dominates the drive from ascending sensory pathways.
  • It is similar to what happens afterward in a supratentorial lesion that causes an uncal herniation.

Figure 2 Decerebrate posture

questions.text: Which of the following structures integrate impulses for eye-hand coordination?
questions.solution:
Option A: Superior colliculus

  • The visual pathway sends one set of impulses to the superior colliculus; these visual impulses are then carried into the cerebellum by the tectospinal tract.
  • The superior colliculus is an important brain structure that controls saccadic eye movements.  
  • Reach neurons activated during arm movements are also found in the superior colliculus, and their location extends deeper into the underlying mesencephalic reticular formation.
  • Reach neurons are classified into two types based on how they respond to gaze position.
  • The first type of reach neurons is the gaze-independent reach neurons, whose activity is determined solely by the position and movement of the arm, which is usually contralateral. 
  • The activity of these neurons is related to the activity of the shoulder muscles. 
  • The gaze-related reach neurons, on the other hand, are active for reaching into a specific area relative to the current point of gaze. 
  • It means the target must project on a specific part of the retina, regardless of which arm is used or how the target is reached. 
  • Many fixation neurons in the superior colliculus's rostral pole discharge tonically during fixation and pause during saccades. 
  • Some fixation neurons' activity can be increased during simultaneous arm movements, while others' activity can be decreased.

Option B: Frontal eye field

  • Frontal eye fields (area 8; frontal lobe) control the voluntary tracking of an object in the field of vision.
  • The frontal eye field regulates horizontal gaze on the contralateral side.

Option C: Pretectal nucleus

  • Cranial nerve II is the sensory nerve, from where the impulse is passed to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus (III N – the motor nerve for light reflex) via the pretectal nucleus.
  • The pretectal nucleus is the interneuron involved in the pupillary light reflex.

Option D: Area 17

  • Area 17 has the primary visual area (V1 – visual cortex; occipital lobe).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the composition of the organ of Corti?

choices.text: A single row of inner hair cells and a single row of outer hair cells
3-4 rows of each inner and outer hair cell.
A single row of inner hair cells and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.
A single row of outer hair cells and 3-4 rows of inner hair cells

questions.solution:
Option C: A single row of inner hair cells and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.

                                        Organ of Corti

  • The organ of the Corti is located on the basilar membrane.
  • It contains hair cells which are the auditory receptors.
  • It is spiral in structure and extends from the base to the apex of the cochlea.
  • The hair cells are arranged in four rows.
  • There are 20,000 outer hair cells and 3500 inner hair cells.
  • Only a single row of inner hair cells is located towards the center of the cochlea, and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.
  • The covering of the rows is by a tectorial membrane in which the tips of outer hair cells are embedded.
  • The process of hair cells penetrates through reticular lamina supported by the rods of Corti.
  • The sensory neurons innervate the inner hair cells.
  • 4-10% of neurons innervate the outer hair cells.
  • These neurons form the cochlear part of CN VIII.
  • The sensory neuron cell bodies are around the hair cells' bases in the spiral ganglion within the modulus.
  • The efferent fibers terminate at the outer hair cells rather than the inner hair cells.

Option A: A single row of inner hair cells and a single row of outer hair cells.

  • The hair cells are arranged in 4 rows.
  • One row of inner hair cells and 3 rows of outer hair cells (not a single row).

Option B: 3-4 rows of each inner and outer hair cell.

  • Only 1 row of inner hair cells is present instead of 3-4 rows.
  • 3-4 rows of outer hair cells are present.

Option D: A single row of outer hair cells and 3-4 rows of inner hair cells.

  • One row of inner hair cells is present.
  • 3-4 rows of outer hair cells are present.
  • This option gives the opposite composition.

questions.text: Which statement concerning visceral pain signals is correct?

choices.text: They are transmitted along sensory fibers that course mainly with sympathetic nerves in the abdomen and thorax
They are not stimulated by ischemia in visceral organs
They are transmitted only by the lightly myelinated δ-type A sensory fibers

questions.solution:
They are transmitted along sensory fibers that course mainly with sympathetic nerves in the abdomen and thorax

  • Visceral pain signals from structures in the abdomen and thorax travel towards the spinal cord in association with fibers of the sympathetic system.

They are not stimulated by ischemia in visceral organs

  • Substances released during ischemic reactions such as bradykinin and proteolytic enzymes stimulate the pain receptors of viscera.

They are transmitted only by the lightly myelinated δ-type A sensory fibers

  • Visceral pain is transmitted through small type C pain fibers and, therefore, can transmit only the chronic-aching-suffering type of pain.

They are typically well localized

  • Pain from viscera is unpleasant. It is poorly localized.

Learning Objective

  • Causes of Visceral Pain
    • Ischemia: Substances released during ischemic reactions such as bradykinin and proteolytic enzymes stimulate the pain receptors of viscera.
    • Chemical Stimuli: Chemical substances like acidic gastric juice, leak from ruptured ulcers into peritoneal cavity and produce pain.
    • Spasm and Overdistention of Hollow Organs: Spastic contraction of smooth muscles in gastrointestinal tract and other hollow organs of viscera cause pain by stimulating the free nerve endings. Overdistention of hollow organs also causes pain.
  • Pain sensation from thoracic and abdominal viscera is transmitted by sympathetic (thoracolumbar) nerves. Pain from esophagus, trachea and pharynx is carried by vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves.
  • Visceral pain signals from structures in the abdomen and thorax travel toward the spinal cord in association with fibers of the sympathetic system.
  • Any stimulus that excites pain nerve endings in diffuse areas of the viscera can cause visceral pain.
  • Visceral pain is transmitted through small type C pain fibers and, therefore, can transmit only the chronic-aching-suffering type of pain.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female arrives at the emergency department complaining of sharp, tearing chest pain radiating to her back over the past 2 hours. The CT scan indicates a dissecting aneurysm of the aorta. Which of the following structures possesses a clearly defined internal elastic lamina?
questions.solution:
Option D: Muscular Artery

  • A muscular artery is a medium-sized artery that draws blood from an elastic artery and branches into small arteries and arterioles.
  • Under the microscope, muscular arteries can be identified by their clearly defined internal elastic lamina.
  • In constricted vessels, the elastic lamina of muscular arteries appears thick and kinky.
  • The elastic lamina is best visualized using Verhoeff's stain but can be easily detected in specimens stained using other techniques as a well-defined negative staining region.
  • Examples of muscular arteries include the radial artery, femoral artery, and splenic artery.
  • Distinct internal elastic lamina is present in the muscular artery. However, the incomplete internal elastic lamina is seen in elastic arteries.

Option A: Capillary

  • An internal elastic lamina is not observed in the capillaries. Capillaries are small vessels that are responsible for the local perfusion of blood.
  • Their structure consists of basal lamina and pericytes.

Option B: Metarteriole

  • An internal elastic lamina is not observed in the metarterioles. A metarteriole is a short micro-vessel in the microcirculation that links arterioles and capillaries.
  • They have individual smooth muscle cells placed a short distance apart, forming a precapillary sphincter that encircles the entrance to that capillary bed.

Option C: Arteriole

  • An internal elastic lamina is not observed in the arterioles. Arterioles are small vessels that carry blood away from your heart and connect your arteries and capillaries.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is found to have developmental delays and severe mental retardation. His blood shows high levels of phenylalanine and phenylpyruvate. The child is given a low-phenylalanine diet which does not improve his condition. Keeping this information in mind, which one of the following conversions is not occurring correctly in this child?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tyrosine to dopamine

  • The given scenario is a classical example of non-classical phenylketonuria characterized by failure to show any improvement with a phenylalanine-deficient diet.
  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is one of the commonest inherited metabolic disorders.
  • It is divided into classic PKU (due to deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase) and non-classic PKU (due to deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin).
  • Children with non-classic PKU are detected based on different clinical symptoms, including hypotonia of the trunk, hypertonia of extremities, myoclonic seizures, and unresponsiveness to a low-phenylalanine diet.
  • Neonates are asymptomatic at the beginning of the disease.
  • Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is a co-factor required for ring hydroxylation reactions, including the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, tyrosine to DOPA, and tryptophan to serotonin.
    • Two steps in phenylalanine metabolism depend on BH4, i.e., phenylalanine to tyrosine conversion and tyrosine to DOPA synthesis using phenylalanine hydroxylase and tyrosine hydroxylase enzymes respectively. Both of these hydroxylases need BH4 as a co-factor.
    • In the absence/deficiency of BH4, both steps fail to proceed, resulting in unusually higher levels of phenylalanine which is subsequently converted to phenylalanine and phenylpyruvate (see fig).

Option A: Phenylalanine to phenyl ketones

  • Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is an essential co-factor for the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.
  • In the settings of tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency, excess phenylalanine is converted to phenyl ketones rather than getting converted into tyrosine.

Option B: DOPA to melanin

  • DOPA-to-melanin conversion is a complex biochemical pathway using multiple enzymes and intermediate products.
  • The first step uses tyrosine hydroxylase to convert tyrosine to DOPA. which is further converted to melanin in a complex biochemical pathway; this pathway is not dependent on BH4.

Option D: Serotonin to melatonin

  • Serotonin is converted to melatonin by an acetylation reaction (using Acetyl CoA) followed by a methylation reaction assisted by N-acetylserotonin O-methyltransferase. Thus, this conversion is in no way dependent on BH4.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes does not require PLP (pyridoxal phosphate) as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase

  • Vitamin B6 is involved in a variety of reactions, as shown below:
  • Carbohydrate metabolism: Glycogen Phosphorylase.
  • Amino Acid Metabolism: All Transaminases – ALT, AST, cystathionine β synthase, cystathioninase, decarboxylases, kynureninase, ALA synthase.
  • Lipid metabolism:- Synthesis of arachidonic acid, Synthesis of Sphingosine (Serine palmitoyltransferase & sphingosine-1-phosphate lyase)
  • Steroid Hormone Action: Removes hormone receptor complex from DNA & terminates the action of the hormone.
  • Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase requires NADP or vitamin B3 (Niacin) as a coenzyme.

Option A: Cystathionine β synthase

  • All Transaminases – ALT, AST, cystathionine β synthase, cystathioninase, decarboxylases, kynureninase, and ALA synthase require PLP as a coenzyme.

Option B: Glutamate decarboxylase

  • Glutamate decarboxylase requires PLP.

Option C: Aspartate transaminase

  • All Transaminases – ALT, AST, cystathionine β synthase, cystathioninase, decarboxylases, kynureninase, and ALA synthase require PLP as a coenzyme.

questions.text: A patient presents with a voracious appetite, obesity, short stature, hypogonadism, and mental disability. Karyotypic analysis shows a small deletion on the long proximal arm of chromosome 15. The physician suspects it to be a case of genomic imprinting. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Genomic imprinting is seen in Prader willi syndrome and Angelman Syndrome.

Prader Willi Syndrome (PWS):

  • Gene on chromosome 15, for which maternal allele is normally imprinted and paternal copy is active.
  • But if paternal allele is deleted, then it leads to PWS.

Causes of PWS

  • Deletion of paternal copy of allele (most common)
  • Maternal uniparental disomy- both copies of maternal chromosome are present.
  • Maternal alleles are already imprinted in this case, so not expressed.

questions.text: Which of the following will be seen when the components of the 50S subunit of prokaryotic ribosomes are centrifuged?
questions.solution:
Option D: 23S RNA & 5S RNA

Ribosomal RNA:

  • Accurate translation of the messenger RNA (mRNA) nucleotide sequence to the amino acid sequence of a protein is necessary for protein synthesis. 
  • The ribosome, transfer RNA (tRNA), and other proteins work together to translate mRNA into proteins. 
  • Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and several ribosomal proteins make up each of the two subunits that make up the ribosome. 
  • The types of rRNA and protein molecules found in prokaryotic and eukaryotic ribosomes affect their structure.
  • Composition of  prokaryotic and eukaryotic ribosomes:

  • The 30S subunit also contains roughly 21 proteins. 
  • Roughly 33 proteins make up the 40S subunit, while the 60S subunit contains about 50 proteins.

Option A, B and C: Refer to explanation of D

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the rate-limiting step of the de novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway in humans?
questions.solution:
CPS I CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol
Uses ammonia as nitrogen source Uses glutamine as nitrogen source
Requires N-acetylglutamate as positive allosteric activator Doesnt require N-acetylglutamate

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) catalyzes salvage of the purine bases guanine and hypoxanthine into GMP and IMP.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male with type 1 diabetes presents in the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, weakness, nausea, and 1 episode of vomit. He has not taken his insulin for the last 4 days. On examination, his pulse is 125/min, respiratory rate is 25/min, and high levels of ketone body. All ketone bodies can be detected by Rothera's test except:

choices.text: All the above can be detected

questions.solution:
Option C: Beta-hydroxybutyrate

  • The above given is a case of diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Patients with diabetes mellitus usually also have symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia, as in this question, indicating that the patient is diabetic.
  • In Diabetes Mellitus,
    • Glucose utilization is impaired due to absolute or relative insulin deficiency.
      • There are two types of diabetes mellitus type 1 and type 2.Type 1 is also called insulin-independent.
      • Type 2 is called insulin-dependent
  • Rothera’s test can only detect acetoacetate and acetone and not beta-hydroxybutyrate.
  • Ketone bodies from the urine sample in DKA patients react with sodium nitroprusside (in the presence of NH3) to form a purple-colored ring.
  • Positive test indicates acetoacetate and acetone.
  • No specific test is available for beta-hydroxybutyrate. So, it is first oxidised to acetoacetate, then Rothera's test is performed.

Option A, B and D: Refer to explanation of C

questions.text: A one-week-old infant presented with relentless vomiting, watery green diarrhea, abdominal distension, and failure to thrive. Further examination showed hepatosplenomegaly and increased cholesterol esters and triglyceride levels in plasma. X-ray showed calcification of adrenals. The child most probably has a defect in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acid lipase

  • The calcification of adrenals is highly diagnostic of Wolman Disease.
  • It is a congenital autosomal recessive disease.
  • It is a cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to lysosomal acid lipase deficiency.
  • As a result of lipase deficiency, excess triglycerides will not be degraded and accumulates in cells.
  • Other clinical features include:
    • Vomiting
    • Watery green diarrhoea
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Poor weight gain
    • Decreased muscle tone
    • Developmental delay
  • Symptoms commonly begin early in infancy and childhood
  • There is no cure for Wolman’s disease. Treatment is by enzyme replacement therapy.
  • The picture below demonstrates bilateral adrenal calcification in an X-ray of a child with Wolman's disorder.

Option A: Acid maltase

  • The deficiency of acid maltase causes Pompe's disease (a glycogen storage disease) with features such as hypotonia, cardiomegaly in muscles, hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia in the liver.

Option B: Acid phosphatase

  • Acid phosphatase deficiency causes a rare autosomal recessive disorder that is characterised by hypotonia, lethargy, intermittent vomiting and opisthotonos.
  • It is associated with fatal outcomes in infancy.

Option C: Alkaline phosphatase

  • Alkaline phosphate deficiency in blood indicates Wilson's disease, which may be a result of celiac disease or malnutrition.

questions.text: Carcinoid tumour cells produce large quantities of 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) with the help of aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is then eliminated in the urine. Which of the following metabolic end product of tryptophan metabolism directly give rise to HIAA?
questions.solution:
Option D: Serotonin

Serotonin metabolism:

  • Carcinoids are small, slow-growing neuroendocrine tumors most commonly located in the gastrointestinal tract
  • They can synthesize a variety of hormones especially serotonin.
  • In these cells, large amount of tryptophan is used for serotonin synthesis from tryptophan causing tryptophan deficiency.
  • Elevated 5-HIAA,which is a catabolic product of serotonin in the urine helps to establish the diagnosis (see fig)

  • Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by diarrhea, flushing, dyspnea, and wheezing.

Option A: Histidine

  • Histidine metabolisms give rise to histamine.
  • Histamine acts as a neurotransmitter and a major contributor to an allergic reaction.

Option B: Niacin

  • Niacin is vitamin B3 which is important for synthesizing energy-providing compounds NAD.
  • Carcinoid syndrome, which uses Tryptophan to synthesize serotonin, can result in niacin deficiency, as niacin is synthesized from Tryptophan.

Option C: Melanin

  • Melanin is produced from dopamine which is synthesized from tyrosine.
  • In carcinoid syndrome, melanin production is not affected.

questions.text:
A 15-day-old baby is brought to the clinic by his mother with the complaint of frequent vomiting. He has recently started feeding on breast milk. An appropriate diagnosis is made, and the patient is discharged after the resolution of the symptoms. A few days later, the baby presents to the clinic again with jaundice. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular examination shows the following findings:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Galactosemia

  • The cataract shown is an Oil Drop Cataract, which is characteristic of Galactosemia.
  • These clinical manifestations of the liver affected when milk is the diet is typical of Classical Galactosemia.

Option B: Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus

  • In Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus, jaundice and hepatomegaly are observed, but cataract is never there.

Option C: Hereditary Fructose Intolerance

  • Bilateral cataracts rule out the possibility of Hereditary Fructose Intolerance, although other symptoms exist in both these diseases.

Option D: Gaucher's disease

  • Gaucher's disease is a sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of β-Glucosidase or β-Glucocerebrosidase with an accumulation of Glucosylceramide.
  • Clinical features include No mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines the chemiosmosis coupling with oxidative phosphorylation?

choices.text: Formation of ATP at substrate level
ATP formation by transport of O2
ATP generation by pumping of neutron
ATP generation by pumping of proton

questions.solution:
Option D: ATP generation by pumping of proton

  • In oxidative phosphorylation, electrons move from Complex I to Complex IV.
  • This movement of electrons is coupled with the movement of H+ from the mitochondrial matrix to intermembrane space.
  • H+ movement generate an electrochemical gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • After the Electron Transport Chain establishes the electrochemical gradient, chemiosmosis uses this gradient to synthesise ATP.
  • Chemiosmotic coupling of oxidative phosphorylation means ATP is formed when protons, which were pumped out during electron transfer, are pumped back from intermembrane space back to Mitochondrial Matrix via the F0-F1 complex (see fig).
  • There is an enzyme called ATP synthase, which serves as the channel for the movement of protons back into the mitochondrial matrix from intermembrane space.
  • When protons are pumped into the mitochondrial matrix, it causes rotation of the rod and the rotor of ATP synthase. 
  • The energy released by this movement of protons is used by ATP synthase to synthesize ATP.

Option A: Formation of ATP at substrate level

  • Substrate-level phosphorylation involves a simple coupling of one exergonic reaction to another endergonic reaction with a negative ΔG.
  • It occurs in glycolysis and TCA.
  • It is the only source of energy in RBCs.

Option B: ATP formation by transport of O2

  • O2 is transported in the blood to all tissues and cells by binding to haemoglobin in RBCs.
  • It is released by a compound 2,3 Bis-PG produced in RBCs by RL shunt.
  • RL shunt produces zero net ATP.

Option C: ATP generation by pumping of neutron

  • There is no pumping of a neutron in any of the pathways. So, it is not involved in any energy production.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of delirium and hydrophobia. She developed these features after having a tonic-clonic seizure. The patient claims she was bitten by a bat on the hand about a month ago. The patient eventually succumbs to respiratory failure and dies. At autopsy, viral particles can be identified throughout the brainstem and cerebellum. The necrosis of virally infected neurons in this patient is most likely mediated by which of the following processes, in addition to direct viral cytotoxicity?

choices.text: Release of oxygen radicals from macrophages

questions.solution:
Correct Options:

Option B: Humoral and cellular immunity

  • The body's response to a viral infection includes killer cells and antiviral antibodies. This is because the humoral and cellular components of the immune system cooperate with one another to protect the body from the potentially detrimental effects of viral infections.
  • To eradicate the cells, either complement-mediated cytolysis or apoptosis will be implemented.
  • Following infection of a peripheral nerve, the rabies virus was able to travel to the brain and spinal cord via a mechanism known as retrograde axoplasmic flow. This flow was regulated by the protein DYNEIN. Rabies was ultimately fatal (microtubule protein).
  • Inflammation typically begins in the brainstem and can later spread to other brain parts, including the cerebellum and the hypothalamus.

Incorrect Options:
 

Option A: Histamine release from mast cells

  • Histamine release from mast cells is seen in acute inflammation, but it is not an antigen-specific response to viral infections.
  • Acute inflammation also shows this additional possibility. In contrast, they are more common in acute inflammatory responses.

Option C: Neutrophil-mediated phagocytosis

  • Neutrophil-mediated phagocytosis is seen in acute inflammation, but it is not an antigen-specific response to viral infections.
  • Acute inflammation also shows this additional possibility. In contrast, they are more common in acute inflammatory responses.

Option D: Release of oxygen radicals from macrophages

  • Release of oxygen radicals from macrophages is seen in acute inflammation, but it is not an antigen-specific response to viral infections.
  • Acute inflammation also shows this additional possibility. In contrast, they are more common in acute inflammatory responses.

questions.text: A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cytochrome C

  • This patient has squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
  • Cytochrome C is a critical regulator of apoptosis present in the mitochondrial membrane.
  • It seeps out of mitochondrial pores and activates apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (APAF-1).
  • APAF-1 converts procaspase-9 to caspase-9, causing downstream caspases to be activated (cysteine proteases).
  • These effector caspases break various target proteins, such as endonucleases, nuclear proteins, and cytoskeletal proteins, to orchestrate the morphological and biochemical changes that occur during apoptosis.

Option A: Catalase

  • Catalases through reactive oxygen species can cause cell death but do not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: Cytokeratin

  • Cytokeratin is a protein found in epithelial cells.
  • It is not associated with apoptosis.

Option D: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase, through reactive oxygen species, can cause cell death but does not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 45-year-old guy appears with a growing abdomen circumference and yellow skin and sclera. Hepatomegaly and jaundice are discovered on physical examination. The image shows a Prussian blue stain from a liver biopsy. What is the most important intracellular iron storage protein in this patient's hepatocytes?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hemosiderin

  • Hemosiderin is an iron storage complex produced during the breakdown of ferritin and phagocytosed haemoglobin (e.g., after red blood cell destruction).
  • It may be found in various tissues (e.g., alveolar macrophages, liver parenchyma) or urine, depending on the underlying pathology (e.g., pulmonary haemorrhage, hemochromatosis, and intravascular hemolysis).

Option A: Bilirubin

  • A haemoglobin breakdown product and parameter of cholestasis. Serum total bilirubin consists of unconjugated bilirubin and conjugated bilirubin.
  • It does not stain with Prussian blue.

Option B: Haptoglobin

  • A plasma glycoprotein that binds to free haemoglobin, resulting in its clearance. Hemolysis (especially intravascular hemolysis) results in decreased free, circulating haptoglobin concentrations. It does not stain with Prussian blue.

Option C: Hemoglobin

  • An iron-containing oxygen transport protein found in red blood cells. Reference ranges vary by source. Elevated in polycythemia vera and decreased in anaemia. It does not stain with Prussian blue.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man develops weakness, malaise, cough, bloody sputum, and night sweats. A chest X-ray reveals numerous apical densities bilaterally. Exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis is documented 20 years ago, and M. tuberculosis is identified in the sputum. The patient subsequently dies of respiratory insufficiency. The lungs are examined at autopsy, as shown in the image:



Which of the following best characterizes the histopathologic features of this pulmonary lesion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Granulomatous inflammation

  • The photograph shows a granuloma composed of histiocytes, giant cells and inflammatory cells. These findings are consistent with granulomatous inflammation.

Granulomatous inflammation:

  • Granulomatous inflammation is characterized by collections of activated macrophages, often with T lymphocytes, and sometimes associated with necrosis.

  • Granuloma formation is a cellular attempt to contain an offending agent that is difficult to eradicate. In this attempt, T lymphocytes often activate, leading to macrophage activation, which can cause injury to normal tissues.

  • The activated macrophages may develop abundant cytoplasm and begin to resemble epithelial cells and are called epithelioid cells. Some activated macrophages may fuse, forming multinucleate giant cells.

  • Granulomatous inflammation is a form of chronic inflammation that characterizes

  • There are two types of granulomas, which differ in their pathogenesis:

Foreign body granuloma:

  • Foreign body granulomas are incited by inert foreign bodies, which induce inflammation without T cell-mediated immune responses.

  • Typically, foreign body granulomas form around materials such as talc (associated with intravenous drug abuse), sutures, or other fibres that are large enough to preclude phagocytosis by a macrophage and are not immunogenic, so they do not incite any specific immune response.

  • Epithelioid cells and giant cells are apposed to the surface of the foreign body. The foreign material can usually be identified in the centre of the granuloma, sometimes within the giant cells, particularly if viewed with polarized light, in which it may appear refractile.

Immune granulomas:

  • These are caused by various agents capable of inducing a persistent T-cell-mediated immune response.

  • This type of immune response usually produces granulomas, such as a persistent microbe, when the inciting agent is difficult to eradicate.

  • In such responses, activated Th1 cells produce cytokines such as IFN-γ, which activates macrophages

  • In some parasitic infections, such as schistosomiasis, the granulomas are associated with strong Th2 responses and eosinophils by collections of activated macrophages, often with T lymphocytes, and sometimes associated with necrosis.

  • Granuloma formation is a cellular attempt to contain an offending agent that is difficult to eradicate. In this attempt, T lymphocytes often activate, leading to macrophage activation, which can cause injury to normal tissues.

  • The activated macrophages may develop abundant cytoplasm and begin to resemble epithelial cells and are called epithelioid cells. Some activated macrophages may fuse, forming multinucleate giant cells.

Histology of granulomatous inflammation:

  • In the usual hematoxylin and eosin preparations, the activated macrophages in granulomas have pink granular cytoplasm with indistinct cell boundaries. They are called epithelioid cells because they resemble epithelia.

  • A collar of lymphocytes surrounds the aggregates of epithelioid macrophages. Older granulomas may have a rim of fibroblasts and connective tissue.

  • Frequently, but not invariably, multinucleated giant cells 40 to 50 µm in diameter are found in granulomas; these are called Langhans giant cells.

  • They consist of a large mass of cytoplasm and many nuclei, and they derive from the fusion of multiple activated macrophages.

  • In granulomas associated with certain infectious organisms (most classically Mycobacterium tuberculosis), a combination of hypoxia and free radical-mediated injury leads to a central zone of necrosis. Grossly, this has a granular, cheesy appearance and is therefore called caseous necrosis.

  • Microscopically, this necrotic material appears amorphous, structureless, eosinophilic, and granular debris, with complete loss of cellular details (as opposed to coagulative necrosis, in which cell outlines are preserved). The granulomas in Crohn's disease, sarcoidosis, and foreign body reactions tend not to have necrotic centres and are said to be noncaseating.

  • Healing granulomas are accompanied by fibrosis that may be extensive in involved organs.

Option A: Acute suppurative inflammation

  • Purulent inflammation is characterized by the production of pus, an exudate consisting of neutrophils, the liquefied debris of necrotic cells, and oedema fluid.

  • The most frequent cause of purulent (also called suppurative) inflammation is infection with bacteria that cause liquefactive tissue necrosis, such as staphylococci; these pathogens are called pyogenic (pus-producing) bacteria.

  • A common example of acute suppurative inflammation is acute appendicitis. Abscesses are localized collections of pus caused by suppuration buried in a tissue, an organ, or a confined space. The seeding of pyogenic bacteria produces them into a tissue.

  • Abscesses have a central liquefied region composed of necrotic leukocytes and tissue cells. There is usually a zone of preserved neutrophils around this necrotic focus, and outside this region, there may be vascular dilation and parenchymal and fibroblastic proliferation

Option B: Chronic inflammation

  • In contrast to acute inflammation, which is manifested by vascular changes, oedema, and predominantly neutrophilic infiltration, chronic inflammation is characterized by the following:

    • Infiltration with mononuclear cells, which include macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells

    • Tissue destruction is induced by the persistent offending agent or inflammatory cells.

    • Attempts at healing by connective tissue replacement of damaged tissue, accomplished by angiogenesis (proliferation of small blood vessels) and, in particular, fibrosis

Option C: Fat necrosis

  • The typical histologic appearance of fat necrosis is the infiltration of foamy macrophages adjacent to adipose tissue.

  • Multinucleated giant cells, lymphocytes and plasma cells are often present, but polymorphs are uncommon.

questions.text: A routine complete blood count performed on a 20-year-old nursing student shows an abnormality in the differential leukocyte count (DLC). She also has had frequent sneezing and “watery” eyes during the past several weeks and reports that she often had such episodes in the spring and summer seasons. Which of the following cell types is most likely to be increased in the last phase reaction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Eosinophils

  • This type of reaction is mainly mediated by the release of histamine from tissue mast cells.
  • In response to the antigen and other stimuli, including cytokines produced at the local site, the T cells differentiate into Th2 cells, which secrete IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13.
  • In the late-phase reaction, leukocytes are recruited that amplify and sustain the inflammatory response without additional exposure to the triggering antigen.
  • Eosinophils are often an abundant leukocyte population in these reactions.
  • IL-5 is involved in the development and activation of eosinophils, which are important effectors of type I hypersensitivity.
  • The associated cellular infiltrates and peripheral blood findings tell mobilization and an increase in the number of eosinophils. The symptoms reported are those of seasonal rhinitis, better known as “hay fever,” a manifestation of type I hypersensitivity.

Option A: Basophils

  • Basophilia is caused due to an infection.
  • Basophilia causes fever, malaise and fatigue.

Option C: Lymphocytes

  • Increased lymphocytes are known as lymphocytosis.
  • Lymphocytosis causes lymphadenopathy, night sweats, chills, and weight loss.

Option D: Monocytes

  • A high level of monocytes causes monocytosis which is a sign of inflammation.
  • Monocytosis causes fatigue, swelling, and fever.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of an ulcer on her right leg. Her medical history is consistent with type II diabetes mellitus. Her medication includes metformin. On examination, the following findings are noted as shown below:



 

The ulcer bed is covered with granulation tissue. Which of the following includes the major cellular components found in this bed?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fibroblasts

  • Fibroblasts, macrophages, and myofibroblasts are involved in forming granulation tissue.
  • Granulation tissue:
  • Granulation tissue is an important component in the wound healing process. Wounds can heal by primary intention (wound edges approximate easily) and secondary intention (wound edges do not approximate).
  • The granulation tissue matrix will fill wounds that heal by second intention. This tissue type is also present in chronic wounds with many different causes.
  • Cells in granulation tissue:

Fibroblasts:

  • This cell type forms the granulation tissue extracellular matrix (ECM).
  • The ECM initially consists of type III collagen, a rapidly produced and weaker form of collagen that is ultimately replaced by the stronger type I collagen at the end of wound healing and scar formation.
  •  TGF-β is a growth factor produced by fibroblasts and keratinocytes during the wound healing process and has been shown to induce granulation tissue formation and the differentiation of myofibroblasts.

Myofibroblasts:

  • Myofibroblasts are responsible for the contractile process in wound closure.
  • When granulation tissue forms, fibroblasts slowly modulate into myofibroblasts, characterized by bundles of actin microfilaments along their cell's plasma membrane.
  • Prostaglandins, bradykinins, epinephrine, and norepinephrine modulate the contraction function by the myofibroblasts.
  • Eventually, the actin binds to the extracellular component fibronectin, attaches to the collagen fibres, retracts, and draws collagen fibres toward it. The mass effect causes wound contraction and closure.

Endothelial cells

  • Angiogenesis requires that the endothelial cells grow quickly into the new tissue from the older intact blood vessels that branch out, form anastomoses with other vessels, and restore blood flow.
  • This process is important for restoring the flow of nutrients and oxygen to the site, removing waste, and transporting leukocytes to the site.
