  • Without this, granulation tissue formation would be stunted and wound healing prolonged.

Keratinocytes

  • In an autocrine and paracrine fashion, keratinocytes produce signals that regulate more keratinocyte activation and stimulate other cell types (fibroblasts) during wound closure. IL-1 increases keratinocyte migration, and proliferation activates nearby fibroblasts and increases KGF (keratinocyte growth factor).
  • TNF-α acts similarly to IL-1 and activates the FGF (fibroblast growth factor) pathway. TGF-β, produced by keratinocytes and fibroblasts, reverts keratinocytes to their basal cell phenotype.
  • This signalling process is deficient in venous ulcers and contributes to non-healing.

Option B: Eosinophils

  • Eosinophils provide an effective mechanism of defence against helminth and parasitic infection.
  • They are also involved in the pathogenesis of allergic reactions.
  • They do not take part in the formation of granulation tissue.

Option C: Neutrophils

  • Neutrophils are involved in acute inflammatory reactions.
  • Their main function is to fight against pathogenesis.
  • During the healing, macrophages rather than neutrophils form granulation tissue.

Option D: Plasma cells

  • Plasma cells are types of immune cells that are involved in antibody production.
  • They do not enter the tissues and participate in forming granulation tissue.

questions.text: Natural Killer (NK) Cells are lymphocytes in the same family as T and B cells, coming from a common progenitor. However, as cells of the innate immune system, NK cells are classified as group I Innate Lymphocytes (ILCs) and respond quickly to various pathological challenges. Which of the following is least likely associated with natural killer cells?

choices.text: Comprise about 5% of human peripheral lymphoid cells

questions.solution:
Option C: Do not secrete interferon-γ

  • NK cells do secrete IFN- γ

Natural killer cells:

  • The function of NK cells is to recognize and destroy severely stressed or abnormal cells, such as virus-infected cells and tumour cells.
  • NK cells comprise approximately 5% to 10% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. NK cells express CD16, a receptor for IgG Fc tails that confers on NK cells the ability to lyse IgG-coated target cells.
  • This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). Signals from activating and inhibitory receptors regulate the killing of target cells by NK cells.
  •  There are many types of activating receptors that recognize surface molecules that are induced by various kinds of stress, such as infection and DNA damage.
  • Thus, these receptors enable NK cells to recognize damaged or infected cells. NK cell inhibitory receptors recognize self-class I MHC molecules expressed in all healthy cells.
  • The inhibitory receptors prevent NK cells from killing normal cells. Virus infection or neoplastic transformation often enhances the expression of ligands for activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class I MHC molecules.
  • As a result, when NK cells engage these abnormal cells, the balance is tilted toward activation, and the infected or tumour cell is killed.
  • NK cells also secrete cytokines such as interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which activates macrophages to destroy ingested microbes, and thus NK cells provide an early defence against intracellular microbial infections.
  • The activity of NK cells is regulated by many cytokines, including the interleukins IL-2, IL-15, and IL-12. IL-2 and IL-15 stimulate the proliferation of NK cells, whereas IL-12 activates the killing of target cells and the secretion of IFN-γ.

Option A: Derived from large granular cells

  • NK cells are derived from large granular cells.
  • Therefore this statement is true

Option B: Comprise about 5% of human peripheral lymphoid cells

  • About 5% of human peripheral lymphoid cells are composed of natural killer cells
  • Therefore this statement is true

Option D: Express IgG Fc receptors

  • NK cells express receptors for the IgG Fc.
  • This helps them in antibody-dependent cytotoxicity.
  • Therefore this statement is true

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of severe abdominal pain and headache for the past two days. He has a history of myalgia and several episodes of vomiting. His parents self-medicated with paracetamol, but the patient had no relief. A dengue NS -1 antigen test was ordered which came out positive. What is the first line of defence of the body in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Option A: Natural Killer cells

NK cells

  • Ability to kill virus-infected cells and tumour cells
  • NK cells act as an early defence against viral infections and some tumours.
  • Two cell surface molecules, CD16 and CD56, are most commonly used to identify NK cells.
  • CD16 is an Fc receptor for IgG, and it confers on NK cells the ability to lyse IgG-coated target cells. This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC).
  • The function of NK cells is regulated by a balance between signals from activating and inhibitory receptors.
  • NK cell inhibitory receptors recognize self-class I MHC molecules, which are expressed in all healthy cells. The inhibitory receptors prevent NK cells from killing the normal cells.
  • Virus infection or neoplastic transformation often enhances the expression of ligands for activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class I MHC molecules.

Option B: T cell

  • Cell-mediated immunity is a type of acquired immunity.
  • CD4+ T cells help B cells make antibodies and produce cytokines to recruit phagocytes and activate other leukocytes.
  • CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected and tumour cells via perforin and granzymes (similar to NK cells).
  • Delayed cell-mediated hypersensitivity (type IV).
  • Therefore, these are not the first line of defence.

Option C: Histiocyte

  • A histiocyte is a morphological term referring to tissue-resident macrophages.
  • However, in viral infections, natural killer cells are the first line of defence.

Option D: Macrophage

  • The dominant cells in most chronic inflammatory reactions are macrophages, which contribute to the reaction by secreting cytokines and growth factors that act on various cells, destroying foreign invaders and tissues, and by activating other cells, notably T lymphocytes.
  • Th1 cells secrete IFN-γ, which enhances the ability of monocytes and macrophages to kill microbes they ingest. This function is also enhanced by the interaction of T cell CD40L with CD40 on macrophages. Macrophages also activate lymphocytes via antigen presentation.
  • Macrophage receptors are CD14 (receptor for pathogen-associated molecular patterns [e.g., lipopolysacharides]), CD40, CCR5, major histocompatibility (MHC) II, B7, Fc and C3b receptors (enhanced phagocytosis)
  • Macrophages are part of innate immunity; however, these are not the first line of defence against viral infections.

questions.text: A 48-Year-old male, a chronic alcoholic, presents to the hospital with sudden onset fever, chills, and rigour. He underwent a liver transplant 2 weeks ago after developing liver cirrhosis and fulminant hepatic failure. His heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and SpO2 is 87%. All of the following regarding the condition described above is true, except?

choices.text: CD8+ T-cells directly destroy the graft
It is the principal cause of early graft failure
Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor
Cytokines secreted by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation which destroys the graft

questions.solution:
Option C: Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor

  • This patient’s presentation with fever, chills and rigour 2 weeks after the hepatic transplant is most likely due to Acute graft rejection.
  • Acute graft rejection does not occur due to preformed antibodies.
  • Preformed antibodies play a role in hyperacute graft rejection, which occurs within minutes to hours, not days to weeks.
  • Graft rejection that is severe: It happens days or weeks after transplantation and is the leading cause of graft failure.
  • There are two types of divisions: CD8+ CTLs may directly destroy graft cells in acute cellular rejection, or CD4+ cells produce cytokines and cause inflammation, damaging the graft.
  • Antibodies attach to vascular endothelium and activate complement via the classical pathway in acute antibody-mediated (vascular or humoral)

 

Option A: CD8+ T-cells directly destroy the graft

  • Acute graft rejection is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Acute graft rejection can occur when CD8+ Cytotoxic T-Lymphocytes directly destroy graft cells in acute cellular rejection.

Option B: It is the principal cause of early graft failure

  • Early graft rejection is mainly due to acute graft rejection.
  • It commonly occurs in weeks to months.

Option D: Cytokines secreted by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation which destroys the graft

  • Cytokines by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation.
  • It results in acute graft rejection.
  • Biopsy shows vasculitis of the graft vessels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old military trainee is brought to the emergency department due to a high-grade fever for 2 days. It is associated with nausea, vomiting and headache. His medical history is positive for viral meningitis at the age of 6 years. His previous records show that he lacks membrane attack complex (MAC). Physical examination shows neck rigidity. Laboratory investigations reveal TLC 15x109cells/L with a neutrophil count of 7x109cells/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Neisseria meningitidis

  • The patient presents with a deficiency of MAC and symptoms of meningitis.
  • MAC is responsible for cell lysis.
  • MAC is formed when C5b attaches to the C6-9 complex.
  • MAC forms holes in the cell membrane, making the cell-permeable to water and ions. This leads to cell lysis.
  • MAC is important for killing microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria.
  • Hence, deficiency of this terminal complex predisposes an individual to disseminated meningococci and gonococci infections.

Option A: Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • Vitamin D deficiency is associated with an increased risk of infections, including those caused by Streptococcus, especially community-acquired streptococcal pneumonia, tonsillitis, and pharyngitis.

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • Disorders of the immune system are associated with high-risk pseudomonal infections.
  • Pseudomonal infections are also seen in patients with diabetes and cystic fibrosis.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Disorders of the immune system and Vitamin A deficiency are associated with an increased risk of Staphylococcal infections

questions.text: A 27 Yr old female, H/O RTA, came with Multiple lacerations over both extremities and an inability to move the left leg. On examination, the patient was lethargic, GCS Poor, Tenderness (+), Crepitus (+), and Bony deformity(+) of the left leg. Vitals: HR = 120/min, RR = 20/min, BP = 80/60 mmHg. Managed with aggressive Fluid resuscitation and IV Antibiotics and analgesics. The major haemoglobin present in an adult is:
questions.solution:
Option A: HbA

  • Major Hb present in the adult is HbA [96%] → contains 2α and 2β chains.
  • Other Hb present in normal adult →3% HbA2 [α2δ2] ;1% HbF [α2γ2]
  • It is also known as HBA or a2b2 Haemoglobin.
  • It consists of two alpha chains and two beta chains.
  • It has a tetrameric structure.
  • It is the most common haemoglobin present in adults, about 97%.
  • Haemoglobin is involved in transporting O2 from the lungs to other body organs.

Option B: HbA1c

Also known as Glycated Haemoglobin.

  • It has important diagnostic value in Diabetes Mellitus.
  • Its concentration is measured depending on the chemical reaction
  • Glycated N-terminal valine of Beta chain.
  • Parallel haemoglobin tests are also performed along with it.
  • It measures blood glucose levels over the past 3 months in chronic hyperglycemic patients.

 

Difference:

NORMAL GLUCOSE TEST: measures current glucose in our system.

HBA1C TEST: measures glycated haemoglobin in the past 3 months.

Normal levels:

  • Non-diabetics: 4 - 5.6%
  • Pre-diabetics: 5.7 - 6.4%
  • Diabetics: Higher than 6.5%

Option C: HbA2 (α2δ2)

 

It is a normal variant of haemoglobin

  • It consists of two alpha and two delta chains.
  • It is present at low levels, almost (1.5-3.1%) in adults.

Significance:

  • It is increased or decreased in some diseases, so it helps to identify underlying diseases.

Causes of Increased HbA2 :

  • Beta thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia
  • Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Unstable Haemoglobinopathies
  • Malaria (doubtful cases)

 

Causes of decreased HbA2 :

  • Iron Deficiency Anaemia
  • Alpha thalassemia
  • Delta thalassemia
  • Sideroblastic anaemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes

 

Option D: HbF (α2γ2):

Also known as Fetal Haemoglobin.

  • It consists of two alpha and two gamma chains.
  • α is encoded by chromosome 16.
  • γ is encoded by chromosome 11.
  • It is present in the fetus during 6th week of pregnancy.
  • Due to its different composition, it binds to oxygen more strongly and efficiently, thus getting oxygen from the mother's bloodstream.
  • It is present in <1% of adult haemoglobin

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a Punjabi family with a history of blood transfusions presents with haemoglobin of 4.5 g/dl, MCV is 70 fl, and RDW is 22. The peripheral smear reveals anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells. The osmotic fragility is reduced too. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Beta thalassemia major

  • This patient with a history of blood transfusions, haemoglobin 4.5 g/dl, MCV is 70 fl, RDW is 22, anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells, and reduced osmotic fragility most likely has Beta thalassemia major.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Severe hemolytic anaemia requiring repeated transfusions
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Skeletal deformities
    • Transient aplastic crisis
    • Growth retardation
  • The peripheral blood smear findings may include the following:
    • Target cells
    • Anisopoikiolocytosis
    • Inclusion bodies
  • Apart from Punjabis, other ethnic groups with a high prevalence of thalassemia are Sindhis, Gujaratis, Parsis, Bengalis and Lohanas.

Option A: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • This patient's history of repeated transfusion makes this diagnosis unlikely, as the need for such repeated transfusions is highly unlikely in iron deficiency anaemia.

Option C: Sickle cell anaemia

  • Reduced osmotic fragility may be seen in sickle cell anaemia,
  • But the absence of sickle cells on the patient's peripheral smear rules it out.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It results in normocytic anaemia secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents in G6PD-deficient individuals.
  • This patient's reduced MCV effectively rules it out.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy with no relevant pre-existing medical issues presents with a 5-day history of fever and perianal soreness. On examination, he appears pale and lethargic. A perianal abscess is noted. Initial laboratory investigations reveal:


	Hemoglobin (Hb): 7.0 g/dL
	Leukocytes: 80 x 10^9/L
	Neutrophils: 15 x 10^9/L
	Platelets: 100 x 10^9/L


A bone marrow biopsy (BMB) and aspirate (BMA) are performed, showing hypercellular bone marrow with the presence of lymphoblasts. Flow cytometry analysis confirms the presence of blast cells positive for CD10, CD19, and CD34,

What is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Option A: paediatric acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

  • Symptoms:
    • Fever.
    • Easy bruising or bleeding.
    • Petechiae
    • Bone or joint Pain.
    • Shortness of breath.
  • The diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia in children is based on a complete medical history, physical examination, and complete blood count (CBC).
  • Treatment has three phases:
    • Inducing remission is the first stage of treatment.
    • The goal is to kill the leukaemia cells in the blood and bone marrow.
    • The second stage of treatment is consolidation and intensification.
    • The final stage of treatment is maintenance.

Option B: multiple myeloma

  • Symptoms:
    • Bone pain, particularly in the chest or spine.
    • Constipation
    • Mental fogginess or confusion
    • Loss of appetite
    • Nausea
  • The gold standard imaging technique for staging newly diagnosed and relapsed myeloma remains plain radiography.
  • One aberrant plasma cell in the bone marrow is where myeloma starts.
  • Myeloma begins with one abnormal plasma cell in the bone marrow
  • Autologous transplantation is the best treatment for multiple myeloma.

Option C: sickle cell anaemia

  • Symptoms:
    • Anaemia
    • Episodes of Pain
    • Swelling of hands and feet
    • Frequent infections
  • A haemoglobin electrophoresis blood test can reveal whether a person carries a particular sickle cell trait or has one of the sickle cell-related disorders.
  • A gene deficiency brings on an inherited condition known as sickle cell.
  • The only treatment for sickle cell disease is a bone marrow or stem cell transplant.

Option D: Folic acid deficiency

  • Symptoms:
    • Pins and needles (paraesthesia)
    • A sore and red tongue.
    • Mouth ulcers.
    • Muscle weakness
  • Laboratory tests for folic acid deficiency would reveal anaemia, manifesting as a decrease in haemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
  • The mean corpuscular volume (MCV) would be increased to a level greater than 100, consistent with a diagnosis of macrocytic anaemia.
  • It can be treated with folic acid tablets.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female was admitted to the ward with intermittent upper abdominal pain for the past 4 months, episodic hot flushes for 2 months and watery diarrhoea 4–5 episodes per day for 13 months. An Upper GI endoscopy was performed, and a biopsy was taken. Histopathology returned positive for chromogranin A. Increased levels of 5-HIAA are seen in the urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
Option C: Carcinoid tumour

  • Carcinoid syndrome is a collection of symptoms caused by the systemic production of various humoral factors such as polypeptides, biogenic amines, and prostaglandins, primarily from well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumours.
  • Neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver are the most common cause of carcinoid syndrome. Neuroendocrine tumours of the foregut and hindgut can also induce carcinoid syndrome in rare cases.
  • Neuroendocrine tumours are most common in the GI tract (approximately 70%), followed by the respiratory tract (about 25%).
  • Carcinoid syndrome pathogenesis is based on physiologically active amines and peptides entering the systemic circulation and escaping the liver's first-pass metabolism. These bioactive compounds are usually deactivated in the liver.
  • Serotonin, histamine, tachykinins, kallikrein, and prostaglandins are the most frequent. In neuroendocrine tumours, up to 70% of tryptophan is converted into serotonin.
  • With the help of aldehyde dehydrogenase, serotonin undergoes oxidative processes that create 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is then removed in the urine.
  • The vasodilatory effects of biologically active amines, peptides, and prostaglandins (flushing, wheezing), gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhoea, malabsorption), Pellagra (secondary to niacin deficiency), cardiac symptoms (right-sided valvular disease, mostly tricuspid regurgitation), fatigue, and sometimes cognitive impairment are common clinical presentations of carcinoid syndrome.
  • The initial diagnostic test for 5-HIAA is 24-hour urine. Chromogranin A is a glycoprotein that neuroendocrine tumours release. It is beneficial for detecting non-secreting tumours. Indium-111 pentetreotide (Octreoscan) has more than 90% sensitivity in symptomatic patients and 80% to 90% in asymptomatic patients.
  • Somatostatin analogues Octreotide and Lanreotide are available for medical management. Surgical removal of the tumour completely treats carcinoid sickness in patients with early-stage bronchial neuroendocrine tumours with carcinoid disease.

Option A: Liver Cirrhosis

  • Cirrhosis is liver scarring (fibrosis) induced by long-term liver injury. The scar tissue obstructs the liver's ability to function correctly.
  • Cirrhosis is often known as an end-stage liver disease since it occurs after various stages of liver damage from illnesses such as hepatitis.
  • Reduced appetite, fatigue, accidental weight loss, slight pain on the upper right side of your belly, nausea, vomiting, enlarged or swollen veins (varices or varicose veins), and jaundice are the most common symptoms.

Option B: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid

  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid (PTC) is epithelial cancer with follicular cell differentiation and a set of specific nuclear characteristics.
  • It is the most common thyroid neoplasm with the greatest overall prognosis. In most situations, the tumour appears as an uneven solid mass, but in rare circumstances, it may exhibit cystic features.

Option D: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

  • Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) accounts for roughly 15% of all lung cancers. Smoking is the major cause of lung cancer, accounting for 85% of occurrences. Secondhand smoking, asbestos, radon, and other environmental variables are also risk factors for lung cancer.
  • SCLC is described by light microscopy as a tumour with cells that are small in size, round-to-fusiform in shape, sparse in cytoplasm, finely granular nuclear chromatin, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.

questions.text: A sixty-year-old man presents to your clinic for treatment to stop smoking. He is a chronic smoker and smokes 2 packs per day. The patient complains of having a chronic cough with sputum production. Physical examination shows a thin male with a red complexion and a barrel-shaped chest. He purses his lips to facilitate his breathing and is sitting leaning forward. A diagnosis of emphysema is made. Which of the following is the most likely histological finding in this patient's lungs?

choices.text: Hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the bronchus with a proliferation of eosinophils
Leakage of protein-rich fluid into alveolar spaces with diffuse alveolar damage
Destruction of alveolar walls with dilation of air spaces
Hyperplasia of bronchial submucosal glands, which secretes mucus

questions.solution:
Option C: Destruction of alveolar walls with dilation of air spaces

  • Emphysema is an example of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
  • COPD includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
  • In emphysema, air spaces distal to the terminal bronchiole are affected.
  • Emphysema is characterised by an abnormal enlargement of lung air spaces.
  • There is a destruction of alveolar walls and lung parenchyma.
  • No fibrosis is seen.
  • There is also a loss of elastic recoil, which causes the trapping of air in alveoli, resulting in obstruction of airflow on expiration.

 

 

 

Option A: Hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the bronchus with a proliferation of eosinophils

  • Hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the bronchus with a proliferation of eosinophils is seen in asthma.
  • This patient has emphysema.

 

Option B: Leakage of protein-rich fluid into alveolar spaces with diffuse alveolar damage

  • Leakage of protein-rich fluid into alveolar spaces is seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • This patient has emphysema.

 

Option D: Hyperplasia of bronchial submucosal glands, which secretes mucus

  • Hyperplasia of bronchial submucosal glands can be seen in cystic fibrosis, asthma and chronic bronchitis.
  • This patient has emphysema.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient complained of an oral tumour. His chief complaint was painful swelling in the anterior gingiva, which made eating difficult. He noticed the swelling 6 months back in the upper anterior gingiva, which progressively increased in size and gradually involved the entire gingiva of both arches. The patient visited a local dentist, and oral prophylaxis was performed. No clinical changes were evident post-prophylaxis, and the lesion attained the present size within 7 days. For the previous 7-8 years, he chewed tobacco and lime 5-6 times a day, occasionally drinking alcohol. Microscopic and Immunohistochemical findings lead to the diagnosis of Lymphoma. Which of the following gene is associated with the pathology of the disease discussed here?
questions.solution:
Option D: C-myc

Burkitt lymphoma

  • Thus EBV alone does not cause Burkitt lymphoma. However, in patients with subtle or overt immune dysregulation (e.g., due to chronic malaria), unchecked B cell proliferation may lead to additional mutations (including the t[8;14] translocation) to replicate autonomously.
  • B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., AIDS patients and transplant recipients) can be associated with EBV.
  • These patients have polyclonal B-cell proliferation that transforms into monoclonal lymphomas.
  • In transplant recipients, withdrawal of immunosuppressive drugs can cause regression of such EBV-induced proliferation.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with EBV.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is endemic in southern China and some other locales; the EBV genome is found in all such tumours, and LMP-1 is implicated in driving cell proliferation. As in Burkitt lymphoma, EBV probably acts in concert with other factors to induce malignant transformation.

Option A: APC

  • The APC protein functions as a tumour suppressor, preventing excessive or uncontrolled cell growth and division.
  • It aids in regulating a cell's capacity to divide, its relationship to other cells within a tissue, and whether or not it moves close to or far from the tissue.
  • Adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) is a gene that suppresses tumour growth. If the APC gene is defective, it becomes unstable and more susceptible to additional changes that may lead to colon and rectal cancers.
  • Tumour suppressor genes stop cells from growing out of control, which could lead to malignant tumours. The APC gene produces a protein essential for various cellular processes that control a cell's potential to become a tumour.

Option B: p53

  • Cancer protein P53 refers to any isoform of a protein encoded by homologous genes in different organisms, such as TP53 (humans) and Trp53 (animals). It is also known as the Guardian of the Genome, cellular cancer antigen p53 (UniProt name), the phosphoprotein p53, tumour suppressor p53, antigen NY-CO-13, and P53 (mice).
  • The p53 proteins, once believed to be a single protein and frequently referred to as such, are essential in vertebrates because they inhibit cancer development.
  • The p53 gene is typically altered, producing a stable mutant protein whose accumulation is thought to be a characteristic of cancer cells.
  • Mutant p53 proteins not only lose their tumour-suppressive activities but often gain additional oncogenic functions that endow cells with growth and survival advantages.

 

Option C: Rb

  • The RB1 gene contains the information needed to produce the pRB protein. This protein controls cell growth and prevents cells from dividing too quickly or uncontrolled, acting as a tumour suppressor.
  • Consistent with its diverse functions, Rb inactivation can lead to increased cell proliferation or cell death.
  • Therefore, while Rb inactivation often promotes cancer development, this may also open up certain vulnerabilities of such cancers to certain drug interventions.
  • As a result, retinal cells devoid of a functional pRB can proliferate uncontrolled and develop into malignant tumours.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman, currently at 22 weeks gestation and with no known health issues, is planning a trip to Mozambique to visit her grandmother. During a prenatal check-up, the doctor prescribed mefloquine, a drug with high protein binding, for prophylaxis. What effects can be anticipated after the ingestion of this drug?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decreased glomerular filtration

  • This is a case of malarial prophylaxis in which a pregnant patient presents to the gynaecologist for a prenatal visit.
  • The abdominal examination of the patient is consistent with a uterus at 22 weeks gestation.
  • The patient wants to visit Mozambique to meet her grandmother. So, in such areas, there is a high chance that the patient will come in contact with a malarial parasite.
  • The doctor advised mefloquine to the patient for prophylaxis against malarial parasites.
  • Mefloquine is an antimalarial drug which acts on the erythrocytic stage and is used as a prophylactic suppressive agent. It is a compound with high plasma protein binding capacity.
  • High plasma protein binding leads to decreased glomerular filtration, as proteins being large in size and negatively charged, are not filtered through the glomerulus.

Option B: High volume of distribution

  • Mefloquine has a low volume of distribution.
  • High protein binding leads to a low volume of distribution into tissues as the protein-bound drug does not cross membranes.

Option C: Lowers duration of action

  • Mefloquine has an increased duration of action.
  • It is because the high protein binding of this drug leads to an increased duration of action, as only free drugs can be metabolised or excreted quickly.

Option D: Less drug interaction

  • Mefloquine has more drug interactions.
  • High plasma protein binding leads to more drug interactions, as there are higher chances of drugs getting displaced.

questions.text: Therapeutic monitoring of the plasma level of the drug is done when the drug's response cannot be measured. Which of the following drugs would not require therapeutic dose monitoring?
questions.solution:
Option A: Warfarin

  • Warfarin's TDM does not need to be done as its response can easily be measured.
  • Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is done under the following conditions:
    • When the response of a drug cannot be measured.
    • The drug should have inconsistent pharmacokinetics. Drugs should have a narrow therapeutic index (TI), where minor differences in dose can lead to adverse effects.
  • The response can be measured in drugs like:
    • Anti-hypertensive drugs: blood pressure can be measured to see their response
    • Anti-diabetic drugs: blood sugar can be measured to see their response
    • Anticoagulants: prothrombin time can be measured to see their response.
      • So, an anticoagulant, warfarin, do not need therapeutic drug monitoring, as its response can be easily measured.
  • Common indications for warfarin include atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism, and prosthetic heart valves.

Option B: Gentamicin

  • Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic.
  • It has potentially nephrotoxic abilities, so it needs to be monitored in renal diseases.

Option C: Cyclosporin

  • Cyclosporin is an immunosuppressant drug and has a narrow therapeutic index.
  • So, its TDM has to be necessary.

Option D: Phenytoin

  • Phenytoin, an anticonvulsant, has a narrow therapeutic index, so TDM is necessary for these drugs.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. For further examination of the eyes, the doctor had to pick cycloplegic drops to ensure that the patient did not develop posterior synechiae; which of the following difference between hyoscine and atropine must the doctor remember well?

choices.text: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses
Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye
Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

  • This is a case of reactive arthritis in which the patient presents with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The above-mentioned clinical feature suggests reactive arthritis.
  • The diagnosis of reactive arthritis is usually made clinically.
  • For further examination of the eye, the doctor had to use cycloplegic drops.
  • To ensure the patient doesn't develop posterior synechia, the doctor must know that hyoscine exerts a depressant effect on the CNS at relatively low doses.

Option B: Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye

  • Hyoscine doesn’t exert more potent effects on the heart than on the eye.
  • It has a more potent effect on the eye and the secretory glands.

Option C: Hyoscine is longer acting

  • Hyoscine is a very short-acting drug.
  • Atropine is a long-acting drug.

Option D: Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

  • Hyoscine has a strong anti-motion sickness activity.
  • It is most commonly used to prevent motion sickness.
  • It can also be used for the reduction of saliva in the mouth.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the doctor complaining of a headache right above the nape of her neck and nausea for 1 month. The doctor suspects it could be of hypertensive origin and orders a battery of tests. It is noted that the serum cortisol levels and ACTH levels are normal, but an ultrasound kidney, ureter, and bladder reveals renal artery stenosis. Since the patient has moderate hypertension, which of the following drug should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiazide

  • Renal artery stenosis is a disease in which atherosclerosis occurs in the arteries that carry blood to the kidney. It can lead to hypertension and damage to the kidney.
  • RAS is mostly seen in older people and can be unilateral or bilateral. The prolonged RAS can lead to kidney failure.
  • Patients with RAS should be given diuretics as the first line of medical treatment. They can reduce the blood pressure in renal arteries by removing salt and water from the kidney, increasing urine output. Thiazide is a diuretic that is given in RAS.

Option B: Guanethidine

  • Guanethidine is also used in the treatment of renal artery stenosis. It is an adrenergic neuron blocker that blocks the action of adrenaline on neuronal alpha 2 adrenoceptors.
  • It also blocks the alpha and beta-adrenoceptor-mediated effects of released adrenaline. But does not blocks any effect of injected adrenaline.

Option C: Lisinopril

  • Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor used to treat blood pressure. It is used in the treatment of renal artery stenosis.
  • ACE inhibitors can be given in unilateral RAS but are contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis due to the risk of azotemia.

Option D: Pseudoephedrine

  • It is a sympathomimetic drug that is used to relieve nasal congestion.
  • Pseudoephedrine is contraindicated in renal artery stenosis. It is a decongestant that can increase blood pressure and damage the kidney.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-anginal drugs can be given through the inhalational route?
questions.solution:
Option A: Amyl nitrite

  • Based on the symptoms of squeezing chest pain, history of hypertension, and no ECG changes on ECG, the patient is likely suffering from Angina.
  • Amyl nitrite is given by inhalational route and used in cyanide poisoning.
  • The inhalation route provides very rapid absorption and, like the sublingual route, avoids the hepatic first-pass effect. Because of its unpleasant odour and concise duration of action, amyl nitrite is now obsolete for Angina.
  • Amyl nitrite is a highly volatile liquid. It is available in fragile glass ampules packaged in a protective cloth covering. Ampule must be crushed with fingers, and the vapours must be inhaled through a protective covering.

 

Option B: Isosorbide mononitrate

  • Heart-related chest pain, heart failure, and oesophagal spasms can all be treated with the drug isosorbide mononitrate, which is marketed under numerous trade names.
  • Although they can be used to treat and prevent heart-related chest pain, beta blockers and calcium channel blockers are typically more recommended.

Option C: Nitroglycerin

  • The drug nitroglycerin belongs to the vasodilators class of drugs.
  • It functions by allowing the blood arteries to relax, which reduces the amount of work the heart must do and the amount of oxygen it needs.

Option D: Propanolol

  • A beta-blocker called propranolol treats various diseases, including tremors, irregular heartbeats, and high blood pressure. It is applied following a heart attack to increase survival rates. Additionally, it helps avoid chest pain and migraine headaches (Angina).
  • This medication works by inhibiting the effects of natural substances in the body that impact the heart and blood vessels, such as epinephrine. This effect lowers blood pressure, heart strain, and heart rate.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Tolazoline prescribed for a 30-year-old female with suspected clonidine-induced Raynaud's phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Option B: Vasodilator

  • Clinical signs: Essential hypertension with painful and cold changes of fingers suggests Raynaud's phenomenon, which is treated by anti-hypertensive drugs.
  • Phentolamine and Tolazoline are non-selective alpha-blockers.
  • Cause vasodilation in peripheral vessels
  • Used in Raynaud's disease and enhance angiography in peripheral vessels
  • Alpha 1 agonists (Phenylephrine) are vasoconstrictors.
  • Anticholinergic drugs like dicyclomine are used as antispasmodics.

Option A: Thrombin inhibition

  • Indirect thrombin inhibitors: Heparin, LMWH, Fondaparinux, Danaparoid.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitors: Lepirudin, Bivalirudin, Argatroban

Option C: Vasoconstrictor

  • Alpha 1 agonists (Phenylephrine) are vasoconstrictors.
  • While Tolazoline is a non-selective alpha-blocker.

Option D: Antispasmodic

  • Anticholinergic drugs like dicyclomine are used as antispasmodics.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 2-3 months. The patient's medical history is significant of bipolar disorder, for which he has been taking lithium for 2 years. You order fasting and random blood sugar, which turns out to be normal. After water restriction, urine and serum osmolality suggest a diagnosis of diabetes insipidus of nephrogenic origin. Which of the following would be the preferred medication for the same?
questions.solution:
Lithium is known to cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus as a side effect. In this condition, the kidneys become resistant to the antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to the inability to concentrate urine and increased urine volume.

Amiloride, a potassium-sparing diuretic, is commonly used in the management of lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. It works by blocking the epithelial sodium channels in the collecting ducts of the kidneys, which reduces the reabsorption of sodium and water. By doing so, it helps to decrease urine volume and alleviate the symptoms of excessive thirst and excessive urination.

Incorrect options:

a) Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in specific clinical situations, such as reducing intracranial pressure or promoting diuresis in acute renal failure. However, it is not the preferred medication for treating lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

b) Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic commonly used in conditions such as hypertension, heart failure, and edema. However, it is not considered the preferred treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

d) Thiazides: Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, are not the preferred medication for treating lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Thiazides can actually worsen the condition in this specific case as they can further impair water reabsorption in the kidneys.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to her physician for her annual checkup, reporting a burning sensation and pain in the epigastric region for two weeks, unresponsive to natural remedies or dietary changes. Suspected to have peptic ulcer disease, why would antacids be prescribed to her?

choices.text: Control of bleeding from the ulcer

questions.solution:
Antacids are medications commonly used to provide symptomatic relief in conditions such as peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcers are open sores that develop on the lining of the stomach or the upper part of the small intestine, often caused by factors such as Helicobacter pylori infection or the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Antacids work by neutralizing the excess stomach acid, reducing acidity in the stomach, and alleviating symptoms such as burning sensation and pain in the epigastric region. They provide prompt relief by neutralizing the acid and reducing irritation of the ulcerated area.

Incorrect options:

2. Ulcer healing: While antacids may provide some relief to the symptoms associated with peptic ulcer disease, they are not primarily used for healing the ulcer itself. Other medications such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or H2 receptor antagonists are typically prescribed for promoting ulcer healing.

3. Preventing ulcer relapse: Antacids alone are not typically used to prevent ulcer relapse. Maintenance therapy with medications like PPIs or H2 receptor antagonists may be prescribed to reduce acid secretion and prevent recurrent ulcers.

4. Control of bleeding from the ulcer: Antacids are not specifically indicated for controlling bleeding from an ulcer. In cases of active bleeding or severe ulcers, other interventions such as endoscopic therapy or medications to reduce acid secretion may be used.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to the emergency department with signs and symptoms suggestive of acromegaly. Radiologic studies revealed the presence of a large pituitary tumour. Surgical treatment of the tumour was only partially effective in controlling the disease. At this point, which of the following drugs is most likely to be used as pharmacological therapy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Octreotide

  • This patient presents to the emergency department with the diagnosis of acromegaly.
  • Acromegaly is a rare hormonal disorder resulting from excessive growth hormone production after the growth plate cartilages have fused in childhood.
  • The clinical manifestation of acromegaly is due to insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1).
  • IGF-1 causes excessive growth of bones and soft tissues.
  • 95% of causes of acromegaly are due to a pituitary adenoma, as seen in this case.
  • The tumour produces an excessive amount of growth hormone.
  • The main goal of treatment is to reduce the tumour's size, relieve the tumour's pressure on adjacent structures and correct the hormonal deficiencies and associated symptoms.
  • Treatment options include surgery to remove the tumour. However, medications may be used when surgery is contraindicated or the tumour is not curative after surgery.
  • Somatostatin analogues, GH receptor antagonists or dopamine agonists can be used as pharmacotherapy.
  • Somatostatin analogues, e.g. octreotide, bind to the somatostatin receptor and inhibit growth hormone secretion.
  • Radiotherapy is used when neither surgery nor medications are completely curative.

Option A: Desmopressin

  • Desmopressin is the analogue of vasopressin.
  • It treats diabetes insipidus, nocturnal enuresis and von Willebrand disease.

Option B: Nafarelin

  • Nafarelin is a potent synthetic agonist of gonadotropin-releasing hormone.
  • It is used to treat symptoms of endometriosis, such as pelvic and menstrual cramps and painful intercourse.
  • It is also used to treat central precocious puberty.

Option D: Somatropin

  • Somatropin is a growth hormone analogue.
  • It is not used in acromegaly, and it would worsen its condition.
  • It is used in conditions such as growth failure and growth hormone deficiency

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic female has been on Metformin and gliclazide therapy for over a year. On testing, the postprandial glucose is as high as 260 mg/dL. HbA1c is noted to be 6.7 %. Which of the following drugs is the best to target and reduce the postprandial glucose in this patient?

choices.text: Long-acting basal insulin, once at night
Voglibose, given immediately before each meal

questions.solution:
Option C: Voglibose, given immediately before each meal

  • It appears that the patient's HbA1c falls within a range that is suitable for a long-term diabetic who is solely taking orally administered antihyperglycemic agents; hence, the addition of insulin is not required. It has been shown that the addition of alpha-glucosidase inhibitors, such as acarbose, voglibose, and others, can considerably lower postprandial glucose levels, which on their own are quite high.
  • There is evidence that voglibose, whether taken on its own or in conjunction with other medications, can reduce postprandial glucose values. This effect is independent of HbA1c levels.
  • Meglitinides, which are essential medicines with a limited duration of action, have also been recommended for use in treating after prandial hyperglycemia. (Eg: nateglinide, repaglinide).
  • Because the patient has been diabetic for a long time, it is recommended that SGLT-2 inhibitors be avoided whenever possible because their usage is associated with an increased risk of developing an infection of the urinary tract.

Option A: Rapid-acting insulin pre-meals

  • Rapid-acting insulin pre-meals is not the best to target and reduce the postprandial glucose in this patient.

Option B: Long-acting basal insulin, once at night

  • Long-acting basal insulin, once at night, is not the best to target and reduce the postprandial glucose in this patient.

Option D: Canagliflozin

  • Canagliflozin is not the best to target and reduce the postprandial glucose in this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Lorazepam and the drugs in its class?

choices.text: The antidote for these is protamine sulphate

questions.solution:
Option C: These act as GABA facilitators

  • Barbiturates bind to the GABA-BZD-Cl channel complex and exert GABA mimetic (direct activation of GABAA receptors) and GABA facilitatory actions.
  • Benzodiazepines bind to a different site (BZD receptor) and increase the binding of GABA to the GABA-A receptor (GABA facilitation effect). These drugs increase the opening frequency of the Cl–channel.
  • Benzodiazepines(BZDs) are preferred over barbiturates as hypnotics for several reasons:-
    • BZDs have flat dose-response curves (these have a high therapeutic index and require a high dose to induce coma).
    • These cause fewer hangovers and less disruption of sleep architecture. The duration of REM sleep is shortened, but the increase in the number of REM cycles compensates for this. Nitrazepam increases REM sleep.
    • These are less prone to drug interactions (because they do not induce microsomal enzymes).
    • Liability for abuse is less.
    • BZD poisoning can be treated with a specific antidote, flumazenil.

Option A: These are very dangerous drugs

  • BZDs have flat dose-response curves (these have a high therapeutic index and require a high dose to induce coma).
  • Thus, the safety index for BZD is good.

Option B: These are strong enzyme inducers

  • These are less prone to drug interactions (because they do not induce microsomal enzymes).

Option D: The antidote for these is protamine sulfate

  • BZD poisoning can be treated with a specific antidote, flumazenil

questions.text: For a 68-year-old male with chronic kidney disease on dialysis, undergoing arteriovenous grafting, dalteparin is administered twice daily during hospitalization. Post-discharge, the patient is instructed to take a medication daily at 6 pm and monitor INR every third day during dialysis visits. Which medication is prescribed under these instructions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Warfarin

  • The patient is a known chronic kidney disease and is on maintenance dialysis. He requires a long-term route for dialysis and is scheduled for an arterio-venous graft. After this procedure, the patient is put on oral anticoagulants.
  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant that acts by inhibiting the Vitamin K-epoxide reductase enzyme.
  • This causes a decline in the activation of Vitamin K-based clotting factors, which are 2, 7, 9 and 10.
  • Its dosage is usually monitored by checking for the prothrombin time (PT)/International normalised ratio (INR).
  • Doctors advise taking warfarin at 6 pm every day due to two reasons which are as follows:-
    • The synthetic hepatic function is maximum at night time.
    • Taking warfarin at night ensures that the dosage can be altered accordingly on the same day when INR is taken in the morning.

Option A: Apixaban

  • It is a direct factor Xa inhibitor.
  • It does not require constant monitoring of aPTT/ PT/ INR.

Option C: Rivaroxaban

  • Apixaban and Rivaroxaban are direct factor Xa inhibitors.
  • They do not require constant monitoring of aPTT/ PT/ INR.

Option D: Dalteparin

  • Dalteparin is low molecular weight heparin which is safe in renal failure.
  • It is available in subcutaneous preparation and does not require aPTT/ PT/ INR monitoring.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby is brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic with complaints of painful swelling of the leg and a history of fever for four days. He is diagnosed with a case of cellulitis. The doctor sends the patient's sample for further confirmation and a catalase test for the causative organism, the results of which are shown in the image below. Which condition is specifically associated with this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chronic granulomatous disease

  • The test shown in the image above is Catalase Positive Test.
  • Chronic granulomatous disease:
  • Predisposes to infection by organisms giving this test positive.
  • X-linked recessive defect in NADPH oxidase, resulting in an inability to form reactive oxygen compounds and decreased respiratory burst used to kill certain ingested pathogens.
  • Affected individuals will be more susceptible to catalase-positive organisms.
  • Nitro Blue Tetrazolium Test → Negative.
  • In infections caused by catalase-negative organisms (which lack catalase and do not break hydrogen peroxide), the host with CGD is successfully able to "borrow" hydrogen peroxide being made by the organism and use it to fight off the infection.
  • Hence, Catalase-negative pathogens like Streptococci and Pneumococci infections are not severe.

Option A: Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia

  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA).
  • Defect in B tyrosine Kinase gene
  • Failure of B-cell precursors (pro–B cells and pre–B cells) to develop into mature B cells: blocks B cell maturation.
  • Decrease immunoglobulins of all classes.
  • Normal Cell-mediated immunity.
  • Up to 6 months of neonatal life, nothing happens due to maternal Antibodies; after that, severe infection occurs.

Option C: Chediak Higashi syndrome

  • Autosomal Recessive with recurrent infections, partial albinism and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Defective phagolysosome fusion, defective chemotaxis.
  • Markedly decreased in melanocytes.

Option D: wiskott aldrich syndrome

  • X linked Recessive disease characterized by immunodeficiency with thrombocytopenia and eczema.
  • WASP gene defect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with high fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, loss of smell sensation and runny nose for 5 days was visited the outpatient department. She gives a history of attending a party at her friend’s place. On examination, she has bilateral crepitations on her chest, and she is vitally stable, with oxygen saturation ranging between 88% to 92% and a temperature of 100 degrees Fahrenheit. In this case, the doctor sent the patient for RT-PCR testing and Chest HRCT, on which she was found positive for COVID-19, and HRCT showed ground glass opacities. Which of the following statements is true about COVID-19?

choices.text: COVID-19 is a type of influenza virus.
Those who take the flu vaccine are immune to it.
It is a new strain that originated in Wuhan, China.
COVID-19 suspects are quarantined for 21 days.

questions.solution:
Option C: It is a new strain that originated in Wuhan, China.

  • True about COVID-19 is that it is a new strain that originated in Wuhan, China.

Coronaviruses (CoV) 

  • Family: Coronaviridae
  • Causes: Common cold to more severe diseases, e.g., MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome) and SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory syndrome). COVID-19 is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans.
    • Common signs of infection include respiratory illness, fever, loss of sense of smell and taste, cough, shortness of breath and difficulty in breathing. In severe cases, the infection can cause pneumonia, acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death.
    • Cases may be asymptomatic.
  • Incubation period: 2-14 days; therefore, quarantine is for 14 days.
  • Risk factors for a severe infection and development of complications from COVID-19 (from highest to lowest risk) include the following:
    • Age > 65 years
    • Living in a nursing home or long-term care facility
    • Chronic diseases
    • Severe obesity (BMI > 40)
    • Diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis, cerebrovascular disease etc.
  • Common complications of COVID-19:
    • Interstitial pneumonia
    • Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS
    • Acute kidney injury
    • Coagulopathy
  • Diagnosis:
    • Screening by Rapid antigen test.
    • Real-time Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR): to confirm cases of acute COVID-19 infection.
  • Prevention: Hand hygiene, cough etiquette, maintaining distance from sick people

Option A: COVID-19 is a type of influenza virus

  • COVID-19 is not a type of influenza virus.
  • Human Influenza viruses have 4 subtypes A, B, C, and D.
  • These viruses cause seasonal epidemics, mostly in the winter (Flu Season).
  • The most common symptoms include fever, aching muscles, chills and sweats, persistent cough, and sore throat.
  • Flu usually resolves on its own. It might get troublesome in young children under age 5 and older adults over 65 years.
  • Warning signs include difficulty breathing and cyanosis.

Option B: Those who take the flu vaccine are immune to it.

  • The flu vaccine doesn't immunize against COVID-19.
  • Flu shots or flu jabs provide immunity against influenza viruses.
  • These vaccines contain inactivated, attenuated, and recombinant viruses, which are given every year to nearly all people above the age of 6 months.
  • The nasal spray of live attenuated influenza vaccine is not recommended in pregnancy and otherwise immune-compromised patients.
  • The covid-19 vaccine has two types which provide immunity against various strains of COVID-19.
    • Components Viral proteins
    • Whole viral proteins

Option D: All cases are symptomatic.

  • A person infected with COVID-19 may not exhibit the symptoms and might be able to transfer the disease to others unknowingly.
  • COVID-19 symptoms include high fever, shortness of breath, and cough commonly.
  • Uncommon symptoms include vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • In atypical cases of COVID-19, patients might not show any symptoms at all, and the body fights the virus with its immunity resolving the infection in a few weeks.
  • It is important to note that the patient without symptoms of COVID-19 still is a carrier of the virus, and the isolation protocols must be followed.

Option E: COVID-19 suspects are quarantined for 21 days.

  • The incubation period of COVID-19 is 2-14 days.
  • A quarantine of 14 days is recommended.
  • Incubation or Latent period is the time between exposure to the pathogen and the appearance of the first symptoms.
  • During the incubation period, the disease is subclinical, and the pathogens divide to reach the threshold for producing symptoms.
  • Patients carrying COVID-19 are highly contagious 2-3 days before the symptoms start.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the OPD with a complaint of right upper quadrant pain associated with intermittent low-grade fever and unexplained weight loss for the last five months. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg with a regular pulse rate of 76 beats per minute. His right upper quadrant has mild tenderness. His ultrasound abdomen and C.T. abdomen are requested, demonstrating a cystic lesion with vesicles at its periphery in segments six and seven of the liver. Additionally, he has a positive casoni test. He is advised anti-parasitic therapy along with the removal of the cyst. Which of the following is the Accidental host for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Man

  • The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, intermittent low-grade fever, weight loss, and mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant. The symptoms suggest hydatid disease, and the USG and C.T. findings of cystic lesions with blisters at the periphery further confirm the scenario. Man is the accidental host for the given condition.

Echinococcus granulosus:

  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus.
  • Definitive host: Dog and wild carnivores.
  • Intermediate hosts: Sheep and other herbivorous animals.
  • Man is an accidental host (dead end).
  • Eggs: Infective stage of the parasite.
  • Eggs transform into larva (hydatid cysts) that penetrate GIT and migrate to various organs like the liver.

  • Hydatid disease mainly affects the lungs and liver. Clinical features depend on the site being affected by the organism. Anti-parasitic therapy and cyst removal are the mainstays of treatment.

 Option B: Dog

  • The dog is the definitive host of hydatid disease.
  • The dog is an intermediate host for tenia solium.
  • Taeniasis is a human parasitic infection that is caused by the tapeworm species.

Option C: Cat

  • Toxoplasma gondii is an intestinal coccidium
  •  It parasitizes members of the cat family as intermediate hosts.

Option D: Foxes

  • Foxes are the intermediate host for Neospora caninum infection.
  • Neosporosis has been recognized in dogs, cattle, horses, and other animals, but the dog is the definitive host.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with fever, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is found to be HIV positive, and hepatomegaly is seen on examination. Sputum culture on SDA and staining reveal the fungus shown in the figure below. Which of the following fungus is the causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Penicillium

  • The image shows brush-like conidiophores.
  • Brush-like conidiophores formed at 25 0C are characteristic of the Penicillium fungus.
  • P. marneffei is the only dimorphic species of the Penicillium fungus.
  • The yeast form is seen as small, oval, 2-4 mm in diameter spherules. The mycelial form produces brick red-colored diffusible pigment.
  • It is an opportunistic fungus and causes infection in immunocompromised patients or individuals with a defective immune system and metabolic diseases like diabetes mellitus.
  • Penicillium causes tuberculosis-like disease involving the liver, spleen, and lungs.

Option A: Aspergillus

  • Aspergillus forms septate hyphae and conidiophores on wet preparations stained with lactophenol cotton blue.
  • Aspergillus fungus forms conidiophores with swollen round vesicles with chains of conidia on elongated cells. These elongated cells are called sterigmata.
  • Tissue sections of Aspergillus fungus show typical dichotomous branching of hyphae at acute angles.
  • Aspergillus is also an opportunistic fungus and causes several clinical syndromes:
    • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
    • Aspergilloma
    • Invasive aspergillosis
    • Superficial infections

Option B: Absidia

  • Absidia causes an invasive disease called mucormycosis.
  • Spores of Absidia are found in air and dust.
  • Wet preparation shows broad ribbon-like hyphae. Hyphae are readily stained with hematoxylin and eosin and show broad, non-septate hyphae.
  • Under the microscope, broad hyphae ending in sporangium can be seen.
  • Absidia causes invasive diseases and can be treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Option D: Acremonium

  • Acremonium fungus causes ocular keratitis.
  • Ocular keratitis by Acremonium fungus can be caused by a preceding corneal injury and bacterial infection of the cornea.
  • Under the microscope, Acremonium can be seen as hyaline hyphae, which produce simple awl-shaped erect phialides with inconspicuous collarettes.
  • Conidia of Acremonium are one-celled, hyaline or rarely pigmented, globose to cylindrical, and mostly aggregated in slimy heads at the apex of each phialide.

questions.text: A 15 year old school going boy presented to the OPD with complains of high fever, vomiting, abdominal pain, purpuric lesions on face and bluish discoloration of extremities. On history taking the patient specified that he had conjunctivitis 30 days prior to the onset of these symptoms. Which of the following is the causative organism of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical condition is Brazilian purpuric fever caused by Haemophilus aegypticus.

  • It is a fulminant condition characterised by fever, conjunctivitis, purpura, hypotension and shock (fulminant septicemia) in infants and children.

  • There is high fatality.

Haemophilus aphrophilus and Haemophilus parainfluenzae :

  • normal mouth commensals and a part of HACEK group.
  • can cause culture negative endocarditis in immunocompromised.

questions.text: A mother came to emergency with her 20 days old baby boy, complaining that the baby has been feverish, lethargic, vomiting, and having breathing difficulties since yesterday. The baby was born at term, and the mother had no complications throughout the pregnancy. This is her first child. On examination, the baby had a fever of 1020F, tachypnea, tachycardia, moderate dehydration and hypotonia. CSF is withdrawn and sent for culture. Gram stain is shown in the image below. Which of the following characteristics is shown by the bacteria causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Motility at 250 C

  • Motility at 250 C is characteristic of the bacterium shown.
  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal meningitis.
  • Common causes of neonatal meningitis are:
    • Escherichia coli
    • Streptococcus agalactiae
    • Listeria monocytogenes
    • The image in question shows Gram-positive bacilli as the cause of neonatal meningitis.
  • Escherichia coli: Gram negative bacilli. Hence, ruled out.
  • Streptococcus agalactiae: Gram-positive cocci. Hence, ruled out.
  • Listeria monocytogenes are Gram-positive bacilli among the common causes of neonatal meningitis. Hence, the answer.
  • Listeria monocytogenes from peritrichous flagella at room temperature (Motility at 250 C), not 370 C. This is assessed by motility test, in which two test tubes are inoculated; one tube is kept at 370 C, while the other is kept at 250C.
  • Better motility is observed at 250 C.

Option A: Catalase negative

  • Listeria species are catalase positive and oxidase negative and ferment carbohydrates to gas but not to acid esculin and sodium hippurate hydrolysis, methyl red positivity, ammonia production from arginine,
  • Negative reaction for hydrogen sulphide production, indole negativity, nitrate positivity
  • Using phenotypic properties, additional biochemical tests can differentiate Listeria ssp., particularly L. monocytogenes.

Option C: Bile solubility

  • The bile solubility test has no role in the diagnosis of Listeria. It is done to diagnose Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is Gram-positive diplococci, non-motile.
  • Indeed, the bacteria developed complete resistance to stomach acid.
  • The Listeria used a "clever set of chemical reactions" to combine one molecule of glutamate with one molecule of acid, effectively neutralizing the acid.
  • S. pneumoniae is distinguished from all other alpha-hemolytic streptococci by the bile (sodium deoxycholate) solubility test. All other alpha-hemolytic streptococci are bile resistant, whereas S. pneumoniae is bile soluble.

Option D: Twitching motility

  • Twitching motility is shown by Trichomonas, whereas Listeria shows tumbling motility.
  • Twitching motility is a type of surface-associated bacterial movement mediated by Pseudomonas aeruginosa type IV pili.
  • Twitching motility is a type of bacterial translocation over moist surfaces that is not dependent on flagella.
  •  It is caused by the extension, tethering, and retraction of polar type IV pili, which function similarly to grappling hooks.

questions.text: An 18-year-old young, newly married female visited an outpatient clinic with complaints of a burning sensation during urination increase in urge and frequency. The physician suggested her some labs, urine DR and urine culture and sensitivity. The culture confirmed that the condition is caused due to Gram-positive cocci. Which of the following is most likely associated with this case?

choices.text: Staphylococcus saprophyticus causes UTI in young females
Most common cause of UTI is Staphylococcus aureus

questions.solution:
Option A: Staphylococcus saprophyticus causes UTI in young females

  • Urinary tract infection (UTI) case in young, newly married female.
  • Gram-positive cocci responsible in this case are Coagulase Negative Staphylococci.
  • The most likely organism is Staphylococcus saprophyticus, as it is the most common cause of UTI in young females.
  • Coagulase Negative Staphylococci (CONS) are non-pathogenic strains and are less virulent than Staphylococcus aureus (coagulase-positive).
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis is a normal commensal of skin epidermidis.
    • Associated with interventions such as IV cannula, CSF shunts, prosthetic valve surgery, and catheters.
    • Causes early prosthetic valve endocarditis [<1yr].
    • Biofilm formation is seen which helps in adherence and antibiotic resistance.
    • Novobiocin sensitive.
  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus:
    • UTI in young females.
    • Associated with honeymoon cystitis.
    • Novobiocin resistance.

Option B: Not associated with honeymoon cystitis

  • Urinary tract infection in young women is most commonly diagnosed 1-2 weeks after their marriage, known as 'honeymoon cystitis.

  • It is very common and needs antibiotic treatment if not resolved within several days.

Option C: Coagulase positive

  • The Staphylococcus saprophyticus is the most common cause of UTI in young women and is coagulase negative.

  • Coagulase negatives are less virulent and less pathogenic than coagulase-positive organisms.

Option D: Most common cause of UTI is Staphylococcus aureus

  • The most common cause of urinary tract infection overall is Escherichia coli (E. coli).

  • E. coli is commonly found in the gut.
  • Women are at increased risk due to the shorter distance between the urethra and anus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents to the hospital with numerous sinus infections, and swelling on his foot. On examination, there is a continuous discharge from the sinuses. He also gave a history of weight loss and had been suffering from a fever for four days. The discharge was yellowish in colour with granules and an offensive odour. The doctor ordered an X-ray and a biopsy. Which of the following is true about the given condition of the patient?

choices.text: It does not affect the lower and upper extremities
Caused by actinomycetes and filamentous fungi
Diagnosis is by examination of sputum

questions.solution:
Option B: Caused by actinomycetes and filamentous fungi

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, slowly progressive granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues caused by actinomycetes and filamentous fungi.
  • This can affect the lower and upper extremities
  • It has a Triad of:
    • Swelling
    • Discharging sinuses
    • Presence of granules in the discharge.

 

  • Laboratory Diagnosis: Diagnosis is by examination of pus/discharge
  • Direct Examination: Granules present in discharge/ pus are thoroughly washed in sterile saline, crushed between the slides, and examined.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Mycetoma is endemic in Africa, India, and Central and South Americas.
    • Overall, actinomycetoma is more prevalent (60%) than eumycetoma (40%).

Note: Botryomycosis is a mycetoma-like lesion, mainly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Option A: It doesn't affect the lower and upper extremities

  • It can affect both the upper and lower extremities.
  • Extremities are affected by their exposure to predisposing factors such as soil.

Option C: Diagnosis is by examination of sputum

  • Diagnosis is made by examination of pus discharging from the sinus.
  • It is an infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, so the sample is taken from the discharging sinuses.

Option D: Uncommon in India

  • It is very common in India, according to epidemiology.
  • Farming is a common profession in India.
  • And lack of education and hygiene awareness predisposes Indians to such infections.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of fever and fatigue beginning 15 days ago, accompanied by headache, weakness, palpitation, abdominal pain and diarrhoea a week later. On her physical examination, the temperature was 39°C. Her sclerae were sub icteric; skin and conjunctivae were pale; lips and tongue were dry. After microbiological analysis, she was diagnosed with Enteric fever. Which of the following is the best selective media to be used for culturing the pathogen involved in this case?

choices.text: Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar medium

questions.solution:
Option B: Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar medium

  • This is a case of typhoid fever in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and fatigue accompanied by headache, weakness, palpitation, abdominal pain and diarrhoea a week later.
  • Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar is - Best selective indicator medium used to isolate salmonella species.
  • Bismuth sulphite, brilliant green - inhibitors→, hinder the growth of most bacteria while allowing salmonella to grow.
  • Ferrous sulphate- Reacts with H2S → formation of ferrous sulfide→brown-black colouration and diffuses into the surrounding medium, giving a brown–black halo.

Option A: Thiosulphate citrate bile salt agar (TCBS)

  • Thiosulphate citrate bile salt agar (TCBS) is used for Vibrio cholera.
  • It can also be used for Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

Option C: Sorbitol MacConkey agar

  • Sorbitol Mac Conkey agar -For EHEC (Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli).
  • MacConkey agar has been used to distinguish those bacteria that ferment lactose from those that do not. This is important because gut bacteria can typically ferment lactose, while important gut pathogens, such as salmonella enterica and most shigellas, are unable to ferment lactose.

Option D: All of the above

  • All of the above is incorrect because Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar medium is used as a selective media for culturing salmonella typhi.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic by his parents with the complaint of persistent thrombocytopenia from birth. He was initially diagnosed with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) at the age of 3 months and was started on IVIG. His clinical condition has continued to deteriorate with recurrent infections and eczema. The diagnosis of wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is confirmed by molecular analysis. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: WASP gene mutation 

  • Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is due to a WASP gene mutation.It is a genetically inherited condition.
  • The symptoms of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome typically appear in the first year of life.
  • It is X linked recessive disease, which is why females are carriers and males are sufferers.
  • The WASP gene mutation leads to the defect in impaired signalling and the inability to mount an IgM response.
  • This leads to defective antigen presentation.
  • Combined B and T cell disorders.The T cells are unable to help the B cells. 
  • Cell-mediated immunity is variable even though IgG and IgA levels are normal.
  • The disease is characterized by a triad of :
    • Recurrent infections
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Eczema.
  • It is also associated with an increased risk of autoimmune problems and hematological malignancies such as lymphoma and leukemia.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by genetic analysis.
  • Treatment includes platelets transfusion, IV immunoglobulin therapy, antibiotics, prophylaxis and a stem cell transplant, may be curative.
  • Life expectancy is shortened.

Option A: Primary B cell defect

  • Primary B cell disorders include:
    • Bruton agammaglobulinemia or X-linked agammaglobulinemia: defect in the B tyrosine kinase gene
    • IgM X Linked Hyper Syndrome: Deficiency of CD 40 ligand on activated T cells.
    • Selective IgA deficiency: leads to repeated sinopulmonary infections
    • Common variable immunodeficiency: B cells present in the blood, decreased immunoglobulins.
    • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia: delayed onset of normal IgG synthesis.

Option B: Primary T cell defect

  • Primary T cell defects include:
    • Di George Syndrome :
      • Chromosome 22 q11 deletion.
      • Absence of thymus & parathyroid glands.
      • Hypoparathyroidism.
      • Congenital heart defects.
    • Chronic Mucocutaneous candidiasis: causes recurrent candidiasis.

Option D: Defect in phagocytosis

  • Disorders of phagocytosis include:
    • CGD (Chronic Granulomatous Disease): deficiency of NADPH oxidase.
    • LAD syndrome (Leukocyte adhesion deficiency): defect of CD 18 (β subunit of integrins).
    • Chediak Higashi syndrome: Defective phagolysosome fusion.
    • Job syndrome/ Hyper Ig E syndrome: deficiency of TH 17 cells.
    • MPO Deficiency: Myeloperoxidase deficiency.

questions.text: A 35 year old married woman had arrived at the police station complaining of domestic abuse by her husband. The investigating medical officer noticed bruises on the forearm, shoulder and back on examination. She also had blackening with swelling and puffiness around her left eye, which made it difficult for her to open it. The blackening around the eye is caused by?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ectopic bruise

  • An ectopic bruise is responsible for the appearance of bruises at a site other than the site of injury, e.g. black eyes.
  • Contusion over bone takes a long time to become visible and may appear further from the site of impact. This results from gravity shifting of blood to the tissue which are more superficial and lax. Such bruises are called ectopic bruises.

Option A: Friction abrasion

  • Friction abrasion: Synonymous to the pressure abrasion.

Option B: Patterned abrasion

  • Patterned Abrasions: If a weapon with a patterned surface hits the body or the body falls on a rough hard patterned surface, the abrasions will usually have the pattern of the object.

Option C: Penny bruise

  • Six penny bruise: Multiple small bruises on the trunk and or limbs caused by the fingertips of the assailant, produced while overpowering the victim.

questions.text: Rifling of the bore of a gun improves the accuracy and range of the shot. In a shotgun, the bore is smooth but the muzzle end is constricted for a few centimeters. This is known as choking. Which of the following is the primary purpose of this design?

choices.text: Prevent the early dispersion of pellets

questions.solution:
Option A: Prevent the early dispersion of pellets

  • Choking is the device employed in shotgun/smoothbore firearms. Terminal a few centimetres of the bore near the muzzle end is partially constricted so as to control the shot pattern. It holds the shot column together for a better distance.
  • It reduces the dispersion of the pellets (primary purpose).

questions.text: The trial of Mr. Gupta is in court now. After having thoroughly studied the case, the judge declared that a magistrate inquest was not needed in this case. What among the following could be the offence Mr. Gupta is being charged for?
questions.solution:
Option A: Homicide

  • Magistrate inquest is not done in Homicide.

Option B: Exhumation

  • In Exhumation cases (where the body is dug out of a grave), the inquest is done by the Executive Magistrate.

Option C: Police custody death

  • The disappearance or death of a person in police custody or during police interrogation is done by Magistrate inquest.

Option D: Dowry death

  • Dowry deaths (suicide/death of a woman within 7 years of marriage) include in the indication for Magistrate inquest.

questions.text: The body of the 28-year-old television actress has been found in the hotel room where she had been staying. Initial findings by the forensic team include glove & stocking hypostasis, bruises around the neck, protrusion of the tongue, and dribbling of saliva. What is the dribbling of saliva is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antemortem hanging

  • Dribbling of saliva: Surest sign of antemortem hanging.
  • Excessive salivation occurs when the person is alive, due to pressure and friction caused by ligature material on the submandibular glands.
  • Dribbling of saliva occurs from the angle of the mouth which is at a lower level, i.e. from the angle opposite to the side of the knot.
  • When the knot is on the nape of the neck, it occurs across the middle of the lower lip.

Option B: Strangulation

  • It is a form of violent asphyxial death caused by constriction of air passage at the neck by means of a ligature or by any means other than suspension of the body.
  • Classification: Ligature strangulation, manual strangulation or throttling, mugging, Bansdola, Garroting, etc.

Option C: Postmortem hanging

  • Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging, not postmortem hanging.

Option D: Throttling

  • Throttling or Manual Strangulation: Asphyxia produced by compression of the neck by human hands.
  • Inward compression fracture of the hyoid bone is the most diagnostic finding of throttling.

questions.text: The body of the 25-year-old who had allegedly committed suicide by hanging in the hostel premises has been brought for autopsy. The doctor decides to collect the specimens via the most commonly choosen method, though the anatomical relations of the organs cannot be maintained by this method. How will the organs be collected if he has chosen Virchow's method?
