choices.text: Organs are removed one by one
In situ dissection combined with en bloc removal

questions.solution:
Option C: Organs are removed one by one

  • Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one.
  • The cranial cavity is exposed first, followed by the thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs. The spinal cord is removed from the back.
  • In this, the anatomico-pathologic relations are not preserved.

Option A: Organs are removed En masse

  • Lettulle's technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed en masse and dissected as organ blocks.
  • It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.

Option B: Organs are removed En block

  • Ghon's Technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital system are removed as organ blocks. The neuronal system is removed as another block.

Option D: In situ dissection combined with en bloc removal

  • Rokitansky's technique: It involves in situ dissection in part, combined with en block removal. It is the preferred choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases, such as HTV, and hepatitis B.

questions.text: An investigation of a missing 25-year-old woman has led the police and the investigating agency to an abandoned bungalow near the edge of the woods. The woman has been rescued alive but had allegedly been sexually and physically assaulted. During the questioning, the police got a lead to excavate the area around the farm shed. They have recovered the bodies of 2 young women, which showed signs of early putrefaction. The police have decided to slap multiple charges against the owner of the bungalow including sexual sadism. What offense is termed as such?

choices.text: Sexual gratification from acts of physical cruelty

questions.solution:
Option A: Sexual gratification from acts of physical cruelty

  • Sadism: Sexual preference disorder that focuses on the infliction of suffering, pain, or humiliation to achieve sexual gratification.

Option B: Having intercourse with an animal

  • Bestiality/zooerasty: Any sexual act with an animal

Option C: Anal intercourse

  • Sodomy: It is anal intercourse between two males (homosexual sodomy) or between a male and a female (heterosexual sodomy). It is also called buggery.
  • Pederasty is intimate sexual relations, especially anal intercourse with a boy outside his immediate family as the passive partner (the boy is known as a catamite, and the man as a pederast).

Option D: Sexual intercourse with dead bodies

  • Necrophilia: A paraphilia whereby the perpetrator gets sexual pleasure in having sex with the dead.

questions.text: A microbiology intern is preparing vaccines in the laboratory. On morning rounds, he was asked to explain about the hepatitis B vaccine by his senior. All of the following are true about the Hepatitis B vaccine except?

choices.text: Made by inserting the segment of the hepatitis B virus gene into an avirulent virus
Hepatitis B Vaccine is identical to natural hepatitis B surface antigen but does not contain virus DNA
Vaccine should be given at the Anterolateral side of left mid-thigh

questions.solution:
Option B: Polysaccharide-based vaccine

  • Hepatitis B is a recombinant protein vaccine, not a polysaccharide-based vaccine.
  • Other recombinant protein Vaccines – Anti-HPV vaccine, Lyme disease vaccine, Cholera toxin B vaccine.
  • Following are examples of Polysaccharide based vaccines:
    • Typhim-Vi
    • Pneumococcal vaccine
    • Meningococcal vaccine
    • Hib vaccine

Other options

Option A: Made by inserting the segment of the hepatitis B virus gene into an avirulent virus

  • Recombinant protein vaccines are recombinant DNA products created by genetic engineering, in which the virus's component (antigen) is introduced into the genome of an unaggressive virus.

Option C: Hepatitis B Vaccine is identical to natural hepatitis B surface antigen but does not contain virus DNA

  • Hepatitis B Vaccine is identical to natural hepatitis B surface antigen, but does not contain virus DNA is a true statement.

Option D: Vaccine should be given at the Anterolateral side of left mid-thigh

  • Instead of the buttock, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm or the anterolateral part of the thigh should receive the hepatitis B vaccination.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male patient presented with weakness and decreased movement of the left lower extremity. He received OPV with DTaP at the local health center 1 month before presenting those symptoms. The physician diagnosed the condition as VAPP. Which of the following statement is an incorrect statement regarding Vaccine Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP)?

choices.text: Onset of flaccid paralysis within 4 to 30 days of receipt of OPV
No specific treatment available, only supportive care
Presence of wild polio virus in stool

questions.solution:
Option D: Presence of wild poliovirus in stool

  • The presence of wild poliovirus in stool is not associated with  Vaccine Associated Poliomyelitis (VAPP).
  • The live attenuated poliomyelitis in the vaccine resembles the wild virus in the laboratory.
  • Since 1999, wild poliovirus type-2 has not been reported.
  • The presence of wild poliovirus in the stool is associated with wild poliovirus Type 1 or Type 3.

Option A: It is Acute flaccid paralysis

  • Vaccine Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP) is an adverse event following exposure to OPV.
  • It results in acute flaccid paralysis within 4-30 days of receiving OPV.

Option B: Onset of flaccid paralysis within 4 to 30 days of receipt of OPV

  • The onset of flaccid paralysis within 4 to 30 days of receipt of OPV is seen with Vaccine Associated Poliomyelitis (VAPP).
  • The Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio is frequently associated with P3 followed by P2 and P1.

Option C: No specific treatment is available, only supportive care

  • No specific treatment is available, only supportive care is given.

questions.text: A woman of age 34 yrs. has been taking large quantities of vitamins in hope that it would prevent many infections & cancers. Now she came with complaint of sleep disturbances, increased hair fall, anorexia, nausea, fissures & dryness of lips. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Chronic Vitamin A toxicity

  • Sleep disturbances, hair loss, anorexia, nausea, skin desquamation (fissures & dryness of lips) are suggestive of Vitamin A toxicity.
  • Enlarged liver & papilloedema can also be seen in chronic Vitamin A intoxication.
  • Most of the time only fat-soluble vitamins (Vit–A,D,E,K) can cause toxicity as they can be stored in the body.
  • High doses of Vitamin A are teratogenic.

Chronic Vitamin K toxicity

  • Vitamin K toxicity can results in Hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and kernicterus in infants.

Chronic Vitamin E toxicity

  • Vitamin E toxicity can results in gastrointestinal manifestations, weakness, fatigue, and emotional lability and even Hemorrhage can occur.

Chronic Vitamin D toxicity

  • Vitamin D toxicity can cause hypercalcemia (d/t increased absorption from intestine) which results in anorexia, nausea, vomiting, thirst & drowsiness.
  • The patient may lapse into coma, while cardiac arrhythmias & renal failure may occur

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the hospital with cough, runny nose, body pain and fever since 5 days. Looking at the current scenario the physician gave him medications and asked him to stay under quarantine for 14 days. Quarantine was originally introduced as a protection against?
questions.solution:
Plague

  • In 14th century, quarantine was introduced in Europe to protect against transmission of plague.
  • Ships, Crews, Travellers were detained for a 40-day period.

List of Quarantinable diseases is:

  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious tuberculosis
  • Plague
  • Smallpox
  • Yellow fever
  • SARS
  • Viral hemorrhagic fever
  • Cholera
  • Flu

Learning Objective

  • Quarantine goal to separates and restricts the movement of people who were exposed to a contagious disease to see if they become sick.
  • Quarantine was introduced in Europe to protect against transmission of plague.

questions.text: USHA is a frontline community worker expected to deliver services at the doorstep of the community. Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for the population of?
questions.solution:
Option A: 1000-2500

  • 1 USHA worker per 1000-2500 population (250-500 households).
  • Therefore, Option A is the correct choice.

URBAN SOCIAL HEALTH ACTIVIST (USHA)

  • Frontline community workers are expected to deliver services at the doorstep of the community.
  • The link between Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) and urban slum population.
  • 1 USHA worker per 1000-2500 population (250-500 households).
  • A woman who resides in the slum, preferably 25-45 years of age chosen through a community-driven process involving the urban local body of counselors, self–help groups, and Anganwadis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented to the hospital with abdominal pain, loose watery stools, nausea, bloating, and fever. Suspecting diarrhea the doctor started his treatment with ORS. Which of the following is incorrect about ‘reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution’?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sodium chloride – 3.5 grams/litre

  • WHO Unicef recommended oral rehydration formulation: reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution.
  • WHO reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution.
  • The sodium chloride content in ORS is 2.6 grams/litre.
Composition Weight Osmolar concentration (mmol/litre)
Sodium chloride 2.6 gm Sodium 75
Potassium chloride 1.5 gm Potassium 20
Sodium citrate 2.9 gm Chloride 65
Glucose, anhydrous 13.5 gm Citrate 10
    Glucose, anhydrous 75
Total 20.5 gms Total 245

Option B: Sodium citrate – 2.9 grams/litre

  • The sodium citrate content in ORS is 2.9 grams/litre.

Option C: Potassium chloride – 1.5 grams/litre

  • The Potassium chloride content in ORS is 1.5  grams/litre.

Option D: Glucose – 13.5 grams/litre

  • The glucose content in ORS is 13.5 grams/litre.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant female presented to the hospital with low-grade fever, headache, swollen lymph nodes, and a runny nose. On laboratory examination, she was detected as positive for rubella infection. The risk of damage to the fetus by maternal rubella is maximum if the mother gets infected in which of the following trimester?
questions.solution:
Option A: 6 to 12 weeks of pregnancy

  • The risk of damage to the fetus by maternal rubella (German measles) infection is highest if the mother gets infected during the first trimester of pregnancy, which corresponds to 6-12 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The risk of congenital malformations following infections by teratogenic organisms is maximum in the first trimester, so the best option is 6-12 weeks.
  • Pregnancy's first three months are the most miserable time for the developing organs and the foetus. The infant develops anomalies in 85% of situations if the infection happens at this time.
  • Whereas visible flaws were discovered in approximately 16% of neonates, who acquired an infection during the second trimester.

Option B: 20-24 weeks of pregnancy

  • Infections with rubella later in pregnancy, such as during the second or third trimesters, are less likely to cause significant harm to the developing fetus
  • Birth defects are not common if maternal infection occurs after 20 weeks of gestation. 

Option C: 24-28 weeks of pregnancy

  • If a maternal infection develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy, birth abnormalities are uncommon.

Option D: 32-36 weeks of pregnancy

  • The risk of damage to the fetus by maternal rubella is not maximum if the mother gets infected after 32 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Pulse polio immunization programme in India was launched in 1995-96. Pulse Polio Immunization is the administration of OPV to which of the following?

choices.text: All children between 0-5 years of age on a single day, irrespective of their previous immunization status
Children in the age group of 0-1 year only who have not been immunized earlier
Children in the age group of 12-24 months only, as the booster dose
All children between 0-5 years of age, whenever there is an outbreak of poliomyelitis

questions.solution:
Option A: All children between 0-5 years of age on a single day, irrespective of their previous immunization status

  • Pulse Polio Immunization is the administration of OPV to Sudden, simultaneous mass administration of Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) on a single day to all children 0–5 years of age, irrespective of their previous immunization status.

questions.text: A patient from a rural village presented to the PHC with loss of color on his skin, blisters, rashes, and muscle weakness. The condition was diagnosed as leprosy. Which among the following is the correct treatment duration for Multi-bacillary leprosy?
questions.solution:
Option B: 12 months

  • The duration of treatment for Multi-bacillary leprosy is 12 months.

Option A: 6 months

  • The duration of treatment for Paucibacillary Leprosy (PBL) is 6 months.

Option C: 2 years

  • The duration of follow-up for Paucibacillary Leprosy (PBL) is 2 years.

Option D: 5 years

  • The duration of follow-up for Multi-bacillary leprosy is 5 years.

questions.text: The Factories Act, 1948 is a social legislation that has been enacted for the occupational safety, health, and welfare of workers at workplaces. What does sickness absenteeism predict in a factory?
questions.solution:
Option B: State of health of workers

  • Sickness absenteeism is a ‘useful index in the industry to assess the state of health of workers, and their physical, mental and social well-being.
  • Causes of sickness absenteeism may not be entirely due to sickness: Economic causes, Social causes, and Medical causes.
  • Methods of reducing sickness absenteeism:
    • Good factory management and practices
    • Adequate pre-placement examination
    • Good human relations
    • Application of ergonomics

questions.text: Immunoglobulins are glycoprotein molecules produced by plasma cells (white blood cells). They act as a critical part of the immune response by specifically recognizing and binding to particular antigens, such as bacteria or viruses, and aiding in their destruction. Which of the following is the correct dose of Rubella immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Option C: 20 ml

  • The dose of rubella immunoglobulin is 20 ml.
  • Active immunization with a live attenuated vaccine is now possible in Rubella.
  • Rubella vaccine strain- RA 27/3
  • Rubella vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • First priority group: Non-pregnant, non-lactating 15-49 years females
  • Rubella can be transmitted from an infected mother to an unborn or new born child known as CRS (Congenital Rubella Syndrome)

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presented to the OPD with frequent urination, burning sensation and blood in urine. The physician sent him for screening suspecting some diagnosis. In which of the following disease, Screening procedure increases the overall survival maximum?
questions.solution:
Option C: Colon cancer

  • Colonic cancer has highest 5-year survival rate post-screening.
  • This can be known by Kaplan Meier survival analysis.
  • Screening of colonic cancer is done by colonoscopy.
  • From above mentioned option colon cancer has highest 5-year post-screening survival rate.

SCREENING TESTS OF OTHER OPTIONS

Option A: Prostate cancer

  • Prostate specific antigen + DRE

Option C: Lung cancer

  • Chest x-ray

Option D: Ovarian cancer

  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) & CA-125 blood test.

Learning Objective

  • Colonic cancer has highest 5-year survival rate post-screening among the different cancer mention above, according to Kaplan Meier. Screening of colonic cancer is done by colonoscopy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for contraception advice. She has a history of epilepsy for which is been on phenytoin for the last 2 years. She is been using condoms as a method of contraception for the past 2 years. Which of the following contraception method is not indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

  • Oral contraceptive pills are relatively contraindicated in this patient because Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and it will increase the metabolism of OCP. Which will indeed decrease the blood concentration of OCP leading to decreased efficacy of OCP.
  • Thus, this will lead to contraception failure. Because of the interaction between enzyme inducers.
  • Contraception failure in patients taking phenytoin can also cause a congenital defect in the fetus, because of which OCP is contraindicated in this patient.

Option B: IUCD

  • IUCD is a long-term method and very effective method of contraception.
  • The mechanism of action of Copper IUCD is, that it releases copper which is very toxic to the sperm. It prevents the entry of sperm into the uterus.
  • The mechanism of IUCD is not altered by Phenytoin. Therefore, it is not contraindicated for this patient. Rather it is indicated in this patient owing to its efficacy.

Option C: Condoms

  • Condoms are a barrier method of contraception.
  • Enzyme inducers like phenytoin will not alter its mechanism.
  • Condoms provide production against sexually transmitted diseases.

Option D: Vaginal sponge

  • The vaginal sponge is also a barrier method of contraception and like condoms, its mechanism is not altered by phenytoin.
  • Available by the brand name “TODAY”

questions.text: A 20-year-old female from a rural village presented to the PHC with severe itching in her scalp and numerous white nits visible on her scalp. The physician identified the causative agent of the disease to be a louse. All of the following diseases spread through Louse, except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Filariasis

  • Filariasis - A wide range of mosquitoes can transmit the parasite, depending on the geographic area. In Africa, the most common vector is Anopheles and in the Americas, it is Culex quinquefasciatus. Aedes and Mansonia can transmit the infection in the Pacific and in Asia. not louse.

Other options

Option A: Trench fever

  • Trench fever: A rickettsial disease limited to Central Europe.
    • Causative agent: Bartonella Quintana (earlier, Rochalimaea Quintana).
    • Vector: Louse
    • Reservoir: Humans
    • Mode of transmission: Louse feces
    • Drug of choice: Tetracycline.

Option B: Pediculosis

  • An infection of the hairy areas of the body or clothing with lice eggs, larvae, or adults is known as pediculosis.
  • This bug feeds on human blood in its crawling stages, which can cause intense itching.
  • Crab lice are typically found in the pubic region, head lice on the scalp, and body lice along clothing seams.

 

Option D: Epidemic typhus

  • Epidemic Typhus: It is a type of rickettsial disease of the typhus group.
    • Vector: Louse (P. capitis, P. corporis).
    • Mode of transmission (IS NOT BY LOUSE-BITE): Scratching and inoculation with infected louse feces, Crushing infected louse on the body, and Inhalation of infected louse feces or dust.
    • Clinical picture: Prolonged febrile illness, vasculitis.
    • Drug of choice: Tetracycline

questions.text: A 23-year-old sexual worker visited the hospital for getting vaccinated against HPV as she was not vaccinated before. Which of the following is the correct type of HPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option D: Bivalent & Quadrivalent

  • Currently, two Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) vaccines are available in India as a protection against cervical cancer.
  • Gardasil vaccine: HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18 (Quadrivalent).
  • Cervarix vaccine: HPV types 16, 18 (Bivalent).

Other options

Option A: Monovalent

  • There is no monovalent HPV vaccine available.

Option B: Bivalent

  • The HPV vaccine Cervarix is a bivalent vaccine, that gives protection against HPV type-16,18.
  • Bivalent HPV vaccines protect against two HPV types, typically HPV 16 and HPV 18, which are known to be high-risk types associated with cervical cancer. They are designed to provide protection against these two specific HPV types.

Option C: Quadrivalent

  • The HPV vaccine Gardasil is a quadrivalent vaccine.
  • Gardasil vaccine: HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18 (Quadrivalent).
  • Quadrivalent HPV vaccines provide protection against four HPV types: HPV 16, HPV 18 (high-risk types), and HPV 6 and HPV 11 (low-risk types). These vaccines offer broader protection against both cervical cancer and genital warts.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to draw some study designs. Identify the study design given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option D - Nested case-control study

  • The given image depicts a Nested case-control study.
  • Nested case-control study:
  • - Type of cohort Study
  • Temporality → forward-looking study
  • Only done in
    • New & Rare diseases
    • If Diagnostic tests are very Expensive.
  • It is a small case-control study that is nested in a big cohort study.

Other options

Option A - Cross-sectional study

  • Cross-sectional study:
    • Aka Snapshot study/ Prevalence study (as prevalence is calculated).
    • Done at point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
    • Based on primary data.
    • Can't calculate the strength of association.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study

  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of a prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.

Option C - Case-control, study

  • Case-control study is better for rare diseases.
  • Case-control study has 2 groups
    1. Cases: Having the disease
    2. Controls: They are comparison groups not having the disease
  • We ask about the history of the same exposure in both groups & then compare both groups.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a sudden syncopal episode while playing with his grandchildren. He is currently alert and describes occasional substernal heaviness and shortness of breath. His lungs have bibasilar rales and BP is 120/80mmHg. Which is the classical finding expected in this patient?

choices.text: Ejection systolic murmur with Narrow split S2
Ejection systolic murmur with a wide split S2
Harsh Holosystolic murmur with soft S2
Harsh pan-systolic murmur with loud S2

questions.solution:
Option A: Ejection of systolic murmur with Narrow split S2

  • The clinical presentation of exertional syncope, angina equivalent and dyspnea in the geriatric age group points to the diagnosis of valvular Aortic stenosis.
  • Ejection systolic murmur and narrow split S2 are seen in aortic stenosis


Aortic Stenosis:

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • An early systolic ejection sound is frequently audible in children, adolescents, and young adults with congenital BAV disease.
  • This sound usually disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid.
  • As aortic stenosis increases in severity, LV systole may become prolonged so that the aortic valve closure sound no longer precedes the pulmonic valve closure sound, and the two components may become synchronous, or aortic valve closure may even follow pulmonic valve closure, causing paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • The sound of aortic valve closure can be heard most frequently in patients with AS who have pliable valves, and calcification diminishes the intensity of this sound.
  • Frequently, an S4 is audible at the apex and reflects the presence of LV hypertrophy and an elevated LV end-diastolic pressure; an S3 generally occurs late in the course, when the LV dilates, and its systolic function becomes severely compromised.
  • The murmur of AS is characteristically an ejection (mid) systolic murmur that commences shortly after the S1, increases in intensity to reach a peak towards the middle of the ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure.
  • It is characteristically low-pitched, rough, rasping, and loudest at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.
  • It is transmitted upward along the carotid arteries.
  • Occasionally it is transmitted downward and to the apex, where it may be confused with the systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation (MR) (Gallavardin effect).
  • In almost all patients with severe obstruction and preserved CO, the murmur is at least grade III/ VI.
  • In patients with mild degrees of obstruction or severe stenosis with heart failure and low CO in whom the stroke volume and the transvalvular flow rate is reduced, the murmur may be relatively soft and brief.

Option B: Ejection of systolic murmur with a wide split S2

  • Aortic stenosis causes a narrow split S2 or paradoxical split S2.

Option C: Harsh Holosystolic murmur with soft S2

  • The murmur of aortic stenosis is ejection systolic, not harsh holosystoliic.

Option D: Harsh pan-systolic murmur with loud S2

  • The S2 heart sound intensity decreases due to immobile leaflets worsening aortic stenosis.
  • The A2 component may not be audible in severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to breathlessness and palpitations for 2 days. It is associated with fatigue. Her past medical history includes a history of rheumatic fever (RF) at the age of 15 years. She was prescribed penicillin at that time, but she had been non-compliant. She has no family history of heart disease. Her blood pressure is 123/82mmHg, her pulse is 63/min, and her BMI is 23kg/m2. Auscultation reveals a mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is also called Floppy valve syndrome or Barlow syndrome.
  • Causes of MVP include:
  • Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus
  •  Marfan syndrome
  •  Ehler Danlos syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Anteroposterior diameter decrease
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Ostium secondum atrial septal defect (ASD)​​​​​​​
  • The patients present with palpitations, lightheadedness, shortness of breath and fatigue.
  • The mitral valve presents with mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur.
  • The mid-systolic click occurs due to extra tension generated in the chordae tendineae during exercise.
  • The late systolic murmur occurs due to the leakage of blood into the left atrium.
  • Chest x-ray, echocardiograms, ECG, and cardiac catheterization are used to diagnose mitral valve prolapse.
  • Treatment includes using beta-blockers, diuretics, antiarrhythmics, anticoagulants and antibiotics.
  • Complications include mitral valve regurgitation and arrhythmias.
  • Mitral valve repair or replacement is required in cases of severe mitral regurgitation.

Option B: Hamman-rich syndrome

  • Hamman-rich syndrome is an idiopathic interstitial lung disease.
  • It progresses rapidly and may lead to ARDS and fulminant respiratory failure.

Option C: Rheumatic aortic regurgitation

  • Rheumatic aortic regurgitation causes an early diastolic murmur.
  • A mid-diastolic murmur will be heard in severe aortic regurgitation, called the Austin flint murmur.

Option D: Congenital mitral stenosis

  • The mitral valve controls blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle of the heart, and the narrowing of this valve is known as mitral stenosis.
  • Congenital mitral stenosis leads to mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old construction worker comes to the clinic for a follow-up. He was diagnosed with hypertension and started on losartan and amlodipine 6 months back. He still had high blood pressure, due to which thiazide was added to his medication regimen. Today, he continues to have an elevated blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg. Physical examination is normal, electrolytes are normal, and he is not taking any over-the-counter medications. Which is the next helpful step in the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Check pill count

  • The patient is suffering from resistant hypertension, which is defined as persistently high blood pressure despite being on an optimum dose of three antihypertensive medications of different classes.
  • The leading cause of resistant hypertension is non-compliance on the part of the patient.
  • Ideally, one of the 3 agents should be a diuretic, and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts.

Option B: Perform renal doppler

  • Renal doppler is used to look for renal artery stenosis, which can be responsible for resistant hypertension.
  • However, the patient had no abdominal bruit, and medication non-compliance is more commonly associated with this condition.
  • If the pill count checks out, then investigations should be done to determine other causes of resistant hypertension.

Option C: MRI Aorta

  • MRI aorta is the most accurate way to check for arterial compliance in the aorta.
  • Long-term hypertension can cause stiffening of the aorta, hence decreasing arterial compliance.
  • This technique will tell us about the effect of long-term hypertension on the patient’s cardiovascular system. It will tell nothing about the cause of resistant hypertension.

Option D: Adrenal CT scan

  • Adrenal CT scan can be used to look for adrenal adenoma or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Both these conditions will present with resistant hypertension due to excess aldosterone secretion in the blood.
  • The patient will also have hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis in this case. This patient’s electrolytes are normal, making this condition less likely.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the paediatrician by her mother with complaints of delayed growth. The mother also reports that the child complains of backache and leg pain. On examination, his legs appear bent, and he has a waddling gait. He is at the 10th percentile for length,15th percentile for weight, and 50th percentile for head circumference. Lab investigations show a standard metabolic profile, with normal calcium, phosphorus, 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and parathyroid hormone levels. However, the serum ALP level is low. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hypophosphatasia

  • The disease is caused by a deficiency of tissue nonspecific (bone/liver/kidney) alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP)
  • Defective Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) permits the accumulation of its major naturally occurring substrates, including phosphoethanolamine (PEA), inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), and pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP).
  • The accumulation of PPi interferes with mineralisation through its action as a potent inhibitor of hydroxyapatite crystal growth.
  • Hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria are common.
  • Because of the large number of described mutations in the TNSALP gene and variable clinical expression, the disease severity varies widely. It has the following joint presentation depending upon the age of the patient:
  • During the perinatal period, it is lethal.
  • During infancy, the initial development appears normal; however, rachitic deformities develop by age six months, and approximately 50 % of affected patients die during infancy.
  • It presents premature loss of deciduous teeth, delayed walking, and shuffling gait during childhood. The Symptoms may improve spontaneously after puberty and recur later in life.
  •  During adulthood, it is most commonly characterised by poorly healing, recurrent metatarsal stress fractures, and bone pain (thighs and hips).

Management

  • The treatment is usually supportive.
  • A low-calcium diet, glucocorticoids, and calcitonin have been used in a small number of patients with variable responses. Because fracture healing is poor intramedullary rods may be used.
  • In 2015, asfotase alfa, a nonspecific tissue ALP was approved as enzyme replacement therapy for perinatal/infantile- and juvenile-onset forms

Option A: Hypoparathyroidism

  • The most common aetiology of hypoparathyroidism is the autoimmune or surgical destruction of parathyroid glands. The other causes include abnormal parathyroid gland development, altered regulation of parathyroid hormone (PTH), and impaired PTH action on end organs.
  • It results in hypocalcemia and triggers various symptoms, such as muscle cramps, seizures, and heart failure.
  • Laboratory findings include hypocalcemia with low or inappropriately normal PTH and hyperphosphatemia with normal renal function.

Option C: Hyperparathyroidism

  • Hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is characterised by abnormally high parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in the blood due to overactivity of the parathyroid glands.
  • Its clinical presentation ranges from asymptomatic to bone pain, gastric ulcers, and kidney stones.
  • Hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is characterised by elevated parathyroid hormone and ALP levels.

Option D: Pseudopseudo-hypoparathyroidism

  • It is a rare condition due to defective Gs protein α subunit inherited from the father (GNAS gene imprinting).
  • However, because of the mother's normal allele, there is no end-organ resistance to PTH.
  • The clinical features include Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (round face, short stature, obesity, brachydactyly of the 4th and 5th fingers, intellectual disability, and subcutaneous ossifications).
  • The laboratory investigations show normal calcium, PTH, and phosphate.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the outpatient department with complaints of intermittent headaches and palpitations for a few months. She is noted to have profuse sweating. On examination, her blood pressure was 155/95 mmHg, and (electrocardiogram)ECG showed sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 108 beats/min. She underwent extensive investigations and was diagnosed with Pheochromocytoma. Which of the following hormones would be secreted in a higher concentration in such a patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Norepinephrine

  • Normally, the adrenal medulla secretes epinephrine>norepinephrine.
  • The major catecholamine secreted in a Pheochromocytoma is norepinephrine in 80% of the cases.
  • The term paraganglioma is used to describe catecholamine-producing tumours in the head and neck. These tumours may secrete little or no catecholamines.
  • If the size of Pheochromocytoma is < 5cm, then the major catecholamine produced is epinephrine.
  • If Pheochromocytoma is seen with MEN 2A, the major catecholamine produced is epinephrine.

Option B: Epinephrine

  • Most pheochromocytomas also produce epinephrine. But in 80% of the cases, the major hormone produced is Norepinephrine. About a 3rd of pheochromocytomas exclusively produce norepinephrine.

Option C: Dopamine

  • Dopamine is also one of the hormones produced by many pheochromocytomas, but its concentration is very low compared to Norepinephrine or Epinephrine.

Option D: Vanillylmandelic Acid

  • Catecholamines are metabolised into Vanillylmandelic acid and HMA, the nonactive products to be secreted out of the body.
  • VMA and HMA levels in urine are usually measured to aid the diagnosis of Pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 22-years-old female, G2P1L1, gave birth to a term baby girl of weight 3.2kgs in a hospital. The mother has no chronic medical condition and taking all her required supplements. Her vitals are within normal range. Routine neonatal screening tests are done. Neonatal screening for congenital hypothyroidism showed a TSH value of 38 mIU/ml & free T4 value of 0.5 ng/dl. What is the most common presentation in such a neonate?
questions.solution:
Option D: Asymptomatic at birth

  • Neonatal screening for congenital hypothyroidism showed a TSH value of 38mIU/ml & free T4 value of 0.5ng/dl.
  • It is caused by abnormal thyroid gland development or dyshormogenesis in iodine-sufficient regions.
  • Most commonly, infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic at birth.
  • But some are presented by the following characters:
  • Puffy face
  • Paleness
  • Protuberant tongue
  • Protruding umbilicus
  • Potbelly
  • Poor brain development

 

  • Sluggish feeding 
  • constipation 
  • Lethargic 
  • sleep more, needs to be awakened to feed
  • Hoarse cry
  • Hypothermia 
  • Cardiomegaly 
  • Murmur
  • Asymptomatic pericardial effusion 
  • Macrocytic anemia 
  • hypotonic with slow reflexes 
  • prolonged physiological jaundice 

other options

Option A: Prolongation of physiological jaundice

  • It occurs in the case of congenital hypothyroidism, but most neonates are asymptomatic at birth.
  • It is defined as jaundice that lasts more than 14 to 21 days.

 

Option B: Wide open posterior fontanelle

  • It occurs in the case of congenital hypothyroidism, but most neonates are asymptomatic at birth.
  • Large-size fontanelle (both anterior and posterior) are early signs in symptomatic neonates.

Option C: Enlarged tongue and feeding problems

  • It occurs in congenital hypothyroidism, but most neonates are asymptomatic at birth.
  • It also occurs in many other cases like Down syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, acromegaly and primary amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 26 years male presents to opd with complaints of pain abdomen, nausea and vomiting for 5 hours. He says that the pain is intolerable and radiating to the umbilicus. There is a history of 2 episodes of hematuria. USG revealed multiple renal stones. Urinalysis is done, and the following urine crystals are seen. These stones are made of which of the following substance?
questions.solution:
Option A: Calcium oxalate

  • Etiologies:
    • Hypercalciuria
    • Hyperoxaluria
    • Hypocitraturia
    • Can result from increased intake of Ethylene glycol (antifreeze)
    • Vitamin C
    • Associated with inflammatory bowel disease, i.e., ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease due to malabsorption
  • Crystals are Biconcave dumbbells or bipyramidal envelopes.
  • Urine pH is low
  • Stone is radio-opaque
  • Urine alkalinization is chosen for prophylaxis.

Option B: Uric acid

  • The stones are rounded rhomboids, rosettes, or needle-shaped.

Option C: Calcium phosphate

  • Calcium phosphate stones are Wedge-shaped prisms.

Option D: Cysteine

  • Cysteine stones are hexagonal.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of swelling of her feet and ankles. She has a 10-year-long history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension. The physician suspects diabetic nephropathy. Which one of the following studies is most sensitive for detecting diabetic nephropathy in the early stage?
questions.solution:
Option A: Microalbuminuria

  • A common consequence of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes, diabetic nephropathy affects the kidneys.
  • Diabetes that is not well managed can, over the course of time, cause damage to blood vessel clusters in the kidneys, which are responsible for filtering waste from the blood. This can result in damage to the kidneys in addition to causing high blood pressure.
  • The sensitive filtering mechanism of the kidneys can sustain further harm if the patient has high blood pressure since this condition causes the pressure there to rise.
  • The presence of microalbuminuria is indicated by the excretion of 30-300 mg of albumin every 24 hours (20-200 mcg/min or 30-300 mcg/mg Creatinine) on at least two out of three urine collections.
  • The diagnosis of microalbuminuria, often known as low levels of albumin excretion, has been associated with the early detection of diabetic kidney disease. At this stage, vigorous care is required in order to stop or slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy.

Option B: Creatinine clearance test

  • Creatinine clearance test detects diabetic nephropathy at a later stage of diabetic nephropathy.

Option C: Ultrasonography

  • USG is not useful in diagnosing diabetic nephropathy.

Option D: Serum creatinine level

  • Serum creatinine level rises at a later stage of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of headache, swelling on both ankles and puffiness of the face, and generalised weakness. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and his pulse is 80 beats/min. In addition to generalised oedema, cervical lymphadenopathy is also noted on examination. He is a truck driver by occupation. His investigations reveal hypercholesterolemia, raised serum creatinine, hypoalbuminemia and a CD4 count of 150. Rapid HIV test is positive. HBV and HCV are negative by a rapid test kit. Urine analysis reveals nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis

  • The patient in the given scenario has a positive rapid HIV test and CD4 count of 150, suggesting that the patient has an HIV infection.
  • Isolated nephrotic range proteinuria secondary to HIV infection indicates HIV nephropathy.
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults associated with an HIV infection.
  • The patient usually presents with signs of nephrotic syndrome along with kidney injury, which is signified by raised creatinine and high blood pressure in this patient.

Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • It is usually idiopathic but may be associated with malignancies (Hodgkin’s lymphoma), not HIV.
  • It usually presents with selective proteinuria and normal kidney function tests initially.
  • The patient’s age, HIV infection and raised creatinine make this diagnosis less likely.

Option C: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous Nephropathy can be associated with infections, autoimmune conditions and solid organ malignancies.
  • The infections this condition is associated with are hepatitis B and C, not HIV.
  • This patient has a positive rapid test for HIV, but they are negative for HBV and HCV, making this diagnosis less likely.​​​​​​​

Option D: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis

  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is usually a nephritic syndrome but can present with nephrotic range proteinuria in advanced disease.
  • It is associated with either an autoimmune condition such as SLE or an infection such as HBV or HCV.
  • This patient has HIV nephropathy, which is associated with FSGS, making MPGN a less likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with chronic complaints of burning sensation and discomfort over the epigastrium. He has a duodenal ulcer and H. pylori infection on endoscopy and biopsy. He has been prescribed proton pump inhibitors (PPI) & advised to follow up. Which of the following is a side effect of prolonged intake of PPI?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decreasing the effect of clopidogrel

  • Clopidogrel, an inactive prodrug, is converted to a thiolactone intermediate and then to an active metabolite that binds irreversibly to ADP receptors on the platelet surface.

  • Multiple cytochrome (CYP) enzymes catalyze these two stages, with CYP2C19 playing an essential role in both.

  • As with most CYP enzymes, CYP2C19 activity can be altered by other medicines, and CYP2C19 inhibitors can theoretically reduce clopidogrel's antiplatelet efficacy by interfering with its bioactivation.

  • PPIs' competitive suppression of CYP2C19 is the theoretical basis for their interaction with clopidogrel.

Option B: Wrist fracture

  • The incidence of all fractures, severe osteoporotic fractures, hip fractures, vertebral fractures, and other fractures rose with PPI usage, but not the risk of wrist and humerus fractures.

  • The risk of any fractures, major osteoporotic fractures, and other fractures increased for PPI adherence when the proportion of days covered (PDC) was less than 0.80.

Option C: Eradication of Clostridium difficile infection

  • PPIs significantly reduce the amount of stomach acid produced, which promotes spores' growth and capacity to transform into a vegetative form of C. difficile.

  • PPIs also hinder leukocyte activity by preventing phagocytosis and acidifying the phagolysosome.

Option D: Decreased risk of community-acquired pneumonia

  • Proton pump inhibitors are associated with an increased, not decreased, risk of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with the complaints of multiple episodes of diarrhoea approximately for the past 2 months accompanied by weight loss. Occasional blood streaks are noted in the stool. On examination, the patient looks weak with mild pallor. Ulcerative colitis is suspected. What will be the earliest radiological finding on barium enema?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fine mucosal granularity

Fluoroscopy of ulcerative colitis:

  • Double-contrast barium enema allows for exquisite detail of the colonic mucosa and the bowel proximal to strictures to be assessed.
  • It is, however, contraindicated if severe acute colitis is present due to the risk of perforation.
  • Mucosal inflammation leads to a granular appearance on the surface of the bowel.
  • As inflammation increases, the bowel wall and haustra thicken. Mucosal ulcers are undermined (button-shaped ulcers).
  • When most of the mucosa has been lost, islands of mucosa remain, giving it a pseudopolyp appearance. In chronic cases, the bowel becomes featureless with the loss of normal haustral markings, luminal narrowing, and bowel shortening (lead pipe sign).
  • Small islands of residual mucosa can grow into thin worm-like structures (so-called filiform polyps)
  • Colorectal carcinoma in the setting of ulcerative colitis is more frequently sessile and may appear to be a simple stricture.

Option A: Loss of haustrations

  • Loss of haustration is a late finding of ulcerative colitis.

Option C: Pipe stem colon

  • In extended standing UC, Luminal narrowing combined with the loss of haustrations results in the pipe-stem appearance of the colon.

Option D: Collar button ulcer

  • Once the granular appearance develops after the inflammation, a continued inflammation results in collar button ulcer formation.

questions.text: You are a first-year medicine resident rotating in the department of haematology. A group of patients came for follow-up after having allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Which of the following has the least 5-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Blast crisis in CML

  • Blast crisis in CML has the least five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • The median survival time is <1.5 years.

Option A: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency syndrome

  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency syndrome has a 90% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Aplastic Anemia

  • Aplastic anaemia has a 90% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia has a 50% five-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 30 years old man is brought to the hospital by ambulance after a road traffic accident. He was an unrestrained passenger and sustained considerable trauma. He was given a blood transfusion in the OT and developed tachycardia, hypotension (BP 70/40 mm of Hg), temperature 100°F and haematuria within 10 minutes of starting the transfusion. Which of the following is most likely the reason for his presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: ABO incompatibility

  • This is likely a case of ABO incompatibility. It is a type 2 hypersensitivity.
  • It presents with hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and fever.
  • The patient develops intravascular hemolysis leading to hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria, and jaundice develops due to intravascular hemolysis.
  • Hemolysis leads to acute renal failure.
  • Reaction due to ABO incompatibility typically occurs within 1 hour.
  • Hemolysis occurs due to transfusion reaction by the preformed antibody.
  • Positive Coombs test is found in ABO incompatibility.

Option A: Anesthetic drug hypersensitivity

  • Anaesthetic drug hypersensitivity usually occurs immediately in patients who have undergone major surgery.
  • Tachycardia, hypotension, and vasodilation are the usual presentation in this condition.
  • Most inhalational agents cause vasodilatation.

Option B: Disseminated intravascular coagulation

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation presents with bleeding from venepuncture sites, GIT, lungs, and skin and along with thrombosis of microcirculation and large vessels.

Option C: Graft-versus-host disease

  • Graft-versus-host disease presents with fever, maculopapular rash, diarrhoea, and LFT abnormalities.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to an inability to swallow and hoarseness for 3 hours. His wife reports multiple episodes of vomiting and lightheadedness for the last few days. Physical examination reveals gait ataxia, miosis and ptosis on the left side, along with reduced pain and temperature sensations on the right side of the body. Deviation of the uvula to the right side is also seen. Which of the following arteries is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

  • The patient presents with the lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) clinical features.
  • The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) supplies the lateral medulla.
  • Ischemia of the lateral medulla produces symptoms depending upon the structures involved.
  • The inability to swallow implies that the cranial nerve XII (Hypoglossal nerve) is involved.
  • Hoarseness of voice is related to cranial nerve X (Vagus nerve) involvement.
  • Dizziness and vomiting indicate the involvement of the vestibular nucleus.
  • Ataxic gait implies the involvement of the cerebellum (posterior circulation involvement)
  • Loss of pain and temperature on one side of the body means the lateral spinothalamic tract is also involved.
  • Right-sided deviation of the uvula means that the vagus nerve is involved (left vagus nerve).

Option A: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery supplies the pons.
  • CN V, VI, and VII are involved due to blockage of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

Option B: Posterior cerebral artery

  • The posterior cerebral artery supplies the midbrain.
  • A stroke involving the posterior cerebral artery causes CN III and CN IV lesions.

Option D: Lenticulostriate artery

  • The lenticulostriate artery supplies the cerebral cortex.
  • Occlusion of the lenticulostriate artery presents as hemiplegia.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic with walking difficulty and bilateral foot deformity. There is no history of speaking difficulty, nystagmus, diplopia and cardiopulmonary problems. Vital signs are within normal range. On physical examination, thickened peripheral nerves and sensory gait ataxia is observed. The patient is unable to dorsiflex the foot. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Charcot Marie Tooth disease

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to the defective proteins involved in myelin sheath structure and function.
  • It results in foot abnormalities and motor/sensory deficits.
  • The image shows the presence of Pes Cavus which indicates distal muscle weakness.
  • Concomitant sensory deficit leads to Gait ataxia.
  • Nerve biopsy: Classical onion bulb appearance s/o Charcot Marie Tooth disease.
  • Charcot Marie Tooth disease ( Hereditary sensorimotor neuropathy) manifests as:
  • Peroneal muscle dystrophy
  • Stork leg appearance
  • Thickened nerves
  • Nerve biopsy: Onion bulb appearance
  • Distal weakness

Option A: Friedreich ataxia

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to repeat trinucleotide (GAA) on chromosome 9.
  • It leads to mitochondrial dysfunction.
  • It is associated with diabetes mellitus and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (the main cause of death).
  • Dysarthria and nystagmus are also present.
  • Foot abnormalities (pes cavus and hammer toe) are present along kyphoscoliosis.
  • It has the following degenerative abnormalities;
    • Spastic paralysis (lateral corticospinal tract)
    • Ataxia (spinocerebellar tract)
  • Decrease in vibration and proprioception (dorsal column and root ganglia)

​​​​Option B: Ataxia telangiectasia

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder with a defect in the ATM gene on chromosome 11.
  • There is a failure to detect DNA damage and cease the cell cycle progression.
  • It mainly occurs in a child who has been exposed to radiation.
  • The main features are given below:
    • Ataxia (cerebellar defects)
    • Telangiectasia/spider angiomas
  • IgA deficiency (sinopulmonary problems)​​​​​​​
  • There is an increase in alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and a decrease in immunoglobins.
  • It causes an increased risk of lymphoma and leukaemia.

Option D: Guillain-Barre syndrome

  • It is an autoimmune condition that destroys Schwann cells by inflammation and demyelination of motor fibres, sensory fibres and peripheral nerves.
  • It is characterised by;
    • Ascending muscle paralysis
    • Decrease deep tendon reflexes 
    • Facial paralysis
    • Respiratory failure​​​​​​​
  • It is associated with respiratory infections (viral infections like Zika) or gastrointestinal infections (campylobacter jejuni).
  • Other abnormalities are also present, like sensory deficit, cardiac abnormalities, hypertension or hypotension.
  • Labs show an increase in CSF protein with normal cell count.
  • Respiratory support is mainly needed in such patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents in OPD with a history of swelling and severe pain in his great toe since last night. On examination, tenderness is positive, and warmth of the joint is noticed. The physician suggested a microscopic examination of the synovial fluid of the affected joint; hence, aspiration of synovial fluid was done. On Polarised microscopy, the following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Uric acid

  • The image shows the presence of needle-shaped uric acid crystals on polarised light microscopy, making gout the most likely diagnosis.
  • Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis.
  •  Patients usually have gout episodes lasting for several days when their gout flares and are mostly symptom-free between the episodes.
  • An acute episode typically develops its maximal intensity within 12 hours.
  • The main features it presents are pain: which is often very significant, swelling, erythema, and warmth. Most of the first presentations affect the 1st metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
  • Attacks of gout affecting this area were historically called podagra. Other commonly affected joints include the ankle, wrist, and knee.
  • If untreated, repeated acute gout episodes can damage the joints, resulting in more chronic joint problems and deformities.
  • Investigations for gout include: 
    • Synovial fluid analysis (needle-shaped negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals under polarised light).
    • Negative Birefringence: Needle-shaped Urate crystals and apple green.
    • Positive Birefringence: Calcium pyrophosphate crystals.
    • Serum Uric acid levels: should be checked once the acute episode has settled down (typically 2 weeks later), as they may be high, normal, or low during the acute attack.
  • Acute management consists of NSAID or colchicine as first-line drug treatments.

Option B: Calcium Pyrophosphate

  • Calcium Pyrophosphate crystals are present in the synovial fluid of a patient with pseudogout.
  • Pseudogout is a form of microcrystal synovitis disease caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the synovium of the joint space. For this reason, it is termed acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease.
  • Pseudogout is associated with increasing age and Patients who develop pseudogout at a younger age (< 60 years) usually have some underlying risk factors and systemic illnesses such as hemochromatosis, hyperparathyroidism, low magnesium, low phosphate, etc.
  • Pseudogout does not affect the small joints, but the knee, wrist, and shoulders are most commonly affected, and joint aspiration shows: weakly-positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals.

Option C: Calcium phosphate

  • Calcium phosphate stones are the type of renal stones that may occur in renal tubular acidosis, and high urinary pH increases the supersaturation of urine with calcium and phosphate; more specifically, Renal tubular acidosis types 1 and 3 increase the risk of stone formation (types 2 and 4 do not).
  • Calcium phosphate stones are radio-opaque stones (composition similar to bone) and are not deposited in synovial joint spaces.

Option D: Cystine

  • Cystine stones are a type of renal stone that are Semi-opaque and have a ground-glass' appearance in radiographs.
  • They are associated with a disease called Cystinuria, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the formation of recurrent renal stones.
  • It is due to a defect in cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine membrane transport.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents to the general physician setting with complaints of morning stiffness associated with increased pain intensity after periods of inactivity and on/off pain in the buttock region. He also complained of photosensitivity and blurring of vision. On examination, the slit lamp showed findings of keratic precipitates on the back of the cornea. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) typically involves a young man who presents with lower back pain and stiffness of insidious onset and gradual increase in intensity.
  • Stiffness is usually worse in the morning and improves with exercise and movement.
  • The patient with AS may experience pain at night, which improves after getting up and with mobility.
  • Keratic precipitates are classically seen in anterior uveitis.
  • On examination, lateral and forward flexion is reduced, and decreased chest expansion.
  • Other features of AS include Apical fibrosis, Anterior uveitis, Aortic regurgitation, Achilles tendonitis, AV node block, Amyloidosis, etc.
  • The first-line investigation of choice is the x-ray of the iliac joint.
  • If the x-ray is negative of the sacroiliac joint involvement in ankylosing spondylitis, but the suspicion for AS is high, then the next step in the evaluation of the disease should be obtaining an MRI of the sacroiliac joint.
  • Signs of early inflammation involving sacroiliac joints (bone marrow edema) confirm the diagnosis of AS and prompt further treatment.
  • Treatment includes: NSAIDs are the first-line treatment. Also, encourage the patients to regular exercise mainly through swimming and physiotherapy. TNF therapy should be given to patients with persistently high disease activity despite conventional treatments
  • Uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation of AS, occurring in 20-30% of patients.
  • The incidence is much higher in individuals who are HLA-B27 positive (84- 90%).

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Rheumatoid Arthritis involves the small joint of the hands, which is more common in females.
  • It is diagnosed based on the 2010 rheumatological criteria of diagnosis of RA.
  • Radiological features of RA
    • Evidence of soft tissue swelling and joint effusion.
    • Symmetrical involvement.
    • Juxta-articular osteopenia (within weeks).
    • Loss of articular cartilage and bone erosions (after months).
    • Narrowing of joint space.
    • Articular destruction and joint deformity, e.g. subluxation of atlantoaxial and cervical joints.
    • Lack of hypertrophic bone changes (sclerosis or osteophyte).

Option C: Still’s disease

  • Still’sdisease is also seronegative arthritis which presents as
    • Arthralgia, elevated serum ferritin, salmon-pink, maculopapular rash, and Pyrexia of unknown origin; however, it typically rises in the late afternoon/early evening in a daily pattern and accompanies a worsening of joint symptoms and rash lymphadenopathy.
  • Rheumatoid factor (RF) and antinuclear antibody (ANA) are negative.
  • Still’s disease has a bimodal age distribution (15-25 years) and (35-46 years).
  • The diagnosis of Still's disease in adults can be challenging.
  • The Yamaguchi criteria are the most widely used.

Option D: Reactive arthritis

  • Reactive arthritis is also of the HLA-B27 associated seronegative spondyloarthropathies; it was formerly called Reiter's syndrome, a term which is described as a classic triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and arthritis following a dysenteric illness or less commonly respiratory illnesses. It is not an associated case as presented in the Ques.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency for a 3-day history of dark urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she has a normal mental status; icterus is present, heart and lungs are normal. Her speech is slurred and monotonous. Examination shows a broad-based gait and a low-frequency tremor in her left hand.

Lab findings include:

Hematocrit: 26

Reticulocytes: 5%

Platelets: 1.3 lakhs 

Alk. Phos: 30 units/L 

ALT: 110 units/L

AST: 220 units/L

Total bilirubin:13mg% (Direct:4 mg) 

HbsAg is positive

Hepatitis ‘A’&’C’ are negative. 

The urine drug screen is negative. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a nodular appearing liver and an enlarged spleen. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wilson’s disease

  • Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder in which impaired copper excretion causes Copper to accumulate in the body.
  • Autosomal recessive mutations in the ATP7B gene cause the production of defective ATP7B protein.
    • Reduced incorporation of Copper into apoceruloplasmin leads to decreased serum ceruloplasmin and reduced biliary copper excretion.
  • It results in free serum copper accumulating in the liver, cornea, CNS (basal ganglia, brain stem, cerebellum), kidneys, and enterocytes.
  • In its initial stages, Wilson's disease leads to copper deposits in the liver. As the disease progresses, Copper accumulates in other organs, most importantly in the brain and cornea.
  • Hepatic involvement in Wilson’s disease may range from elevated liver biochemical tests (although the alkaline phosphatase may be low) to cirrhosis and portal hypertension.
  • The neurologic manifestations of Wilson's disease are related to basal ganglia dysfunction and include an akinetic-rigid syndrome similar to parkinsonism, dysarthria, dysphagia, incoordination, and spasticity.
  • Psychiatric features include behavioral and personality changes and emotional lability and may precede characteristic neurologic features. The risk of depression is increased.
  • The pathognomonic sign of the condition is the brownish or grey-green Kayser-Fleischer ring, which represents fine-pigmented granular deposits in the Descemet membrane in the cornea.
  • In the above-mentioned clinical scenario, the patient has clinical findings of hepatosplenomegaly, slurred speech and tremors. These findings are consistent with Wilson's disease.
  • Low hematocrit of 26% and increased reticulocyte count indicate the hemolysis of RBCs because of excess copper accumulation.
  • This hemolysis leads to increased production of unconjugated bilirubin, and damaged hepatocytes also cause imperfect conjugation. Thus, causing jaundice due to increased unconjugated bilirubin.
  • The liver enzymes are also mildly elevated, indicating hepatocyte damage.
  • Moreover, the presence of nodular liver, portal hypertension and splenomegaly indicate chronic liver damage.

Option A: Acetaminophen intoxication

  • Acetaminophen intoxication also causes drug-induced hepatitis. Acetaminophen causes hepatotoxicity by the following mechanism:
  • Exhaustion of hepatic metabolic pathways causes the formation of a toxic metabolite of acetaminophen, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI).
  • Glutathione initially inactivates NAPQI, but its reserves eventually deplete, leading to NAPQI build-up
  • NAPQI build-up causes irreversible oxidative hepatocyte injury, ultimately leading to liver cell necrosis.
  • Symptoms of acetaminophen toxicity include progressive liver damage (RUQ pain and tenderness and abnormal liver function tests).
  • If acute liver failure does not develop, patients typically begin to recover within 2 weeks after ingestion.
  • Moreover, it also causes acute kidney injury in 50% of the patients with liver damage.

Option B: Acute viral hepatitis

  • The clinical presentation of acute viral hepatitis includes fever, malaise, myalgia, RUQ pain and tenderness, nodular liver and splenomegaly.
  • However, liver enzyme elevation is markedly enlarged compared to those in Wilson's disease.

Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis

  • Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune disease which causes chronic, progressive liver disease characterized by the destruction of the intralobular bile ducts and hypercholesterolemia due to altered lipoprotein metabolism.
  • Fatigue is usually the first symptom in patients presenting with this disease.
  • Other symptoms include marked generalized pruritus, hepatomegaly, RUQ discomfort, splenomegaly, hyperpigmentation, jaundice, pale stool and dark urine.

questions.text: A fifty years old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of abdominal pain. The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle but does not smoke or drink alcohol. He likes to eat out, and his diet consists of fried foods daily. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and his BMI is 32. Abdominal examination shows an enlarged, non-tender liver. The liver span, on light percussion, is 20 cm. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, which shows that his liver echogenicity is more than that of the renal cortex and spleen. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Metabolic Syndrome

  • The patient's history and findings suggest nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
  • Primary nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is associated with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.
  • Metabolic syndrome is a combination of diabetes, hypertension and obesity.
  • This causes a high risk of developing coronary heart disease and stroke.
  • Metabolic syndrome is characterized by increased blood pressure, blood glucose levels, triglycerides, and being overweight or having too much fat around the weight.

Option A: Marasmus

  • There is no hepatomegaly seen in marasmus.

Option C: Wilson disease

  • Wilson's disease causes cirrhosis due to excessive copper.

Option D: Nutmeg liver

  • Cardiac cirrhosis is a cause of the nutmeg liver.

questions.text: A 61 years old former heavy smoker with a known case of chronic bronchitis presents to the emergency room with a history of shortness of breath which gradually increased in severity and presented even at rest. He also had peripheral chest pain. He has been undergoing treatment for 3-4 years. The complication least likely to occur in this case is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Spontaneous pneumothorax

  • Chronic bronchitis is the presence of productive cough for three months in two consecutive years.
  • It comprises one type of COPD (chronic obstructive lung disease), the other being emphysema.
  • Chronic bronchitis is due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucus-secreting glands, which results in overproduction and hypersecretion of mucus by goblet cells.
  • Cigarette smoke is the most important cause of chronic bronchitis due to active smoking or passive inhalation.
  • Patients commonly present with chronic productive cough, malaise, and chest or abdominal pain due to excessive coughing.
  • Patients with chronic bronchitis are known as “blue bloaters” because they have a blunted respiratory response to high blood CO2 (hypercarbia), which produces an inappropriately low respiratory drive that results in hypoxemia and cyanosis.
  • Chronic CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.
  • Long-term hypoxia leads to increased hemoglobin production leading to polycythemia.
  • Blue bloaters are typically overweight and have red faces due to polycythemia.
  • Chronic hypoxia in chronic bronchitis leads to pulmonary artery hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax is a complication of the rupture of bullae in an emphysematous patient.

Option A: Pulmonary hypertension

  • Pulmonary hypertension is a common complication of chronic bronchitis/COPD.
  • Mucus production narrows the airways and reduces the flow of oxygen-rich air into the lungs.

Option C: Respiratory acidosis

  • Chronic carbon dioxide retention results in respiratory acidosis.

Option D: Polycythemia

  • Long-term hypoxia leads to increased hemoglobin production leading to polycythemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old footballer was elbowed in the chest by a rival defender during ball possession. Following the chest trauma, the player collapses and dies. The most probable cause of death is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Commotio Cordis

  • Commotio cordis is ventricular fibrillation precipitating due to blunt trauma to the heart. It does not occur due to structural heart damage. Still, it occurs as a result of the distortion of the myocardium creating enough energy to cause inappropriate depolarisation resulting in an unstable dysrhythmia.
  • Blunt, non-penetrating, often innocent-appearing injuries to the chest may trigger ventricular fibrillation even in the absence of overt signs of injury and lead to sudden cardiac death.
  • This syndrome, referred to as Commotio Cordis, occurs most often in adolescents during sporting events (e.g., baseball, hockey, football) and results from an impact to the chest wall overlying the heart during the susceptible phase of repolarisation just before the peak of the T wave.
  • The patient presents with sudden cardiac arrest following an impact over the anterior chest wall overlying the heart.
  • Physical exam reveals a contusion overlying the heart, absence of pulse with ventricular fibrillation on ECG.
  • Survival depends on prompt defibrillation.

Option A: HOCM

  • Familial HOCM is an Autosomal dominant inherited disease in approximately 50% of cases.
  • The most common gene involved is β-myosin heavy chain > Myosin-binding protein C > Troponin T.
  • Clinical features of HOCM
    1. Dyspnea (earliest symptoms) due to Diastolic malfunction (due to small LV cavity), Pooling of blood in lungs, Pulmonary Oedema present
    2. Chest pain on exertion: Sub. Endocardial Ischemia
    3. Effort intolerance
    4. Sudden collapse/death on exercise/ running due to Ischemic ventricular fibrillation, Twitching, Loss of Pulse / BP, Sustained arrhythmias (Atrial Fibrillation)

Option C: Hemo-thorax

  • Blood can build up between the chest wall and the lungs, known as hemothorax.
  • The pleural cavity is the name given to this space where blood may collect.
  • As the blood presses on the exterior of the lung, the accumulation of blood in this area may eventually cause your lung to collapse.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: Aortic transection

  • Traumatic aortic transection, also known as aortic rupture, is a condition in which the aorta almost completely tears through all of its layers due to stress, such as the kind experienced in a fall or a car accident.
  • The magnitude of the force is of high magnitude leading to the tear of all layers.
  • The majority of the time, this disease is fatal and needs urgent medical care.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: The age of onset of OCD seems to have a bimodal distribution, with a peak in childhood (at approximately 10 years of age) and another in early adulthood. There is evidence that brain activity differs in adults with childhood- onset OCD versus adult-onset OCD. Brain areas involved with obsessive compulsive disorder include all except:
questions.solution:
Corpus callosum

  • It is the primary commissural region of the brain consisting of white matter tracts that connect the left and the right cerebral hemispheres
  • This structure is not involved in development of OCD.

Orbito-Frontal Cortex

  • OCD patients have excess activity in the frontal regions of the brain, especially Orbito-Frontal Cortex

Basal Ganglia

  • Caudate Nucleus, which is a part of the Basal Ganglia, is affected in patients with OCD

Head of Caudate Nucleus

  • Caudate nucleus is affected in patients with OCD.

Neuroanatomical Structures Involved in OCD
  1. Orbito-frontal Cortex
  2. Caudate Nucleus (which is a part of Basal Ganglia)
  3. Thalamus
  • How to remember: In OCD - CBT is treatment of choice and OCT anatomical structures are involved.
  • Extra edge: Other important Brain areas and associated psychiatric disorders
Psychiatric Disorders Brain Areas involved
1. Anxiety disorders
  1. Locus ceruleus
  2. Raphe nucleus
  3. Caudate nucleus
  4. Temporal cortex
  5. Frontal cortex
2. Depression Damage to the left frontal lobe
3. Alzheimer's disease Hippocampus

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with a feminine mannerism is presented in the psychiatric office by his mother, who claims that she has seen him occasionally dressing like a female. His friends have also noticed a change in his behavior; he was bullied in high school. On investigation, the patient claims that he knows he is a male and never considers himself of the opposite gender. He denies the urge to change his sexual characteristics. This patient is most likely suffering from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pseudo transsexualism

  • Effeminate males and masculine female homosexuals sometimes cross-dress and occasionally want a sex change. This is called pseudo-Transsexualism
  • Unlike Transsexualism, these patients do not feel part of the other sex and have the urge to change their sex.

Option A: Transsexualism

  • It is the severest form of gender identity disorders
  • There is a sense of discomfort with anatomical sex organs and a desire to get rid of them, i.e., dissatisfaction with allotted sex.
  • Phrases like - I am a male in a female body or vice versa are quite characteristic.
  • Observation for a long period is needed to be very certain of the diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Sex Reassignment Surgery (SRS) with hormonal treatment.

Option B: Tranvestism

  • Episodic crossdressing to have a sense of belonging to the opposite sex is called Dual role Transvestism.
  • Crossdressing to attain sexual excitement is known as Fetishistic Transvestism (occurs exclusively in heterosexual males)
  • In contrast, transexuals wear clothes of the other sex because they feel a part of the other sex, not for sexual excitement

Option D: Paraphilias

  • Paraphilias are disorders of sexual preference in which sexual arousal occurs persistently and significantly in response to objects which are not a part of normal sexual Arousal.

questions.text: Sleep is not a single process; there are several distinct types of sleep. These different types of sleep differ both qualitatively and quantitatively. Sleep is not a passive process; during sleep, there is a high degree of brain activation and metabolism. Which one of the following phenomenon is not associated with slow wave sleep?
questions.solution:
NREM/Slow wave sleep disorders-

  • Seen in stage 3 and 4.
  1. Somnambulism- sleep walking
  2. Somniloquy - sleep talking
  3. Sleep enuresis
  4. Night terror
  5. Bruxism (stage 2)

Features of REM sleep:

  • Sleep Atonia
  • Dreaming
  • Irregular heart rate

HOW TO REMEMBER : B=2nd letter and T for Three. B for Bruxism in stage 2 and T for Terror in stage 3 of sleep.

questions.text: A recent study showed that delirium and associated clinical features are often present and may be prominent. The EEG usually shows diffuse slowing of background activity, although patients with delirium caused by alcohol or sedative-hypnotic withdrawal have low-voltage fast activity. All of the following are features of delirium except:

choices.text: Most common organic mental disorder with an chronic onset
After cataract surgery it is known as black patch delirium

questions.solution:
Option B: A most common organic mental disorder with a chronic onset

  • It is a false statement.
  • DELIRIUM is the most common organic mental disorder with an acute onset.
  • It does not have a chronic onset.
  • More common in elderly patients
  • It is also known as ICU psychosis, Organic Psychosis, Acute Brain Failure, etc.

 

Precipitating factors:

Medical Causes

 

 Drugs

 

 Surgical causes

 
1. Fever

 

 1. Anticholinergics

 

 1. Head injury

 
2. Encephalitis

 

 2. Alcohol and sedatives withdrawal

 

 2. post-operative

 
3. Pneumonia

 

 3. Narcotics

 

 3. Fractures (e.g., hip #) and trauma

 
4. Endocrinal abnormalities

 

 4. Dhatura

 

 4. Admission to ICU

 
5. Dyselectrolemia

 

 5. Treatment with multiple drugs

 

 5. Severe burns

 

 

  • Delirium can also occur when there is sensory deprivation. (e.g., after cataract surgery- known as Black patch delirium)
  • Clinical features:
    • Hallmark- Clouding of consciousness
    • Disorientation to time, place, and person
    • Poor attention and concentration
    • Sleep-wake cycle disturbances
    • Evening worsening of symptoms-Sun downing phenomenon
    • Flocculation/carphologia: Picking behavior of bedsheets
    • Perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations
    • Restlessness
  • Neurotransmitter involved: ↓ Acetylcholine
  • The structure involved: Reticular formation
  • EEG finding: Generalized slowing
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of the underlying cause
    • Drug of Choice:  Haloperidol
  • Delirium is an emergency condition. So, it is always acute.

Option A: Clouding of consciousness is pathognomic

  • It is a true statement.
  • Clouding of consciousness is a hallmark feature of delirium.

Option C: After cataract surgery, it is known as black patch delirium

  • It is a true statement.
  • Delirium can also occur when there is sensory deprivation. (e.g., after cataract surgery- known as Black patch delirium)

Option D: Floccillation is seen

  • It is a true statement.
  • Flocculation/carphologia: Picking behavior of bedsheets is a characteristic feature of delirium

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman attended the outpatient department with a lump measuring 5x4cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. A fine needle aspiration cytology of the lump revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. As a result, she underwent a Patey's modified radical mastectomy. During the procedure, which structure is preserved?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pectoralis major

  • In Patey’s modified mastectomy, the pectoralis major is preserved.
  • Modified Radical mastectomy
