    • Removal of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes with preservation of pectoralis major muscle and medial (anterior thoracic) pectoral nerve.
  • Anatomic boundaries:
    • Anterior margin of latissimus dorsi muscle laterally
    • The midline of the sternum medially
    • Subclavius muscle superiorly
    • 2 to 3 cm inferior to the inframammary fold inferiorly

Options A: Intercostobrachial nerve

  • Intercostobrachial nerve is not preserved during the modified radical mastectomy.

Option C: Pectoralis minor

  • Pectoralis minor is not preserved during the modified radical mastectomy.

Option D:  Axillary fascia

  • Axillary fascia is not preserved during the modified radical mastectomy.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of fever for 1 month and  generalized weakness. She also presents with an anterior neck swelling for 4 years which rapidly progressed in the past 3-4 months, accompanied by pain over the swelling, and hoarseness of voice. The patient further reported a history of recent weight loss and decreased appetite. She denied dysphagia, dyspnea, and any history of cancer in the family. Prior medical history was described as non-significant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anaplastic

  • This patient has had neck swelling for the past 4 years with a rapid progression in size since the last 3-4 months associated with hoarseness of voice and pain over the swelling likely has anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.
  • Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is most commonly seen in life's 7th to 8th decade.
  • It presents more commonly in women.
  • The patients present with a history of neck swelling and a sudden increase in the size of the swelling associated with severe pain over the swelling
  • The most common route of spread is by direct invasion causing compression of the surrounding structures:
    • Dyspnea due to tracheal compression
    • Dysphagia due to esophageal compression
    • Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement
  • The most common site of metastasis is Lungs
  • On FNAC, it shows giant and multinucleated cells
  • Has a poor prognosis due to the aggressive nature of the tumor

Option A: Papillary

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma presents in young patients with a history of radiation exposure.
  • It presents a painless thyroid mass, hard and fixed with irregular borders and regional lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Follicular

  • Most commonly present in the fifth decade of life.
  • Present with an enlargement of the thyroid gland, most commonly asymptomatic, and occasionally show hypo or hyperthyroid symptoms.

Option C: Medullary

  • It is a rare calcitonin-producing tumor originating from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland.
  • Present with symptoms of compression of surrounding organs i.e. dyspnea, dysphagia, and hoarseness
  • It has a history of similar presentation in the family due to RET mutation (the RET proto-oncogene codes the RET receptor tyrosine kinase)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with active alcoholism and chronic hepatitis C presented to the emergency department with hematemesis and hematochezia started 5 days ago. The patient was alert, tachycardic, and hypotensive. Splenomegaly is noted. Upper GI endoscopy showed multiple esophageal varices, mild portal hypertensive gastropathy, and no gastric varices. Which of the following agents is recommended for the medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Octreotide

  • For managing variceal bleeding, somatostatin and its analogs, octreotide, are the agents of choice.
  • It should be initiated at the onset of variceal bleeding.
  • A combination of octreotide and endoscopic therapy is more effective in controlling bleeding and is the preferred treatment for most patients.
  • Although Vasopressin is the most potent available vasoconstrictor, it causes hypertension, myocardial ischemia, arrhythmia, ischemic abdominal pain, and limb gangrene, so it is not used.

Option B: TIPS

  • TIPS (Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt).
  • It is a second-line therapy if the other medications fail.
  • TIPS decreases the portal pressure by channeling between the hepatic vein and the portal vein branch.

Option C: Antibiotics

  • This patient is hemodynamically unstable, so the first target is maintaining blood pressure to make the patient hemodynamically stable, which is life-saving.
  • So the first step is to give IV Fluids and octreotide to decrease the bleeding by causing vasoconstriction of splanchnic vessels.

Option D: Nitroglycerine

  • Nitroglycerine is an important vasodilator. Instead of decreasing bleeding, it will exacerbate this condition.
  • This drug is popular to use in angina.

questions.text: A 39-year old female came to the OPD complaining of pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen for the past 5 days. The patient was further evaluated, and CT abdomen was done. What is your diagnosis based on the sign shown in the CT image?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gallstones

  • The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign; this sign is seen in Gallstones.
    • The center of the gallstone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure; this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on the radiograph suggestive of the Mercedes-Benz sign or Seagull sign.
    • A plain radiograph of the gallbladder will show radiopaque gallstones in 10% of patients.

Option B: Liver abscess

  • In general, they appear as peripherally enhancing, centrally hypoattenuating lesions.
  • Occasionally they appear solid or contain gas in the form of bubbles or air-fluid levels.
  • The “double target sign” is a characteristic imaging feature of hepatic abscess, in which a central low-attenuation lesion (fluid-filled) is surrounded by a high-attenuation inner rim and a low-attenuation outer rim.

Option C: Common bile duct stones

  • The sensitivity of CT to detect stones in the common bile duct is 65%-88%.
  • Target sign: Central round density of the stone and surrounding lower attenuating bile or mucosa.
  • Rim sign: Stone is outlined by a thin shell of density.
  • Crescent sign: Bile eccentrically outlines luminal stone, creating a low attenuation crescent.

Option D: Hydatid cyst

  • Fluid-filled cyst, with frequent peripheral focus areas of calcification, usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • The “water-Lily sign” indicates a cyst with a floating, undulating membrane caused by a detached endocyst.
  • Hyperdense internal septa within a cyst showing a spoke wheel pattern may also be seen.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of dysphagia and hematemesis. Dysphagia affects more solids than liquids. An endoscopic evaluation reveals a mass lesion in the gastroesophageal junction. Which of the following options is most likely associated with tumorsof the gastroesophageal junction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Siewert type II

  • Siewert classification is a system of anatomical classification used for adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction.
  • In type Siewert type II, Adenocarcinoma is present in the real cardia.
  • Its exact location is 1 cm above and 2 cm below the gastroesophageal junction.

Option A: Siewert type I

  • In Siewert type I, adenocarcinoma is present in the distal esophagus.
  • It is 1-5 cm above the gastroesophageal (GE) junction.

Option C: Siewert type III

  • In Siewert type III, Adenocarcinoma is present in the Sub-Cardinal Stomach.
  • Its location is 2-5 cm below the gastroesophageal (GE) junction.

Option D: Siewert type IV

  • This classification has only three types.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted for asymptomatic renal stones. She received extensive resection of the small intestine due to strangulating obstructive ileus 7 years ago. She has a strong family history of renal stones. A plain film of the kidney, ureter, and bladder and a CT scan revealed bilateral renal stones (right 4 mm, left 10 mm). Which of the following could have predisposed the patient to develop urolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Short bowel syndrome

  • Malabsorptive condition that arises secondary to the removal of significant segments of the small intestine.
  • Most common causes are Mesenteric infarction, Crohn's disease, tumours, and radiation enteritis
  • It usually appears when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel
Changes seen in Terminal Ileal Resection
  • Unabsorbed fatty acids bind with calcium. Increased concentration of free oxalates (oxalates bind with calcium normally and therefore escape without intestinal absorption)- Free oxalates are absorbed- Oxalate kidney stones
  • Vitamin B12 Malabsorption- Megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Bile salts Malabsorption-watery diarrhoea
  • Decreased bile salts in the bile−
    • Cholesterol gall stones
    • Steatorrhea and Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins

Option A: Family history of renal stones

  • Kidney stones develop more frequently in individuals with a family history of kidney stones than in those without a family history; however, little information is available regarding whether the increased risk is attributable to genetic factors, environmental exposures, or some combination
  • This patient has a history of small bowel resection, which predisposes him to kidney stones

Option C: Strangulating obstructive ileus

  • Strangulated bowel obstruction is defined as ischemia and infarction of an obstructed loop of the bowel because of the compromised blood supply.
  • The disease itself has no association with the development of kidney stones. However, bowel resection performed as a result of it predisposes to kidney stones.

Option D: Prolonged hospitalization and bedridden

  • The risk factors for kidney stones include metabolic diseases, small bowel resection, recurrent urinary transactions, dehydration, and poor dietary habits.
  • Prolonged hospitalization is not a risk factor for kidney stones.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea for the last two months. He is afebrile and vitally stable. He looks pale and has oral ulcers. His abdominal examination is unremarkable. On further evaluation, in barium contrast studies, the hose pipe appearance of the intestine is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Crohn’s disease

  • Hose-pipe appearance is a feature of Crohn’s disease.
  • Crohn’s disease:
    • Chronic transmural inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract.
    • Radiologic findings:
      • Deep ulcers
      • Hose-pipe appearance (long stricture extending into I/C valve with thickened wall)
      • Fat halo sign
      • Cobblestone appearance
      • Creeping fat sign

Option B: Malabsorption Syndrome

  • Malabsorption syndrome is a digestive disorder that prevents the body from effectively absorbing nutrients from food.
  • It has many causes, but most commonly involves damage to the small intestine's mucous lining.

Option C: Ulcerative Colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease which involves the colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea and abdominal pain along with iron deficiency anaemia.
  • There is a collar button appearance and loss of haustrations.
  • Signs seen:
    • Target sign / Halo sign
    • Comb sign
    • Rose thorning sign
    • Creeping fat sign
    • String sign of Kantor

Option D: Hirschsprung’s disease

  • Hirschsprung's disease is characterised by the absence of ganglionic cells in the distal colon and rectum.
  • It occurs due to the failure of migration of neural crest cells to distal bowel segments and affects cells in both myenteric and submucosal plexuses.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions Oschner-Sherren's regimen is used as management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Appendicular mass

  • The case mentioned above has features of recurrent abdominal pain suggestive of appendicitis and received the Oschner-Sherren regimen. This regimen is indicated in appendicular mass.
  • If an appendix mass is present and the patient's condition is satisfactory, the standard treatment is the conservative Oschner-Sherren regime.
    • Temperature and pulse rate should be recorded 4 hourly.
    • The fluid balance record is maintained.
    • The extent of mass should be marked and examined regularly.
  • Criteria for stopping conservative management of an appendix mass
    • A rising pulse rate
    • Increased or spreading abdominal pain
    • The increasing size of the mass

Option A: Appendicular abscess

  • The appendicular abscess is a collection of pus resulting from necrosis of the tissue superimposed with infection in an inflamed appendix.
  • It is a rare complication of acute appendicitis (preoperatively) or appendectomy (postoperatively).

Option B: Chronic appendicitis

  • Chronic appendicitis is a long-standing inflammation or fibrosis of the appendix that presents clinically as prolonged or intermittent abdominal pain.
  • It might result in complications such as intra-abdominal infections, bowel obstruction, or perforation.

Option D: Acute appendicitis

  • Acute appendicitis is an inflammatory condition of the appendix characterized by acute severe right iliac fossa pain and leukocytosis and requires urgent appendectomy.

questions.text: A 30-year old man presents to the emergency department with extreme abdominal pain radiating to his groin for the last one hour. The ultrasound examination revealed mild hydronephrosis bilaterally. Non-enhanced computer tomography is then performed and shows a 10-mm hyperdense picture in the left ureter topography and a 9-mm hyperdense image in the right ureter topography, consistent with a diagnosis of bilateral ureterolithiasis. Given the clinical feature, which nerve carries the referred pain from the ureteric colic to the groin?
questions.solution:
Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve

  • Clinical sign: Abdominal Pain radiating to the groin, hydronephrosis bilaterally, and hyperdense area indicate ureterolithiasis.
  • Stone in the middle one-third of the ureter→ pain is radiated in the iliac fossa, hypogastrium, and groin via the Iliohypogastric nerve.
  • The most common symptom of ureteric colic is pain.
  • The severity of pain is not related to the size of the stone.
  • Radiation of pain depends on the location of the stone.

Option A: Subcostal nerve

  • Stones in the upper ureter or renal pelvis→ pain is referred to as testis in males and labia majora in females via the subcostal nerve.

Option C: Ilioinguinal nerve

  • Stone located in the distal one-third of the ureter→ pain is referred to in the inner aspect of the thigh, scrotum, and perineum via the Ilioinguinal nerve.
  • Stone located on the left side in the middle one-third of the ureter- Pain is radiated to the left iliac fossa (mimics diverticulitis).
  • Stone on the right side in the middle one-third of the ureter- Pain is radiated to the right iliac fossa (mimics acute appendicitis)

Option D: Genitofemoral nerve

  • Stone located in the distal one-third of ureter→ pain is referred to in the inner aspect of the thigh, scrotum, and perineum via the genitofemoral nerve.
  • Stone located on the left side in the middle one-third of the ureter- Pain is radiated to the left iliac fossa (mimics diverticulitis).
  • Stone on the right side in the middle one-third of the ureter- Pain is radiated to the right iliac fossa (mimics acute appendicitis)

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to a primary care physician complaining of chest discomfort for the last ten days. His primary care physician provides symptomatic treatment, which gives an initial improvement in symptoms. Afterwards, his chest discomfort started again, and he developed progressive dyspnea with exertion. A CT chest reveals a round, well-demarcated mass in the middle mediastinal compartment. Which of the following is rare enough to be included in the middle mediastinal masses found in the patient discussed above?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ganglioneuroma

  • Clinical signs: young age, progressive dyspnea on exertion and radiological evaluation round, well-demarcated mass in middle mediastinum all suggest the differentials of the bronchogenic cyst, ascending aortic aneurysm, pericardial cyst, ganglioneuroma.
  • Ganglioneuromas are usually rare and asymptomatic; some possible symptoms are usually caused by the compression of surrounding structures or hormone secretions (e.g., norepinephrine) and associated effects of them (e.g., diarrhea, hypertension).
  • In autonomic nerve cells, ganglioneuromas most often start to develop and are considered rare tumours. These are usually noncancerous (benign) tumours.
  • The intestines are the most common location of ganglioneuromas. They have a slow growth rate and secrete certain hormones.
  • No known risk factors are there. However, they are associated with genetic disorders such as neurofibromatosis type 1.

Option A: Bronchogenic cysts

  • Bronchogenic cysts form in the mediastinum and are abnormal growths of tissue.
  • They are small in size benign tumours and typically central in location.
  • The most common symptoms include fever, cough, pain, dyspnea, pulmonary infections, and tracheobronchial compression.

Option B: Ascending aortic aneurysm

  • An ascending aortic aneurysm is a focal dilatation on the upper portion of the aorta to more than 1.5 times its normal diameter. They may cause the blood vessel wall to tear or break open as the aneurysms bulge outward.
  • The condition is commonly asymptomatic, but some patients may experience back pain, chest pain, difficulty swallowing, coughing or wheezing, hoarseness, and shortness of breath.
  • A chest X-ray, chest CT scan, and MR angiography are required to diagnose the condition.

Option C: Pericardial cyst

  • The pericardial cyst causes a rare and benign mediastinal mass.
  • They are most commonly asymptomatic, and incidental findings usually help diagnose the condition on imaging.
  • Less common symptoms may include persistent cough, dysphagia, dyspnea, and atypical chest pain.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the hospital for a burn injury. Baby fell into a tub of hot water, father pulled him out and poured water at room temparture over affected areas of lower extremities, abdomen and torso. The burns were initially described as not too bad but later developed into blisters. The best method to assess burns caused by boiling water in a child is?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lund and Browder chart

LUND AND BROWDER CHART

  • It was created by Dr Charles Lund and Dr Newton Browder based on their experiences in treating over 300 burn victims injured at the Cocoanut Grove fire in Boston in 1942.
  • Takes into account different proportional body surface areas in children according to age.
  • Different percentages are used as the ratio of head and neck surface to the body surface is greater in children than in adults.

Option A: Palm method

  • In the case of smaller burns or patches of burn
  • The palmar surface of the hand of the person who is burned (not the fingers or wrist area) accounts for 1 % of total body surface area (TBSA) and is useful for calculating the percentage of burns

Option B: Rule of 9

  • It is not the most accurate method for the calculation of TBSA.
  • It is a crude but quick and effective method of estimating burn size.

Option D: None of the above

  • Lund and Browder chart is the most efficient method to calculate burn in children.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old male patient presented with complaints of painful nodules on the back and upper limbs for several years. She reported the growth of some nodules and an increase in number over time. The patient is obese and has a BMI of 37. On physical examination, skin-coloured subcutaneous nodules all over the upper limbs and on the back were found, as shown in the image below: 



Surgical removal of the painful nodules and anatomopathological examination was performed, which confirmed the proliferation of well-differentiated and uniform adipocytes sitting on a fibrovascular network. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dercum's disease

  • This patient is most likely suffering from Dercum's disease. Dercum's disease is also referred to as adiposis dolorosa.
  • It is a rare condition characterised by multiple painful lipomas.
  • These lipomas mainly occur on the trunk, upper arms & upper legs, as shown in the image below:

  • Mostly occur between 35-50 years and is more common in women.
  • The clinical features include severe pain.
  • The pain may be caused by lipomas pressing on nearby nerves or inflamed connective tissue.
  • Some patients also experience weight gain, depression, lethargy, and confusion.
  • The exact aetiology of Dercum's disease is unknown.
  • The diagnostic work-up includes detailed patient history and clinical examination to identify typical multiple lipomas.
  • The distribution of the lipomas helps distinguish Dercum's disease from other similar disorders. The histopathological examination of the excised tissue can confirm the diagnosis.
  • As far as the treatment is concerned, no specific treatment is available for Dercum's disease. The patient is managed by conservative measures such as the use of analgesics and injections of corticosteroids.
  • Surgical excision of the mass is indicated in case of severe refractory disease.

Option A: Weber Christian panniculitis

  • Weber Christian panniculitis refers to a group of diseases that involve deep fat. These disorders first appear on the skin as reddish, tender nodules.
  • Systemic symptoms such as fever and body aches are also seen.
  • Usually, both sides of the body are affected, and the thighs and lower legs are the most frequent areas. An oozing of yellowish drainage and scarring is also seen. However, these features are not mentioned in the clinical vignette so that we can rule out this option.

Option C: Liposarcoma

  • Liposarcoma is a type of cancer that occurs in fat cells in the body, most often in the limbs or abdomen muscles. However, this patient's clinical picture suggests Dercum's disease.

Option D: Erythema nodosum

  • Erythema nodosum is a type of skin inflammation located in a part of the fatty layer of the skin.
  • It manifests as reddish, painful, tender lumps most commonly located in the front of the legs below the knees. These features are not present in the vignette so that we can rule out this option.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency department with a history of loss of consciousness and slurred speech for the last 12 hours. The patient is a known smoker with a 20-pack-year history. The patient is normal and reports that he suddenly fell while walking in his house. He lost consciousness for 5 minutes, after which the patient developed slurred speech. On examination, the patient had unilateral hemiparesis, which later progressed to unilateral hemiplegia. Which of the following is the most common cause of neurological deterioration in the case mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Option B: Vasospasm

  • Clinical signs: Loss of consciousness, slurred speech, unilateral hemiparesis, and unilateral hemiplegia suggests a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). This is most probably because of vasospasm.
  • Types of CVA:
    • Ischemic CVA
    • Hemorrhagic CVA
  • Vasospasm
    • Narrowing of the arteries at the base of the brain following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) occurs regularly.
    • This vasospasm causes symptomatic ischemia and infarction in approximately 30% of patients and is the major cause of delayed morbidity or death. 

Option A: Rebleeding

  • Recurrent cerebrovascular accidents are common, but one must have a previous CVA or any other ischemic disease history.

Option C: Embolism

  • An embolus from another body part typically enters the bloodstream and travels to the brain to form an embolic stroke.
  • Cardiac illness or cardiac surgery are common causes of embolic strokes, which happen quickly and without prior signs and symptoms.

Option D: Hydrocephalus

  • Injuries or strokes can induce brain damage, which leads to hydrocephalus ex-vacuo. In these circumstances, the ventricles are larger than usual because the brain structures surrounding them shrink.
  • This disease is more of a "hydrocephalus look-alike" than a true hydrocephalus.

questions.text: Which structure is most likely responsible for the copious dark blood encountered during a bedside tracheostomy in a patient with head trauma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anterior jugular vein

  • This patient who underwent tracheostomy and bleeding during the procedure most likely sustained an injury or transection to the anterior jugular vein.
  • Tracheostomy is the most common surgical procedure for critically ill patients who require extended mechanical ventilation.
  • Indications for tracheostomy in critically ill patients:
    • Presence of pathological conditions, prediction of prolonged mechanical intubation, inability to protect the airways or both
    • High-risk airway and airway oedema after surgery and maxillofacial trauma
    • High-risk airway due to cervical immobilization for fracture fixation
    • Need for airway surgery due to inability to intubate the patient
  • The time of tracheostomy is controversial.
  • An early tracheostomy (48 hours) is preferred over a delayed tracheostomy (14-16 days). PDT is often used for elective tracheostomy in critically ill adult patients
  • Perioperative complications of percutaneous tracheotomy include:
    • Peristomal bleeding due to injury to the anterior jugular veins or thyroid isthmus.
    • Injury to the trachea or oesophagus, or both, by cutting the posterior wall of the trachea
    • Extra luminal placement, creating an incorrect tract during tracheal cannula placement
  • The anterior jugular vein is susceptible to injury during the tracheostomy procedure, as the anterior jugular vein can cross the midline overlying the proximal trachea. Midline cervical dissection without adequate visualization can injure the vein and require open surgical repair.

Option B: External jugular vein

  • The external jugular vein collects blood from the exterior cranium and parts of the face.
  • It begins at the parotid gland, extends downwards, and runs along the side of the neck.
  • This vein is covered by the platysma and pierces through the superficial layer of the fascia of the neck.
  • The external jugular vein ends in the venous angle or the internal jugular vein. However, this vein is not susceptible to injury during the tracheostomy.

Option C: Internal jugular vein

  • It is a paired vein that collects blood from the brain, face, and thyroid gland from the sigmoid and inferior petrosal sinus's confluence and exits the skull through the jugular foramen. Afterwards, it continues inside the carotid sheath with the carotid artery and the vagus nerve.
  • However, this vein is not susceptible to injury during the tracheostomy.

Option D: Middle thyroid vein

  • This vein is not susceptible to injury during the tracheostomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of throat pain and increasing difficulty swallowing food for the past 5 months. He has also had episodic left ear pain for the past 3 months. Further history reveals hypertension, chronic smoking, and alcohol. Family history is positive for laryngeal cancer. Examination shows left cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows a 3 cm ulcerating mass infiltrating the floor of the mouth. The senior physician recommends the commando operation. Which of the following statements best describes the commando operation?

choices.text: Abdominoperineal resection of the rectum for carcinoma
Resection of all level 1 to 4 neck lymph nodes
Excision of carcinoma of the jaw and lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Option D: Excision of carcinoma of the jaw and lymph nodes

Oral cavity cancer:

  • Oral cavity cancers refer to malignant tumours of the oral mucosa, tonsils, and salivary glands.
  • Predisposing factors include smoking, oral tobacco consumption, long-term alcohol use, and human papillomavirus infection. 
  • Oral cavity cancers are usually present in males aged 55–60 years, with clinical features like pain, dysphagia, or a nonhealing ulcer on the tonsils, tongue, or oral mucosa.
  • Clinically suspected cases are confirmed via histopathological examination of a biopsy specimen. Imaging and panendoscopy help determine the extent of the tumour and rule out spread.
  • Treatment depends upon the stage of the tumour and the extent of its spread and may include surgical resection (usually with neck dissection), radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
  • Commando’s operation: Total glossectomy + hemi-mandibulectomy + removal of floor of mouth + Radical lymph node dissection
  • Indicated when carcinoma is fixed to the mandible with infiltration of the floor of the mouth.
  • Total glossectomy: This is the removal of the entire tongue, including the base of the tongue.
  • Mandibulectomy is a surgical procedure wherein the mandible (jaw), a crucial bone in the face that contributes significantly to mastication or chewing, is removed or resected.
  • There are several kinds of mandibulectomy depending on the thickness and extent of resection required. Hemi-mandibulectomy is the type in which half of the mandible is removed.

Option A: Abdominoperineal resection of the rectum for carcinoma

  • The patient has cancer of the oral cavity infiltrating the floor of the mouth. Its treatment includes surgical resection of the tongue, mandible, floor of the mouth and the infiltrating lymph nodes.
  • Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is a type of surgery in which the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon are removed through small cuts in the belly. It is a surgical procedure done primarily to remove cancer from the rectum.

Option B: Disarticulation of the hip for gas gangrene of the leg

  • Hip disarticulation (HD) is a radical lower extremity amputation performed by carefully transecting all muscles and nerves surrounding the hip joint and separating the leg at the joint capsule.
  • It is considered a last resort to be used as a life-preserving measure under emergent circumstances due to high morbidity and mortality rates.
  • A hip disarticulation is a reasonable option for treating severe lower extremity infections.

Option C: Extended radical mastectomy

  • A mastectomy is a surgery to remove a breast. There are several types of mastectomy, including total, modified radical, and radical.
  • A radical mastectomy is the most extensive type. During the procedure, the surgeon removes the entire breast, the underarm (axillary) lymph nodes, and the chest wall muscles.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presented to the emergency department with sudden and continuous pain in his left testicle after an injury while playing sports. The pain was accompanied by radiating pain to the abdomen and left inguinal area, nausea, and vomiting for more than 12 hours. The patient had no prior history of this kind of pain. Upon examination, no testes were found in the left scrotum. What is the appropriate surgical procedure for this condition?

choices.text: Can be delayed 24 hours and limited to the affected side
Can be delayed but should include the asymptomatic side
Should be immediate and limited to the affected side
Should be immediate and include the asymptomatic side

questions.solution:
Option D: Should be immediate and include the asymptomatic side

  • This is the case of testicular torsion, as the patient presented after trauma with a painful scrotal and inguinal area associated with nausea and vomiting.
  • This occurs in neonates and adolescents male.
  • The blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the torsion of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia to the epididymis and the testis.
  • On diagnosis, a prompt surgical detorsion with testicular fixation should be performed to relieve acute testicular ischemia.
  • The contralateral side should be fixed, too, as that side can also be affected.

​​​​​​​Option A: Can be delayed 24 hours and limited to the affected side

  • It cannot be delayed as it can lead to ischemia of the testes.
  • The contralateral side should also be explored as that can also be prone to testicular torsion.

​​​​​​​Option B: Can be delayed but should include the asymptomatic side

  • Surgery cannot be delayed due to avascular necrosis.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option C: Should be immediate and limited to the affected side

  • The contralateral side should be explored as this anatomical defect can also occur on that side.

questions.text: You are the 2nd year PG in the surgery department assisting the chief surgeon in Exploratory laparotomy for a patient with severe abdominal trauma. The patient was successfully managed, and while closing the abdomen after a midline laparotomy, you were asked by your chief to suture the incision. What length of suture will you choose to close the incision?

choices.text: Twice the length of the incision
4 times the length of the incision
6 times the length of the incision
8 times the length of the incision

questions.solution:
Option B: 4 times the length of the incision

  • The length of the suture depends upon the type of incision.
  • For a laparotomy incision, the suture length should be 4 times the length of the incision.

Option A: Twice the length of the incision

  • For a skin suture, the length of the suture is twice the length of the wound

Option C: 6 times the length of the incision

  • This is usually done in the incision of abdominal surgeries other than laparotomy.

Option D: 8 times the length of the incision

  • This is not recommended for a laparotomy incision.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of end-stage renal disease from focal segmental glomerulosclerosis was managed solely with steroid therapy until he underwent a living-unrelated donor kidney transplant after a progressive deterioration in renal function. The most probable malignancy that can occur in this individual post-transplant is :
questions.solution:
COMPLICATIONS OF IMMUNOSUPPRESSION
INFECTION MALIGNANCY NON-IMMUNE SIDE EFFECTS
  • High risk of infection by virusesQ (CMV InfectionQ)during first 6 months
  • Recipient derived infectionsQare more common than donor derived infections
  • Bacterial infection- during first monthQ
  • Polyoma BK virus is associated with a progressive nephropathy and Ureteral obstruction
  • JC virus has been found to be associated with progressive multimodal leukoencephalopathy
  • Chemoprophylaxis is important in high risk patients
  • Pre-transplant vaccination against community acquired infection should be considered
  • MC malignancy in transplant recipient: Skin cancerQ (SCC)
  • Increased risk of PTLD & Kaposi sarcoma and other virally mediated tumours
  • Hypertension & chronic allograft nephropathy-Calcineurin inhibitorsQ
  • New onset diabetes - Tacrolimus or steroidsQ
  • Hyperlipidemia, anemia & accelerated cardiovascular diseaseQ
  • Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in transplant survivorsQ

questions.text: A 22-year-old otherwise healthy male presented to the ER following a single gunshot wound to the left groin. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. The ankle-brachial index confirmed an arterial injury (<0.9). On immediate exploration, a transected superficial left femoral artery was identified. Which of the following is the suture with maximum tensile strength and minimum tissue reaction that can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Polypropylene

  • Polypropylene(Non-absorbable) has maximum tensile strength and minimum tissue reaction.
  • Polypropylene suture:
    • Polypropylene suture is a monofilament (non-absorbable surgical suture). It comprises an isotactic crystalline stereoisomer of polypropylene, a synthetic linear polyolefin. It is pigmented in blue colour to enhance visibility.
    • Polypropylene sutures elicit maximum tensile strength and minimal tissue reaction that does not cause tissue rupture.
    • This suture is indicated for use in general soft tissue approximation and ligation, including use in cardiovascular, plastic, neurological surgeries, ophthalmic, micro procedures, and hernia repair. It is the preferred suture material for vascular anastomosis. It is neither absorbed nor subjected to weakening by tissue enzymes, non-adhering, and biologically inert. Thus, it is used for permanent fixtures.

Option A: Poliglecaprone

  • Poliglecaprone is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of polymers made from 100% homo polymer of polyglycolide and caprolactone.  
  • It has been found non-antigenic and non-pyrogenic and exhibits slight tissue reaction during absorption. It is available in Undyed and Violet colours.  
  • It is an ideal approximation suture for subcuticular closure. It retains 50%-60% of its tensile strength for 7 days, 20%-30% for 14 days, provides wound support for 21-28 days and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis, and completely gets absorbed within 90-120 days which is predictable.

Option C: Polyglactin

  • Polyglactin is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture. It is a co-polymer of 90% glycolide and 10% L-lactide.  
  • It retains tensile strength of about 70% till 14 days after implantation, it completely absorbs within 56-70 days by a simple hydrolytic mechanism, and its absorption is predictable.

Option D: Polydioxanone

  • Polydioxanone is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of polyester, poly (p-dioxanone).  
  • It is suitable for cases where extended wound support and strength are required.
  • It retains about 70% of the initial strength for 2 weeks, 50% for 4 weeks, and 25% for 6 weeks and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely gets absorbed within 180-210 days.
  • The absorption of this suture is reliable and predictable.

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room by her son due to a penetrating stab injury on the anterior neck. A kitchen knife was deeply stuck in the midline of the anterior neck, but there was no active bleeding. The patient was semiconscious; bradycardia and hypotension were noted. Which of the following is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Option D: Neurogenic shock 

  • Results from loss or suppression of sympathetic tone resulted in massive vasodilation in venous Vasculature leading to decreased Venous return and decreased cardiac output, which results in impaired tissue perfusion & cellular metabolism.
  • Clinical features
  • Paralysis below the level of the lesion; hypotension
  • Bradycardia due to loss of sympathetic tone → Arterial & venous vasodilation → Warm & dry skin
  • Hypothermia

Option A: Hypovolemic shock

  • Hypovolemic shock results in tachycardia to compensate for cardiac output.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Distributive

  • Distributive shock is also called septic shock.
  • In septic shock, there is a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance, which results in tachycardia and increased cardiac output to maintain peripheral perfusion.

Option C: Hypovolemic + septicemic shock

  • Hypovolemic & septicemia shock both results in tachycardia.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 24-year-old married woman has been trying to reduce her weight for the past 3 months. Her BMI is 31 kg/m2. However, she continues to eat high-fat and high-calorie foods regularly. Menarche occurred at age 14. Her first child was born at the age of 22. She has also been using oral contraceptives for the past 5 years. Which of the following factors is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Use of oral contraceptives

  • Risk factors for breast cancer
    • Risk factors that cannot be modified
      • Age
      • Female sex
      • Menstrual factors [Early age at menarche (<12 years ) and late age at menopause (>55years)]
      • Nulliparity
      • Family history of breast cancer [First-degree relatives(mothers, sisters, and daughters) of patients with breast cancer -have a two-fold to three-fold increased risk for the development of the disease]
      • Genetic predisposition (30% of all familial breast cancers)
      • Personal history of breast cancer
      • Race
      • Ethnicity
      • History of radiation exposure
    • Risk factors that can be modified
      • Reproductive factors [age at first live birth (fully term pregnancy after 30 years), parity, lack of breastfeeding]
      • Obesity (high-fat diet)
      • Alcohol consumption
      • Tobacco smoking
      • Use of hormone replacement therapy and Oral contraceptive pills (Oophorectomy before age 35 without estrogen replacement is a protective factor for breast cancer)
      • Decreased physical activity

Option A: Age

  • Increasing age is a risk factor for breast cancer. However, this risk increases after the age of 30.
  • This patient's age (24) is not a risk factor for breast cancer.

Option B: Age at menarche

  • Menstrual factors are very important in determining the risk of breast cancer in a woman's life span. If the age at menarche is <12 years, increased exposure to estrogen increases the risk for the development of breast cancer. 

Option D: Age at first live birth

  • When breast cells are made in adolescence, they are very immature and respond to the hormone estrogen.
  • A full-term pregnancy makes breast cells fully mature and grows more regularly.
  • This is how pregnancy helps protect against breast cancer.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old baby to the clinic after she noticed asymmetry of thigh folds. Upon asking about the complications during pregnancy, she states that except for the breech presentation of the baby, there was no other complication during the pregnancy. On the examination of the child, thigh folds are asymmetrical. Abduction of the thigh produces a clunk sound. Keeping in view the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the treatment of the choice for this baby?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is Developmental dysplasia of Hip

  • Pavlik harness is the treatment of choice in child less than 6 monthd

Treatment Plan of DDH :

A. Neonate and Young Child (1–6 month)—Closed reduction.

B. Pavlik harness is the treatment of choice

  • 6 to 18 months: Closed reduction, and spica casting.
  • 18 months to 3 years: Open reduction
  • 3 years or more : Various Osteotomies required to keep the head of femur into the acetabulum e.g. Salter's, Dega's,Pemberton's.

Minerva cast- cervical spine disease

Reiser’s cast- scoliosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old Lorry driver driving a long distance decides to take a nap, parks his vehicle on the side of the road, and sleeps under the lorry. Unfortunately, another lorry driver driving under the influence of alcohol loses control and hit this lorry on the backside. The patient is brought to the emergency 2 hours after the incident. Proximal limb amputation is planned for this patient. What is the normal permissible ischemia time?
questions.solution:
Option B: 6 hours

  • Irreversible necrotic changes begin in muscles after 6 hours of ischemia (warm ischemia time).
  • It is preferable to begin the replantation of parts with good muscular bulk (viz., parts proximal to palms and foot) within this time.
  • Cooling (to 4°C) may extend this time to 12 hours (cold ischemia time).

A sequence of re-implantation:

The sequence of reimplantation (Mnemonic: BE FAN VS)

  • B- Bone (first to be implanted)
  • E-Extensor tendon
  • F-Flexor tendon
  • A-Arteries
  • Nerves
  • V-Veins
  • S- Skin (preserved first and implanted last)

Option A: 4 hours

  • The permissible ischemic time for the heart and lungs is 4 hours.

Option C: 24 hours

  • The permissible ischemic time for the kidney is < 24 hours

Option D: 12 hours

  • Less than Twelve hours is the permissible ischemic time for the pancreas.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a road traffic accident two hours ago. He is not able to put weight on his left lower leg. His blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, his pulse is 105/min, and his respiratory rate is 18/min. On physical examination, abrasions are seen on the chest and lower extremities. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. The pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. An x-ray of the lower limbs is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture of the shaft of the femur
Fracture of the neck of the femur with injury to femoral vessels

questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior dislocation of the hip

  • The posterior dislocation is the most common type of dislocation of the hip.
  • The shortening and attitude of the limb in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation are characteristic of posterior dislocation of the hip.
  • X-ray shows the characteristic finding of posterior dislocation of the hip in which the femoral head is displaced posteriorly, superiorly, and laterally to the acetabulum.
  • The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur.
  • Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the vessels fall backwards, and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.
  • It is treated with closed reduction.
  • Complications include avascular necrosis of the femoral head, chondrolysis, and post-traumatic arthritis.
  • Dashboard injury can lead to:
    • Posterior hip dislocation
    • Acetabular fracture
    • Patellar fracture
    • Fracture of neck of femur
    • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

Option B: Anterior dislocation of the hip

  • It is seen in high-energy impacts, i.e., trauma.
  • The hip is forced into abduction with external rotation of the thigh.
  • Anterior dislocation of the hip leads to the lengthening of the limb.
  • The x-ray will show anterior dislocation. The femoral head will be present in front of the acetabulum.

Option C: Fracture of the shaft of the femur

  • High energy injuries, such as dashboard injuries, lead to fractures of the shaft of the femur.
  • Most commonly seen in younger individuals.
  • The patient presents with extreme thigh pain.
  • It can be associated with femoral neck fractures.
  • The AP and lateral x-rays of the femur will show the fracture line with or without dislocation.

Option D: Fracture of the neck of the femur with injury to femoral vessels

  • Dashboard injury can lead to femoral neck fracture.
  • Patients may be asymptomatic in the early part of the disease process.
  • Hip pain that may radiate to the groin and thigh.
  • The pain is typically aggravated by walking and climbing stairs and alleviated by rest.
  • Less external rotation (<45 degrees) is seen. It is associated with avascular necrosis.
  • The AP view of the x-ray will show the fracture line with or without displacement.

questions.text: A 15-year-old school-going boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of right knee pain for the past few days. He denies any trauma. On examination, right knee swelling is noted. An x-ray of the lower limb is ordered. X-ray shows the following findings as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Chondroblastoma

  • 8-16 years of age group.
  • The most common site of chondroblastoma is epiphysis of the distal femur.
  • X-ray – Expansile mass in the epiphyseal area.
  • Mimics synovitis
  • Clinical features: pain and swelling.
  • Biopsy:- Chicken wire calcification
  • Treatment is curettage with bone grafting or bone curettage.

Option A: Enchondroma

  • Most common tumor of bones of hands and feet
  • Shows calcification
  • On biopsy, Hyaline cartilage can be seen
  • Treatment is extended curettage
  • 5% of cases are premalignant

Option B: Osteochondroma

  • Occurs before skeletal maturity
  • Diaphysis achalasia (development malformation)
  • Usually grows away from the joint
  • Very commonly seen around the knee and the shoulder

Option C: Osteoclastoma

  • Also known as giant cell tumor
  • Tumor site: lower-end femur
  • Parts affected: Epiphysis
  • Only tumors that can involve the joints
  • Only tumors that can involve the cartilage
  • Treatment: In giant cell tumors, extended curettage is done
  • 2 types: Giant cell and Mononuclear cell

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a head injury from a road traffic accident. He is semiconscious with a GCS of 7/15. The patient has multiple lacerations on his head. The patient's CT brain was done, revealing a convex-shaped hyperdense lesion that doesn’t cross the suture line. The patient is planned for endotracheal intubation. The anesthesiology resident used his right hand on the neck to view the glottis properly while performing endotracheal intubation. The manoeuvre used in this case is:
questions.solution:
Option D: Backward – upward – rightward pressure

  • This is a case of extradural hematoma in which the patient is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a head injury from a road traffic accident. He is semiconscious with a GCS of 7/15.
  • The patient has multiple lacerations on his head. The patient's CT brain was done, revealing a convex-shaped hyperdense lesion that doesn't cross the suture line.
  • The doctor used a backwards-outward-rightward pressure manoeuvre in this case.
  • The use of external laryngeal manipulation can improve the laryngeal view.
  • Backwards upward rightward pressure (BURP manoeuvre) on the thyroid cartilage is most commonly used.
  • The BURP manoeuvre has been shown to improve laryngeal view decreasing the rate of difficult intubation from 4.7% to 1.8%.

Option A: Optimal external laryngeal manipulation

  • Optimal external laryngeal manipulation (OELM)is achieved when the laryngoscopist uses his or her right hand to guide the position and pressure is exerted by an assistant's hand on the larynx.

Option B: Chin lift

  • In this manoeuvre, the head of the patient is tilted posteriorly to 15 to 30 degrees of atlantooccipital extension.
  • The chin is lifted with fingers to anteriorly pull the tongue and oropharyngeal soft tissue.

Option C: Jaw thrust

  • In this method, the fingers are placed behind the angles of the lower jaw when the patient is in the supine position.
  • The jaw is moved anteriorly to pull the base of the tongue and soft tissue away from the airway.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is being posted for a right-modified radical mastectomy under general anaesthesia. Induction of anaesthesia is done with Inj. Propofol and endotracheal intubation is facilitated with Inj. Atracurium. While doing mask ventilation after administering muscle relaxant, the monitor showed a blood pressure reading of 75/40 mmHg, a pulse rate to be 130/minute, and flushing of the face, which was treated with intravenous fluid bolus and Inj. Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV. Which of the following is the underlying mechanism of these observed findings?

choices.text: Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors
Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol

questions.solution:
Option A: Histamine release

  • Histamine release by benzylisoquinolinium compounds such as mivacurium, atracurium and tubocurarine can cause skin flushing, decreases in blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance and tachycardia.
  • Histamine has positive ionotropic and chronotropic effects on the myocardial H2 receptors. The clinical effects of histamine are seen when the drug administration is rapid.
  • Cisatracurium, vecuronium or rocuronium may be appropriate for patients with hemodynamic instability due to less or no histamine release.
  • Slow administration of benzylisoquinolinium compounds over 60 seconds and prophylaxis with combined H1 and H2 blockers maintain cardiovascular stability.

​​​​​​​Option B: Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors

  • Neuromuscular blocking agents interact with nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors within the autonomic nervous system and at the nicotinic receptors of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Tubocurarine causes marked ganglionic blockade resulting in hypotension due to peripheral venous and arteriolar dilatation via stimulation of the vascular H1 and H2 receptors.
  • Pancuronium produced a profound vagolytic response by blocking the sympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals. It is characterised by tachycardia, reduction in heart rate variability and baroreflex sensitivity. It may also stimulate the catecholamine release from adrenergic nerve terminals.

Option C: Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol

  • It may result in hypotension, but the observed findings of flushing do not particularly occur secondary to propofol administration.

Option D: Preoperative use of antihypertensives

  • Antihypertensives are used preoperatively in some patients with elevated blood pressure readings to keep their blood pressure within a suitable range for the induction of anaesthesia.
  • Flushing is particularly not expected secondary to this intervention.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and pancreatic carcinoma with liver secondaries on palliative treatment. He is attending the pain clinic regularly and getting tablets of morphine for cancer pain. He was not able to come and get treatment for the past 3 days. Which of the following symptom will the patient suffer for using the drug involved in this case for 3 days?
questions.solution:
Option B: Abdominal cramps, vomiting, insomnia

  • The physical dependence on morphine usually requires about 25 days to develop but may occur sooner in emotionally unstable persons.
  • Abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting & diarrhoea, reach their peak in 72 hours & then decline over the next 7 to 10 days.
  • The following are some of the most common side effects of morphine use: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and constipation are examples of gastrointestinal side effects.
  • Morphine opioid receptors are present in the gastrointestinal tract, and their activation may cause a slowing of gut movement, resulting in constipation.

Option A: Constipation, bradycardia, coma

  • Atropine is a prescription medication used to treat symptoms of low heart rate (bradycardia), to reduce salivation and bronchial secretions prior to surgery, and as an antidote for cholinergic drug overdose or mushroom poisoning.
  • Constipation, bradycardia, and coma are the side effects.

Option C: Hyperthermia, vomiting, restlessness

  • Several drugs or drug classes, including amphetamines, diuretics, cocaine, antipsychotics, metoclopramide, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), and alcohol, can cause or contribute to hyperthermia disorders.
  • Calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells has been shown to increase with antipsychotic use, potentially leading to increased muscle contractility and rigidity, muscle breakdown, and hyperthermia, along with vomiting and restlessness.

Option D: Hypothermia, nausea, constipation

  • Hypothermia is a rare but potentially fatal side effect of antipsychotic medication (APD). Despite extensive research into the opposite condition, hyperthermia, in the context of the malignant antipsychotic syndrome, little is known about hypothermia caused by APDs.
  • Drugs can cause hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis dysregulation, resulting in an increase in core temperature.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department complaining of pain in the right inguinal region. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 110/minute. Physical examination revealed a mass consistent with an inguinal hernia. He was scheduled to be operated on while under general anaesthesia. The anaesthesiologist decided to use succinylcholine for intubation and anaesthesia induction. Which of the following side effects is anticipated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sinus bradycardia 

  • Sinus bradycardia is a common side effect seen in patients who have had repeated succinylcholine exposure. 
  • In these patients, atropine is effective in preventing bradycardia. 
  • Bradycardia occurs when succinylcholine acts on the muscarinic cholinergic receptor in the cardiac muscle. Other effects are 
    • Junctional rhythm
    • Sinus arrest
    • Ventricular dysrhythmia 
  • Autonomic stimulation during intubation or laryngoscopy causes ventricular dysrhythmia. 

Option A: Ventricular tachycardia

  • Ventricular tachycardia can occur when succinylcholine acts on muscarinic receptors in the autonomic ganglion.  
  • It is not a common succinylcholine side effect. 

Option C: Torsades de pointes

  • Torsades de pointes can occur for various reasons, some of which are listed below.  
    • Ventricular fibrillation 
    • Electrolyte imbalance (Hyponatremia, Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia)
  • It is not a succinylcholine side effect. 

Option D: Paroxysmal atrial tachycardia

  • The development of a short circuit in the atrium causes paroxysmal atrial tachycardia. 
  • Succinylcholine does not cause paroxysmal atrial tachycardia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with his wife and presents with acute onset of severe pain in his right great toe. He has long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension. On physical examination, inflammation and erythema of the affected joint are visible. On x-ray, rat bite erosions with overhanging edges are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Gouty arthritis

  • Patient with arthritis due to gout often presents with swollen, red, and painful asymmetric joints.
  • Risk factors of gout include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, obesity, chronic alcohol use, and dyslipidemia.
  • A painful metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the classical manifestation of gouty arthritis.
  • Tophus formation often occurs on the olecranon bursa, Achilles tendon, and external ear.
  • Radiographically, the typical finding of gout is a punched-out lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin and overhanging edge, defined as the "Martel sign" or "rat-bite" erosion.

 

Figure: Gouty arthritis

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • The radiographic hallmarks of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are soft tissue swelling, osteoporosis, joint space narrowing and marginal erosions.
  • arthritis (musculoskeletal manifestations) | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/32161/dd9f125ed61b0524efc35c13421116_gallery.jpg" style="width: 270px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

 

Option C: Osteoarthritis

  • The radiographic findings of primary osteoarthritis are-
    • Nonuniform loss of joint spaces
    • Osteophyte formation
    • Cyst formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis.
  • The radiographs of an initial stage of osteoarthritis may not show all of the findings

 

Option D: Ankylosing Spondylitis

  • Radiographic findings of ankylosing spondylitis are bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis (earliest feature), bamboo-spine (knobby spine, poker back or universal syndesmophytes), syndesmophytes, and enthesitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents at the outpatient clinic with right upper quadrant pain and abdominal distention for the past 3 days. A year before, she was diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma, stage IA, and underwent abdominal hysterectomy and removal of both ovaries. She had not received oral contraceptives in the past. On CECT, a  peripheral nodular Enhancement pattern is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Hemangioma

  • Hemangiomas have initial peripheral nodular puddling of contrast with a delayed homogenous central enhancement pattern.
  • A liver hemangioma is a noncancerous (benign) mass in the liver made up of a tangle of blood vessels. Also known as hepatic hemangiomas or cavernous hemangiomas, these liver masses are common in the population
    hemangioma | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/30765/39e1da22507788a97080f5340d7b80_gallery.jpg" style="width: 240.068px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

Table showing enhancement pattern of different liver lesions:

Option B: Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • HCC has an early arterial enhancement and Rapid Washout pattern (HCC is supplied mainly by the hepatic artery).
    hepatocellular carcinoma - ScienceDirect" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0016508504016063-gr1.jpg" style="width: 338.4px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

Option C: Metastasis

  • Liver metastases are typically hypoattenuating on unenhanced CT, enhancing less than the surrounding liver following contrast. They have a typical washout which distinguishes them from the hemangioma

Option D: Hepatic Cysts

  • The hepatic cysts do not enhance even if contrast is used, and it shows as a significant hypodense lesion in the liver

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a known case of diabetes mellitus type-2, presents to the emergency department with complaints of mild abdominal pain over the left side of the abdomen for the last 2 days. He has had a history of bloody diarrhoea for the last 5 days. On examination, abdominal tenderness is present. A plain X-ray abdomen is advised; this shows a thumbprint sign. Based on the above-given findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ischemic colitis

  • Ischemic colitis is the most likely diagnosis here.
  • Ischemic colitis is where the blood flow to the colon is temporarily reduced.
  • It may be caused due to constriction of the blood vessels supplying the colon.
  • Thumb printing: Indentation in contrast or air-filled bowel lumen caused by submucosal infiltration resembling a thumb printing, e.g., Ischemia.
  • Thumb printing is a Radiographic sign of large bowel wall thickening, usually caused by oedema, related to an infective or inflammatory process ('colitis').
  • The normal haustra thicken at regular intervals appearing like 'thumbprints' projecting into the aerated lumen.

Option A: Ulcerative colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease causing inflammation and ulcers in the digestive tract. It has a lead pipe appearance in the barium study.

Option B: Meconium ileus

  • Meconium ileus is a small intestine blockage in infants due to increased thickness of intestinal contents (meconium). It is most commonly associated with cystic fibrosis.

 Option C: Crohn's disease

  • Crohn's disease causes inflammation of the tissues in the digestive tract, mainly involving the terminal ileum and parts of the colon. A fat halo sign is seen on the CT scan.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female was brought to the neurology ward by her mother with complaints of one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure 2 hours ago. The patient has no history of nausea, vomiting or weakness of any limb. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The CT brain of the patient is done, and the image is given below. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Neurocysticercosis

  • This is a case of neurocysticercosis in which the patient presents with complaints of an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

  • In this case, the initial investigation is a non-contrast CT scan of the brain.

  • The CT brain shows multiple calcified nodules, also known as a starry sky appearance.

  • Neurocysticercosis is a severe parasitic infection caused by the larval cyst of the pork tapeworm (Taenia solium).

  • The larval cysts are the enclosed sacs containing the immature stage of a parasite.

  • Starry sky appearance:

    • On non-contrast CT brain- Calcific nodular stage of NCC (neurocysticercosis).

    • On histopathology, “Burkitt's lymphoma”.

    • On immune fluorescence, “Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

    • On USG liver, " Acute hepatitis

Option A: Tuberculoma

  • Tuberculomas are rare and a serious form of tuberculosis that is caused due to the hematogenous spread of mycobacterium tuberculosis.

  • There may be evidence of tuberculosis elsewhere. The CSF may show features consistent with tuberculous meningitis.

  • Response to antituberculosis therapy is slow and paradoxical expansion of lesions despite therapy is not uncommon.

  • Ring-enhancing lesions around the brain stem.

  • T2 hypointense and lipid lactate peak on MRS.

Option B: Hydatid cyst

  • Hydatid cysts are formed due to parasitic infection.

  • Caused by Echinococcus granulosus (EG), a dog tapeworm, a parasite.

Option C: Toxoplasmosis

  • Toxoplasmosis is a disease caused by infection from the toxoplasma gondii parasite.

  • Mostly affect immunocompetent individuals, including children and pregnant women, and the infection goes unnoticed. In approximately 10% of patients, it causes a self-limiting illness, most common in

  • adults aged 25–35 years.

  • The Sabin–Feldman dye test (indirect flfluorescent antibody test), which detects IgG antibody is most commonly used.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with severe refractory dysmenorrhea; she says she has been getting painkiller injections for the past 8 months for this condition. The doctor advises her diagnostic laparoscopy that reveals black-brown powder burn-like lesions on peritoneal surfaces and also covering bilateral tubes, which is sent for biopsy. The report says there is a presence of haemorrhage and the endometrial glands. Which of the following is the LEAST likely mechanism for her dysmenorrhea?

choices.text: Collection of shed menstrual blood in implants

questions.solution:
Option D : SEPTIC SEEDING OF IMPLANTS:

History of dysmenorrhea, powder burn like lesions and biopsy with endometrial glands are all suggestive of a diagnosis of endometriosis. Endometriotic implants are aseptic in nature that cause deep peritoneal inflammation, which on healing causes adhesions and fibrosis. Possible mechanisms causing pain in patients with endometriosis include:-

  • Local peritoneal inflammation,
  • Deep infiltration with tissue damage,
  • Adhesion formation,
  • Fibrotic thickening,
  • Collection of shed menstrual blood in endometriotic implants, resulting in painful traction with the physiologic movement of tissues.

Option A : LOCAL PERITONEAL INFLAMMATION:

  • There is local peritoneal inflammation at the site of implants

Option B : DEEP INFILTRATION WITH TISSUE DAMAGE:

  • These implants infiltrate the tissues deeply which along with inflammation, is responsible for pain.

Option C :COLLECTION OF SHED MENSTRUAL BLOOD IN IMPLANTS:

  • These implants containing endometriotic glands and stroma and are therefore associated with collection of blood at each menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complained of excessive hair growth on her face, upper arms, and back for the past year. She mentions that her hair growth has rapidly increased over the past few months, and she also complains of hoarseness in her voice. Her abdominal ultrasound reveals an ovarian tumor. Which type of tumor is the most likely?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor

  • This patient is showing signs of virilization of rapid progression; such changes are seen with masculinizing ovarian tumors such as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors or Arrhenoblastomas.
  • Ovarian tumors which produce male sex hormones are called virilizing tumors.
  • These tumors occur commonly in the third and fourth decades of life. They are rare tumors. They secrete androgens and cause defeminization followed by masculinization.
  • Virilization: Permanent changes
    • Hoarseness
    • Breast atrophy
    • Clitoromegaly
    • Oligomenorrhea to amenorrhea
    • Benign
    • Rapid onset hirsutism
  • Conservative surgery is the appropriate treatment for young females with Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors. The patient might need adjuvant chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin with poor prognostic factors.

Option A: Granulosa cell tumors

  • These functional ovarian tumors produce estrogen and are associated with precocious puberty, menorrhagia, endometrial hyperplasia, and cancer. So, it is not a true statement.

Option C: Immature teratoma

  • Immature teratoma or benign cystic teratoma is 90% of all teratomas. These are usually present as pelvic masses in women in their second or third decade of life and may also, at times, present with torsion. There are no virilization changes associated with teratoma.

Option D: Polycystic ovarian disease

  • A woman with PCOD may present with similar complaints of excessive hair growth. However, such rapid onset and progression changes must always warrant evaluation for a masculinizing ovarian tumor. Since there is also an ovarian tumor in radiology, a Sertoli cell tumor is most likely. Hence, it is a false option.

questions.text: Which of the following long-term health effects is NOT associated with PCOS?
questions.solution:
Option D: Postdated pregnancy

  • The woman has delayed cycles (oligo-ovulation) and polycystic ovarian morphology on USG. These are suggestive of PCOD.
  • OCPs are used for the management of PCOD for the regularization of cycles.
  • Pregnancy complications of PCOS include preterm birth and not postdates.
  • Health risks associated with Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):

 

  • Type II Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Lipidemias
  • Premature Ovarian failure
  • Breast Cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Pregnancy risks associated with Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Gestational diabetes (diabetes that occurs during pregnancy)
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Preterm birth
  • Babies from PCOS mothers have a higher rate of admission to the neonatal intensive care unit & perinatal death.

Option A: Type II Diabetes

  • PCOS is related to abnormal glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, and raised serum insulin levels and later may be complicated as type II diabetes.

Option B: Infertility

  • PCOD causes anovulatory infertility.

Option C: Abnormal glucose tolerance test

  • PCOS is related to abnormal glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, and raised serum insulin levels and later may be complicated as type II diabetes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman underwent a hysterectomy for a huge fibroid. She presents after 10 days with acute pain and urinary retention to the emergency. She is subsequently catheterized, and the pain is relieved. She states that this is her second such episode after surgery. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Injury to the bladder and neck

questions.solution:
The most probable cause of acute pain and urinary retention in a 55-year-old woman, 10 days after a hysterectomy, considering her previous experience with a similar episode, is:

        3. Injury to the bladder and neck.

Explanation of each option:

  1. Atrophic and stenotic urethra: This condition involves thinning and narrowing of the urethra, typically seen in postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. While it can cause urinary symptoms, such as difficulty urinating or urinary tract infections, it is less likely to cause acute pain and sudden urinary retention shortly after a hysterectomy.

  2. Lumbar disc prolapse: Lumbar disc prolapse can cause lower back pain and, in severe cases, may result in nerve compression leading to pain, weakness, or sensory changes in the lower limbs. However, it is not directly related to urinary retention unless there is significant nerve compression affecting the nerves responsible for bladder control.

  3. Injury to the bladder and neck: During a hysterectomy, the bladder is in close proximity to the surgical site, and there is a risk of injury during the procedure. Bladder injury can result in symptoms like acute pain and urinary retention. If the bladder neck (the opening of the bladder into the urethra) is affected, it can further contribute to difficulty in urination.

  4. Injury to the hypogastric plexus: The hypogastric plexus is a network of nerves located in the pelvis that is responsible for various autonomic functions, including bladder and bowel control. Injury to this plexus during a hysterectomy could potentially lead to urinary retention, but it is less likely to cause acute pain as the primary symptom.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to the gynaecologist with complaints of being unable to conceive for 2 years. She cannot conceive even after having intercourse with her husband twice weekly. She is diagnosed as having infertility secondary to anovulation. The doctor started a drug that causes hypothalamic stimulation by inhibiting estrogen-mediated negative feedback. Based on this mechanism, the drug involved in this case can also be used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oligospermia

  • This is a case of infertility secondary to anovulation.
  • The drug involved in this case is clomiphene citrate.
  • Clomiphene citrate can also be used in the treatment of oligospermia.
  • Clomiphene citrate is thought to have effects on the hypothalamic axis (inhibit estrogen-mediated negative feedback on the hypothalamus) which promotes gonadotropin release.
  • Gonadotropin stimulates pituitary LH & FSH secretion, which helps in testosterone production and spermatogenesis.
  • The drug is started at a dose of 25mg daily dose to increase the FSH. Usually given for 3 months, the spermatogenesis cycle length.
  • This regime is an 'Off- label" used in practice since it's not yet universally accepted.
  • However, it's a frequent therapy before going in for more elaborate and expensive treatment by IVF.

Option B: Erectile dysfunction

  • Sildenafil is the drug of choice for erectile dysfunction.

Option C: Asherman’s syndrome

  • Asherman’s syndrome is not treated by clomiphene citrate. In this syndrome, scar tissues and adhesions are removed via hysteroscopy.

Option D: Carcinoma of the endometrium

  • Treatment of carcinoma of the endometrium is surgical staging followed be radiation or chemotherapy

questions.text: 34-year-old female with urinary incontinence, dribbling occurs constantly, and passes only minimal urine. Multiparous P4+1, last childbirth 6 months ago. What is the most important history to elicit?
questions.solution:
Option A: History of difficult childbirth/ trauma

  • History suggests a genitourinary fistula (continuous involuntary leak with abnormal voiding).
  • A vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal opening between the bladder and the wall of the vagina, resulting in urine leakage out of the vagina.
  • Vesicovaginal fistula is shown below:

 

 

  • Causes of Vesico-vaginal fistula:
    • Gynaecological Surgery: Most common cause in developed countries.
    • Obstetric injury/ Obstructed labour (leading to tissue necrosis) : It is the most common cause in developing countries.
    • Radiation.
    • Malignancy.
    • Foreign bodies: forgotten pessaries.
    • Direct trauma.
    • Infective: TB, schistosomiasis, syphilis, LGV
    • Endometriosis, perforating bladder calculi.
  • A methylene blue swab test can diagnose it. : 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder through the catheter and swabs are placed in the vagina. The methylene blue dye stains the uppermost swab if a vesicovaginal fistula is present.
  • The only treatment of vesicovaginal fistula is surgical.

Option B: History of pelvic irradiation

  • Pelvic irradiation is a cause of fistula however it is a rare cause

Option C: Genital malignancy/ undiagnosed vaginal bleeding

  • A genital malignancy may cause VVF secondary to tissue invasion, however it is not a very common cause and that too in this patient of 34 years age where malignancy is unlikely.

Option D: History of surgery for haemorrhoids

  • Haemorrhoids are swellings that contain enlarged blood vessels. These are found inside or around the rectum and anus and have no association with the vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at a gynecology clinic seeks contraception advice. She's been married for 5 years, has 2 kids, and wants a one-time long-acting contraceptive. She may want another child later. Which contraception is not recommended for her?
questions.solution:
Option B: Laparoscopic tubal sterilization

  • Laparoscopic tubal sterilization is a specific surgery to block the fallopian tubes and prevent pregnancy. Tubal sterilization is considered permanent birth control. This patient wants a long-acting reversible contraceptive.
  • Laparoscopic or open sterilization procedures are irreversible, permanent methods of contraception. This is advised only when the couple is sure of having achieved their desired family size.

  • The above picture sterilization procedure is shown in which the fallopian tube is clipped laparoscopically.

Option A: Cu T

  • Copper T (Cu T) tubes are used for temporary methods of contraception and are long acting.
  • Copper devices can act from 3 years to up to 10 years.

Option C: Implanon

  • It is also used for temporary purposes. It is a reversible method.
  • A single-rod implant with 68 mg of etonogestrel covered by an ethylene vinyl acetate copolymer cover.
  • Placed subdermally on the medial surface of the upper arm 8 to 10 cm from the elbow in the biceps groove and is aligned with the long axis of the arm. Used for 3 years. Not radiopaque and identified with sonography.
  • Nexplanon is similarly shaped and pharmacologically identical to Implanon but is radiopaque.

Option D: LNG IUD

  • Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine systems—Mirena (5 years) and Skyla (3 years).
  • Each releases the progestin into the uterus at a relatively constant rate, which reduces systemic effects.
  • It is also a form of long acting reversible contraception.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, there is mucopurulent discharge extruding from the cervix. The discharge, when examined under the microscope, shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Option A: Neisseria Gonorrhoea

  • The patient, in this case, has Cervicitis.
  • Chlamydia Trachomatis and Neisseria Gonorrhoeae are two significant causal organisms.
  • Clinical manifestation
  • Discharge: In some instances, mucopurulent yellowish discharge can be visualised oozing from the endocervix.
  • Cervical hypertrophy and oedema
