  • Cervical ectopy
  • Friable cervix: easily bleeds when touched
  • Urethritis, bartholinitis, and proctitis symptoms may be present.
  • Cervicitis investigations
  • Gram staining on cervical swabs: gonococcal Cervicitis reveals gram-negative diplococci, but chlamydia cervicitis exhibits the absence of gram-negative diplococci with more than 30 poly-morphonuclear neutrophils per field. This test is neither sensitive nor specific.
  • In enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA), detection of antigens is 60%-80% and 80%-85% specific, respectively.
  • Nucleic Acid Amplification Technique (NAAT) is the most sensitive and specific (99%)
  • Complications
  • Ascending infections: pelvic inflammatory disease, endometritis, salpingitis
  • Septicemia: fever, meningitis, endocarditis, tenosynovitis, polyarthralgia
  • Perihepatitis: adhesions with an anterior abdominal wall called Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.
  • Long-term complications: infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain.
  • Treatment: It involves treatment of both partners

For Nesseria

  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • Cefixime 400 mg single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • A single dose of ceftriaxone (250mg IM) and azithromycin 1 gm (single dose) for both partners treat Neisseria and Chlamydia.

Option B: Chlamydia Trachomatis

  • Chlamydia Trochamatis is also a leading cause of Cervicitis
  • However, the discharge in chlamydia cervicitis is yellowish with a strong odour.
  • Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms.
  • Chlamydia cervicitis exhibits the absence of gram-negative diplococci with more than 30 poly-morphonuclear neutrophils per field.
  • They have 2 forms:
  • Elementary body: It is small and dense. It is infectious and enters the cell via endocytosis. It transforms into the reticulate body.
  • Reticulate body: It replicates in the cell by fission and reorganises into elementary bodies.
  • A single dose of ceftriaxone (250mg IM) and azithromycin 1 gm (single dose) for both partners treat both Neisseria and Chlamydia.
  • Treatment:
  • Azithromycin 1 gm single dose
  • Doxycycline : 100 mg BD x 7 days
  • Erythromycin: 500 mg BD x 7 days
  • Ofloxacin : 200 mg BD x 7 days

Option C: Candida Albicans

  • Candida Albicans caused Candida Vulvovaginitis
  • There is inflammation.
  • There is thick, white “cottage cheese” discharge also present.
  • Pseudohyphae may be visualised on microscopy.
  • The pH is usually normal (acidic), i.e. 4.0–4.5.

Option D: Trichomonas Vaginalis

  • Trichomonas Vaginalis causes Trichomonas Vaginitis.
  • There is inflammation of the vagina.
  • A strawberry cervix may also be present.
  • There is a frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge.
  • There are motile pear-shaped trichomonads on microscopy.
  • The pH is usually greater than 4.5

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who had two normal pregnancies 13 and 20 years ago presents with the complaint of amenorrhea for 9 months. She expresses the desire to become pregnant again. After exclusion of pregnancy, which of the following is the next best test indicated in the evaluation of this patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
LH and FSH levels

  • Patient has secondary amenorrhea, which rules out abnormalities associated with primary amenorrhea such as congenital Mullerian abnormalities and chromosomal abnormalities.
  • The most common cause for secondary amenorrhea in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy, which should be evaluated first.
  • Other possibilities include chronic endometritis or scarring of the endometrium (Asherman syndrome), hypothyroidism, and ovarian failure.
  • The latter is the most likely diagnosis in a woman at this age.
  • Persistently elevated gonadotropin levels (especially when accompanied by low serum estradiol levels) are diagnostic of ovarian failure.
  • Thus the most relevant test here would be LH and FSH which are expected to be raised at this age suggesting ovarian failure or menopause

An endometrial biopsy would show proliferative changes as cycles are mostly anovulatory in perimenopausal age group but this would suggest anovulation but not the exact cause of anovulation, which is expected to be ovarian failure in this case.

Karyotyping is warranted in cases of primary amenorrhea to rule out chromosomal causes

HSG for amenorrhea can identify an obstructive pathology such as Ashermans syndrome which is not likely here

questions.text: A primigravida presents to her antenatal clinic at 24 weeks. As a routine, she gets tested for urine albumin and glucose with a dipstick and tests positive for glucose. Her oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) was normal, and she has no past or family history of diabetes. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A: No further intervention is needed

  • Glucosuria during pregnancy is not necessarily abnormal.
  • The appreciable increase in glomerular filtration, together with the impaired tubular reabsorptive capacity for filtered glucose, accounts in most cases for glucosuria.
  • Though glucosuria is common during pregnancy, the possibility of diabetes mellitus should not be ignored when it is identified.
  • However, in this case, OGTT is already normal; thus, the patient is not diabetic or gestational diabetic, which is a normal finding.

Option B: Start a diabetic diet

  • A diabetic diet should be started in patients with preconceptional and gestational diabetes Mellitus.
  • This patient has normal OGTT; therefore, a diabetic diet is not required.

Option C: Test for HbA1c

  • HbA1c is the test performed in patients with preconceptional diabetes.
  • This patient is not diabetic, and her OGTT is also normal; therefore, HbA1c is not required.

Option D: Renal profile

  • The patient's glucosuria is a normal finding due to increased glomerular filtration and impaired tubular reabsorptive capacity for filtered glucose.
  • To rule out the suspicion of gestational diabetes, OGTT is the best next step.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 17 weeks of gestational age, presents to the clinic for her antenatal evaluation. She is concerned if her current pregnancy has any complications as she has a history of delivering a baby with Down syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option B: Amniocentesis

  • Amniocentesis and karyotyping is the best choice. Because there is a past history of Down syndrome, a confirmatory test should be done.
  • It is generally done around 16–18 weeks and gives confirmatory results but can be performed at any point later in gestation
  • It is the most performed fetal diagnostic procedure.
  • Sample of amniotic fluid is taken using an ultrasound-guided transabdominal needle.
  • Indications of amniocentesis include fetal genetic disorders, congenital infections, allo immunisation and assessment of fetal lung maturity.

Option A: Triple screen test

  • The triple marker is only a screening test, not a confirmatory one.

Option C: Chorionic villous sampling

  • It is usually performed between 11–12 weeks.
  • A sample of the placenta is obtained by ultrasound-guided transabdominal needle, or it can be done by ultrasound-guided transcervical cannula aspiration.
  • If the patient presents at an early gestational age, this would be the most appropriate investigation along with karyotyping.

Option D: Ultrasonography

  • Ultrasound can only pick soft tissue markers of Down syndrome, but it is not confirmatory.
  • Ultrasound scans can be normal in a fetus with Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation is admitted at labor for delivery. She delivers vaginally a healthy-term baby. The baby cries immediately after delivery and is handed over to the pediatrician. Which of these changes in circulation are expected to happen at this stage in the newborn?
questions.solution:
Option C: Functional closure of ductus arteriosus

No anatomical closure or obliteration of either ductus venosus, umbilical vein or foramen ovale occurs immediately at birth. Only functional closure of these results from the expansion of lungs at birth and lowering of the resistance of pulmonary vasculature that results in a change of blood flow pattern through the heart from parallel to series like that in adults.

Shunt/ vessel Functional closure Anatomical closure Remnant called as
Ductus venosus 10-96 hrs after birth 2-3 weeks after birth Ligamentum venosum
Ductus arteriosus At birth Several weeks after birth Ligamentum arteriosum
Foramen ovale At birth 1 year after birth Fossa ovalis
Umbilical vein     Ligamentum teres
Distal hypogastric arteries     Umbilical ligaments

Option A: Obliteration of ductus venosus (DV)

  • After delivery, the physiologic sphincter of the DV constricts so that all of the blood entering the liver passes through the hepatic sinusoids.
  • Occlusion of the placental circulation causes an immediate decrease in the blood pressure in the IVC and the right atrium.
  • Several weeks after delivery, the DV becomes the ligamentum venosum.

Option B: Formation of ligamentum teres

  • The umbilical vein remains patent for a considerable period after delivery and may be used for the exchange transfusion of blood during early infancy.
  • The intra-abdominal part of the umbilical vein eventually becomes the round ligament of the liver, i.e., Ligamentum teres, which passes from the umbilicus to the porta hepatis.

Option D: Obliteration of distal hypogastric arteries

  • Obliteration of the distal hypogastric arteries weeks later post-delivery from the umbilical ligaments.
  • Most of the distal intra-abdominal parts of the umbilical arteries become medial umbilical ligaments.
  • The proximal parts of these vessels persist as the internal iliac arteries and the superior vesical arteries, which supply the urinary bladder.

questions.text: Antenatal ultrasound at 22 weeks in a primigravida suggests an anterior grade 1 placenta with cord vessels ending a few mm away from the placental margin. This type of presentation is associated with an increased risk for which of the following complication?

choices.text: Can cause fetal exsanguinations before labour due to blood loss
Torsion of the umbilical cord and fetal death

questions.solution:
The correct option is 3. Torsion of the umbilical cord and fetal death.

This scenario is describing a situation where the umbilical cord vessels (which provide oxygen and nutrients to the fetus) end a few millimeters away from the placental margin. This is known as a "marginal cord insertion." It's important to clarify that a marginal cord insertion doesn't necessarily mean there's an increased risk for all the complications mentioned, but the most significant risk associated with this condition is torsion (twisting) of the umbilical cord.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Maternal hemorrhage before delivery: This isn't directly related to a marginal cord insertion. Maternal hemorrhage before delivery is more commonly associated with placenta previa (placenta covering the cervix) or other placental abnormalities.

  2. Fetal exsanguination before labor due to blood loss: While there can be concerns about blood flow and oxygen supply in cases of marginal cord insertion, significant fetal exsanguination is not a common direct consequence of this condition. It's more associated with placental abruption or other issues involving the placenta.

  3. Torsion of the umbilical cord and fetal death: This is the correct answer. Marginal cord insertions can potentially result in torsion (twisting) of the umbilical cord due to the way the cord inserts into the placenta. This twisting can lead to reduced blood flow to the fetus and potentially result in fetal distress or even fetal death.

  4. Increased fetal malformations incidence: Marginal cord insertion itself isn't typically associated with an increased risk of fetal malformations. It's more related to issues with blood flow and oxygen supply to the fetus.

questions.text: A woman presents at 8 weeks of pregnancy for evaluation. Her investigations are done, and her blood group turns out B-negative. As a follow-up, her husband’s blood grouping is done, which is B positive. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given to such patients in all except which of the following condition?

choices.text: If she opts for a medical abortion
If amniocentesis is done at 16 weeks
If the baby’s Direct Coomb’s test at birth is positive
If a manual removal of the placenta is done at delivery

questions.solution:
Option C: If the baby’s Direct Coomb’s test at birth is positive

  • An Rh-negative woman and rh positive husband may have an rh positive fetus.
  • Thus there are chances of sensitization of maternal blood with fetal RBCs causing hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

 

Events which can cause sensitization:

  • Delivery (5-30ml)
  • Abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Abruption
  • Amniocentesis
  • Chorionic villi sampling

 

Fetal Rh D-positive erythrocytes induce the production of antibodies in maternal blood, and these antibodies cross the placenta and destroy fetal erythrocytes in subsequent pregnancies.

The erythrocytes haemolysis leads to hemolytic disease: fetal anaemia, jaundice, and hydrops.

 

After delivery Inj Anti D is given if:

  • The baby's  blood group is positive
  • DCT (Direct Commb’s Test) is negative

 

Option A: If she opts for a medical abortion

  • Abortion is an indication of Anti-D injection as there are chances of sensitization

 

Option B: If amniocentesis is done at 16 weeks

  • Amniocentesis or any invasive procedure indicates Anti-D administration if the sensitization is possible.

 

Option D: If a manual removal of the placenta is done at delivery

  • Manual removal of the placenta is an indication to deliver anti-D.

questions.text: 32-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestational age has high blood pressure reading of 150/100 mm Hg, repeat BP is 160/90 mm Hg, and urinalysis is negative for protein. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chronic hypertension

  • This patient with a history of hypertension, increased BP at the 11th week of gestation, no headache or visual changes, and negative urinalysis most likely has chronic hypertension.
  • Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mmHg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

Option A: Preeclampsia

  • Preeclampsia occurs when blood pressure increases to 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).
  • This patient has no visual changes, nausea or headache. Her urinalysis is also negative for protein.

Option C: Eclampsia

  • It is present when seizures develop in a patient suffering from preeclampsia. This patient does not have seizures or preeclampsia.

Option D: Gestational hypertension

  • Gestational hypertension occurs when maternal blood pressure reaches 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks, and proteinuria is not present.
  • The given patient has developed hypertension before 20 weeks of gestation. She also has a history of hypertension for 5 years.

questions.text: A woman presents at 32 weeks for evaluation. She has been an overt diabetic for four years with no history/evaluation suggestive of microangiopathy. Her sugars are well controlled at present with an adjusted dose of insulin. What should be the time of termination of her pregnancy?

choices.text: Should be terminated now after steroid cover
After 37 weeks but not later than 39 weeks
Should be allowed to go till 40 weeks as long as sugars are controlled

questions.solution:
Option C: After 37 weeks but not later than 39 weeks

  • The patient's overt diabetes is well controlled with insulin; therefore, delivery should be performed after 37 weeks but not later than 37 weeks.
Type of diabetes Time of delivery
  • GDM controlled on diet
  • GDM requiring medication
  • Overt diabetes (controlled)
  • Overt DM (uncontrolled)
  • 40 - 41 weeks
  • 38 - 39 weeks
  • ≥ 37 wks.( max:39 weeks)
  • 34 weeks (max 37 weeks)

 

Option A: Should be terminated now after steroid cover

  • The patient's overt diabetes is well controlled with insulin; therefore, delivery should be performed after 37 weeks but not later than 39 weeks.
  • If the overt diabetes is uncontrolled, delivery should be performed at 34 weeks of gestation.
  • Therefore, this option is not correct.

Option B: At 34 completed weeks

  • If the overt diabetes is uncontrolled, delivery should be performed at 34 weeks of gestation.
  • The patient's overt diabetes is well controlled with insulin; therefore, delivery should be performed after 37 weeks but not later than 39 weeks.

Option D: Should be allowed to go till 40 weeks as long as sugars are controlled

  • If the patient's gestational diabetes mellitus is well controlled on a diet, then pregnancy can be expected up to 40-41 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman delivers a preterm baby at 34 weeks. On examination, the baby has a neural tube defect. The woman also had a history of fever with a rash in the first trimester. Which of the following are the most important differential diagnoses of intrauterine infections in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Toxoplasma and rubella

  • ToRCH infections are a group infections that can be passed from the mother to the child (vertical transmission). Transmission can be transplacental or via delivery. These infections include:
    • Toxoplasma gondii.
    • Rubella.
    • Cytomegalovirus.
    • Herpes simplex virus.
  • Some common symptoms in almost all TORCH infections include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenia and growth retardation.
  • Toxoplasma and rubella are most commonly associated with neural tube defects.
  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by toxoplasma gondii, transmitted by cat faeces or ingested infected meat. It occurs in the fetus, mostly when the maternal infection is in the third trimester of the pregnancy. However, severe infection in a baby occurs when the infection in the mother is in the first trimester and is associated with neurologic abnormalities, hydrocephalus, cerebral calcification, chorioretinitis with or without severe visual impairment and blueberry muffin rash.
  • Rubella virus is one of the most potent teratogens, and the risk of fetal infection is worst during organogenesis in the first trimester. It is transmitted to the mother via respiratory droplets and can present as rash, fever, polyarthritis and lymphadenopathy. Congenital rubella syndrome is caused by vertical transmission of the rubella virus and includes one or more of the following:
    • Eye defects—cataracts and congenital glaucoma.
    • Congenital heart defects—patent ductus arteriosus and pulmonary artery stenosis.
    • Sensorineural deafness—is the most common single defect.
    • Central nervous system defects—microcephaly, developmental delay, mental retardation, and meningoencephalitis.
    • Pigmentary retinopathy.
    • Forchiemer spots on the soft palate.
    • Neonatal purpura and dermal extramedullary hematopoiesis (blueberry muffin rash).
    • Hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice.
    • Radiolucent bone disease.
  • If rubella infection occurs before 16 weeks of gestation, termination of pregnancy should be offered.

 

 

Option A: CMV and Toxoplasma

  • CMV infection in the baby occurs if the maternal infection is in the second trimester of pregnancy. It causes hearing loss, seizures, petechial rash, blueberry muffin rash, chorioretinitis and periventricular calcifications in the newborn, not neural tube defects.
  • Toxoplasmosis infection in the third trimester of pregnancy has a high risk of vertical transmission and presents as chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications and sometimes neural tube defects.

 

Option C: Rubella and herpes

  • Rubella virus infection in the first trimester is associated with neural tube defects and other abnormalities of organogenesis in the newborn.
  • Herpes virus infection in the newborn occurs during delivery and causes meningoencephalitis and vesicular herpetic lesions.

 

Option D: CMV and herpes

  • Cytomegalovirus infection in the newborn occurs if the maternal infection is in the second trimester of pregnancy and causes hearing loss, seizures, petechial rash, blueberry muffin rash, chorioretinitis and periventricular calcifications.
  • Herpes virus infection in the newborn occurs during delivery and causes meningoencephalitis and vesicular herpetic lesions.
  • Both of these viruses do not cause neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female G2P1L1 presents to the gynecologist with complaints of the passage of some products of conception followed by heavy bleeding 2 hours ago. She is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. A diagnosis of incomplete abortion is made, and the doctor performs an evacuation. He, however, doubts it is a molar pregnancy and thus sends it for histopathology. The point of distinction between a complete mole and a partial mole is?

choices.text: Partial mole shows trophoblastic proliferation with absent villi
Typical of partial mole is diffuse cellular atypia
Partial mole is more prone to tumor malignancy

questions.solution:
Option D: Partial mole is triploid

  • Partial mole is triploid with karyotype 69 XXX (most commonly) or XXY.
  • Partial mole results from fertilization of a haploid ovum by 2 sperms, both carrying X chromosome mostly; hence the resulting embryo is triploid ( 69, XXX most common, or 69, XXY).
  • Fetal tissue is present in a partial mole along with partial swelling of chorionic villi and focal hyperplasia of trophoblastic tissue.

Option A: Partial mole shows trophoblastic proliferation with absent villi

  • Choriocarcinoma is a malignant tumour of the trophoblast.
  • A characteristic feature is the identification of intimately related syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts without the formation of definite placental-type villi.
  • Since choriocarcinomas include syncytiotrophoblasts, they cause elevated blood levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin.

Option B: Typical of the partial mole is diffuse cellular atypia

  • Focal hyperplasia of trophoblastic tissue is seen in a partial mole.
  • The diffuse cellular atypia is seen in a complete mole.​​​​​​​

Option C: Partial mole is more prone to tumour malignancy

  • A complete mole is more prone to tumour malignancy than a partial mole.
  • A complete mole has a higher chance of transformation to choriocarcinoma than a partial mole.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of sudden-onset abdominal distension, vomiting, and difficulty in breathing in a 32-year-old patient with a history of primary infertility, positive pregnancy test, and severe ascites on ultrasound, who had undergone ovulation induction and ovulation triggered with injection hCG?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome

  • All symptoms are suggestive of severe Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS).
  • The history of infertility treatment is the key to diagnosis in this case.
  • Severe ascites can lead to abdominal distension, vomiting and respiratory difficulty.
  • OHSS can occur during pregnancy; in fact, it is more severe during pregnancy.
  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment.
  • A woman with a history of ovulation induction with ovulation trigger, presenting with complaints of pain in the abdomen and abdominal distension, must always raise suspicion of OHSS.
  • A positive UPT should not raise confusion, as OHSS can be present in pregnancy, too. However, an ectopic pregnancy must be ruled out in such a case.
  • OHSS can range from mild to critical in severity.
  • Different types of presentations of OHSS in severity are given in the chart below.
Mild OHSS

Abdominal bloating

Mild abdominal pain

Ovarian size usually < 8 cm
Moderate OHSS

Moderate abdominal pain

Nausea ± vomiting

Ultrasound evidence of ascites

Ovarian size usually 8 to 12 cm
Severe OHSS

Clinical ascites (occasionally pleural effusion)

Oliguria

Hemoconcentration hematocrit (> 45%)

Hypoproteinemia

Ovarian size usually > 12 cm
Critical OHSS

Tense ascites or large pleural effusion

Hematocrit (> 55%)

White cell count > 25000

Oligouria/ anuria

Thromboembolism

Acute respiratory distress syndrome

Option A: Choriocarcinoma

  • Choriocarcinoma presents with vaginal bleeding that too after a few weeks of pregnancy that resulted in either a vaginal delivery, abortion or molar pregnancy.

Option B: Molar pregnancy

  • Molar pregnancy presents with pervaginal bleeding, and there is a snowstorm appearance of the gestational sac on ultrasound.

Option D: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

  • Although abdominal pain and distension could be a presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy but would occur only as early as 4-6 weeks of conception.

questions.text: A 30-year-old comes to the gynecologist for a routine check-up. The patient is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. The patient was on the 24th day of her cycle. The ultrasound shows an incidental finding of a small thick-walled right ovarian cyst with peripheral vascularity. A follow-up scan is done days post menstruation and shows no such cyst. What is the most probable mechanism involved in resolving the structure involved in the patient’s pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Decreased levels of LH

  • This is a case of a corpus luteal cyst.

  • The ultrasound finding of the thick-walled cyst with peripheral vascularity in the premenstrual period suggests a corpus luteal cyst that spontaneously resolves post menstruation in the absence of pregnancy.

  • Continued corpus luteum function depends on continued LH production.

  • Without this stimulation, the corpus luteum will invariably regress after 12 to16 days and form scar-like Corpora Albicans.

  • In the absence of pregnancy, the corpus luteum regresses, and estrogen and progesterone levels wane.

  • If pregnancy occurs, HCG from the placenta will mimic LH action, and the corpus luteum continues to secrete progesterone.

Option A: Increased levels of progesterone

  • Post-menstruation, there is a drop in the levels of progesterone, which subsequently increases again after ovulation as progesterone is released from the corpus luteum.

Option B: Increased levels of estrogen

  • Post-menstruation, estrogen increases gradually as it is produced from the ovarian follicles, which FSH recruits. This increase is responsible for the inhibition of FSH and not for the resolution of the corpus luteum.

Option D: Decreased levels of FSH

  • FSH levels are high in the early proliferative phase, and levels are inhibited by estrogen that is produced from the follicular development.

  • Drop in FSH does not cause corpus luteal cyst resolution.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is being managed in a tertiary care hospital. The pediatrician explained to the resident doctors that the patient had a partially compensated metabolic alkalosis on the arterial blood gas analysis. Her urine chloride was lower than normal, and the administration of IV normal saline improved her condition. Which of the following is the least likely cause of her acid-base derangement?
questions.solution:
Option D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

  • The case describes a patient who suffered metabolic alkalosis with low urinary chloride that responded to the administration of normal saline. The measurement of urinary chloride is a key diagnostic workup that further reveals the etiologies of metabolic alkalosis and guides further management.
  • The urine levels of chloride [Cl−] are low in patients with metabolic alkalosis resulting from volume depletion. These patients are responsive to the administration of chloride in the form of NaCl or KCl.
  • In contrast, patients who suffer from metabolic alkalosis and have a high urinary chloride are generally resistant to the administration of chloride in the form of NaCl.
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis.
  • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia, the deficiencies of 11β-hydroxylase and 17α-hydroxylase result in the excessive production of mineralocorticoids. This causes hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis (excess of bicarbonate). The unbalanced levels of bicarbonate in plasma are balanced by the increased excretion of chloride in the urine. This causes high urinary chloride levels (as compared to low urinary chloride in this patient), and the condition is resistant to the administration of chloride.

Option A: Vomiting

  • Vomiting results in the loss of gastric contents and secretions that are rich in HCl. The loss of chloride in vomiting causes the kidney to retain chloride, so urinary chloride is low. The condition is sensitive to the administration of fluids containing chloride.

Option B: Cystic fibrosis

  • Cystic fibrosis can result in metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia because of excessive NaCl losses in sweat. As the Cl is being lost in sweat, so the kidneys will decrease the excretion of chloride resulting in low urine chloride. The condition is responsive to the administration of chloride-containing fluids.

Option C: Post hypercapnia syndrome

  • Post hypercapnic syndrome (characterized by metabolic alkalosis) happens after the correction of chronic respiratory acidosis.
  • This is typically seen in patients with chronic lung pathology who are treated with mechanical ventilation.
  • During chronic respiratory acidosis, appropriate renal compensation leads to an increase in the serum [HCO3−]. Because it is still present after acute correction of the respiratory acidosis, this [HCO3−] causes metabolic alkalosis. The metabolic alkalosis persists because the patient with chronic respiratory acidosis is intravascularly depleted because of the Cl− loss that occurred during the initial metabolic compensation for the primary respiratory acidosis. This chloride loss causes low urinary chloride and is responsive to correction by the administration of chloride-rich fluids.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl child is brought by her mother to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of poor physical growth. She looks pale, has hair loss, and frequently falls ill. Her diet is vegetarian. On examination, her sexual characteristics are delayed. Her Hb is 8 g/dL. Which element is deficient in this girl?
questions.solution:
Option C: Zinc

  • The symptoms of poor physical growth, pallor, hair loss and delayed sexual characteristics are suggestive of zinc deficiency.
  • A deficiency of zinc can lead to the syndrome of growth failure, anaemia and hypogonadism.

 

Zinc

  • Second most common trace element in the body after iron.
  • It plays a role in gene transcription, nucleic acid metabolism, and protein synthesis and acts as a major antioxidant (being part of the enzyme superoxide dismutase)
  • It is mainly derived from animal protein. Liver, oyster, meat, fish, nuts and eggs are rich sources.
  • Zinc Deficiency
    • Poor physical growth
    • Delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism
    • Alopecia
    • Anaemia
    • Diarrhoea
    • Dermatitis
    • Impaired immune function
    • Poor wound healing
    • Skeletal abnormalities
    • Acrodermatitis enteropathica
  • Treatment: 0.5-1.0 mg elemental zinc/kg/ day

Option A: Calcium Deficiency

  • Calcium deficiency leads to Tetany and rickets.
  • In old age, a deficiency of calcium leads to osteoporosis.

Option B: Copper deficiency

  • Copper deficiency causes Microcytic anaemia and hypochromic anaemia that are nonresponsive to iron therapy.
  • It may also cause hair depigmentation, neutropenia, neurological problems and osteoporosis.

Option D: Magnesium deficiency:

  • Magnesium deficiency causes Irritability, Tetany and hypo- or hyperreflexia
  • In the heart, magnesium deficiency causes cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: A 28-year-old female primigravida gives birth to an infant at the gestational age of 39 weeks, and the baby's birth weight is 1500 grams. The cry is delayed and weak. On examination, reflexes are sluggish, and on the U/S brain, no solid or cystic lesion was seen. Mild hydrocephalus dilated all four brain edema grade 2 parenchymal and IVH, including the germinal matrix. Grade 2 intracranial hemorrhage is ruled out. At a CT scan of the brain, extensive white matter edema involving the subcortical regions of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes caused effacement of the right lateral ventricle. No hemorrhagic density is identified. Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy involving the frontal, parietal, and temporal regions. Which part of the brain is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Option B: Parasagittal area

  • According to signs and symptoms, the case mentioned above is of Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy and the area mainly involved the parasagittal site.
  • Part of the brain most commonly involved in term neonates with HIE is the Parasagittal area.
  • In preterm neonates- Periventricular area.
  • The most common cause of seizure in newborns is Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy
  • The most common type of neonatal seizures: Subtle seizures

Option A: Periventricular area

  • The severity, duration, and level of brain development of hypoxia all affect the pattern of brain injury.
  • Preterm newborns with mild to moderate HI damage develop periventricular leukomalacia and germinal matrix haemorrhage.

Option C: Basal ganglia

  • The brain's basal ganglia, cerebral cortex, and watershed regions are typically damaged in HIE. However, PVL can also occur.
  • The term "PVL" refers to damage to the brain's white matter close to the lateral ventricles, which are found in the top part of the brain.

Option D: Hippocampus

  • The hippocampus and cerebellum showed the most severe histopathologic brain damage, followed by the cortex, and the brainstem showed the least harm.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate who is preterm is brought to the emergency department by his mother with complaints of poor feeding, fever, and lethargy for 3 days. The mother also complained about reduced milk production. On examination, the baby has tachycardia and tachypnea; his temperature is 39°C, a blood sugar level of 47 mg/dl, a pulse rate of 126 beats per minute, and decreased urine output. The on-duty consultant asks to send all relevant investigations. Which of the following will be most significant in the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Total leukocyte count

  • This is a case of neonatal sepsis in which the patient presents with complaints of poor feeding, fever and lethargy for 3 days.
  • The child has respiratory distress, tachycardia, hypoglycemia and fever. All of these symptoms are non-specific but point towards neonatal sepsis.
  • Neonatal sepsis is the leading cause of mortality and morbidity in neonates.
  • The most important investigation in neonatal sepsis is total leukocyte count.
  • Early onset neonatal sepsis presents in less than 3 days of birth, and the approach towards these patients depends on whether they are symptomatic or not. Symptomatic neonates should undergo a full diagnostic evaluation which includes blood cultures, complete blood count with differentials, lumbar puncture, chest radiography and C reactive protein.
  • Late-onset sepsis presents from 7 to 28 days of life.
  • Empirical antibiotics should be started in all cases and should be followed closely.

Option A: Platelet count

  • In neonatal sepsis, total leukocyte count is significant. It shows there is an ongoing infection within the body.
  • But in premature babies, the total leukocyte count is less than 5000/mm3.
  • The platelet count is important for patients having bleeding disorders.

Option B: Absolute neutrophil count

  • In acute infections, first responders are neutrophils.
  • There should be neutrophilia, but the immune system of premature babies is not fully developed, leading to neutropenia.

Option D: Immature to total neutrophil ratio

  • Immature to total neutrophil (IT) ratio > 0.2 is one of the very important features of sepsis.
  • But total leukocyte count is more significant in neonatal sepsis.

questions.text: A boy was delivered at 30 weeks gestation, with no cry and no breathing. The pediatric resident started with the resuscitation protocol, provided warmth and maintained temperature, positioned the airway, and stimulated the baby. After these steps, a resident noticed that the baby was still apneic and the heart rate was < 100/min. What would be the next single best step of management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Positive pressure ventilation

  • Positive pressure ventilation is the single most effective step in the resuscitation of neonates who fail to breathe at birth.
  • It can be done by using an inflating bag, mask, or T-piece resuscitator.
  • By positive pressure ventilation, we actually prove the air to the baby.
  • This method is used to exchange air between the lungs and the external environment.
  • A device which is used for positive pressure ventilation is known as an 'Ambu bag'.

 

Option A: Suction of airways

  • Suction is used to clear the airways of mucous.
  • Suction should be used only in case of mucous or fluid in the mouth or nose.
  • The pressure of the suction machine should not exceed 80-100 mmHg.

Option B: Tactile stimulation

  • It is the warming and drying of the baby.
  • It is done by using a towel, a warmer or by rubbing the sole.

Option D: Chest compressions

  • Chest compression is used to control the heart rate.
  • It can be done when the heart rate is absent

questions.text: A 6-month-old twin born with a gap of 6 minutes is presented to the clinic by his mother. He complains that the elderly baby is more playful and alert and reacts well, while the younger one is the opposite. He is not very playful and cries. The mother also complains that the younger baby cannot Roll front to back and back to front on the bed. Also, he can not recognize his parents, and he has no anxiety about strangers. The mother gets worried and asks the doctor about her younger baby. What is the 'red flag sign' in developmental milestones in the baby?

choices.text: No sitting with support at 6 months

questions.solution:
Option D: No Social smile by 6 months

  • This is the case of developmental milestones in which a mother has a twin baby. The elderly baby achieved his normal developmental milestone, but the younger one is not because he is not alert and playful and, he is not reacting to voices, he can not roll on the bed dependently. If a baby has not achieved the above developmental milestones at this age, then he is in a red flag sign.
  • A red flag sign means the upper limit for the age at which reflexes, if not present, are abnormal.
  • Normally, the infant has a social smile and recognises parents, is developed in 2 months along with an alert to sound.
  • Normally, a 6-month baby has anxiety about strangers. He can babble and can sit unassisted.

Option A: No sitting with support at 6 months

  • If a baby can not sit with support at the age of six months, it can be called a developmental delay, but we can not say that it is a red flag sign because if a baby can not sit with support at 9 months, then it can be red flag sign for the baby.

Option B: No pincer grasp at 6 months

  • Normally, there is no pincer grasp at the age of Six months.
  • The pincer grasp is developed at 9-10 months which is three fingers (immature) pincer grasp.
  • A mature grasp is two finger grasp which is normally developed at 12 months of age.
  • Timing for usual appearance of reflex is not same as timing for labelling it as red flag sign.
  • Red flag sign means the upper limit for age at which reflex if not present - is abnormal

Option C: No single word by 6 months

  • A baby can not say one single word at 6 months. At 6 months baby can only produce a babbling sound from the mouth.
  • Baby can say mama/dada (non-specific) at 9-10 months.
  • Normally, a baby can say a single word at 12 months which is specific, like he can say clearly mama and dada.

questions.text: A 15-month-old male child is brought to the family physician by his mother for a well-child examination. The mother tells the doctor that they bring toys for the baby, and the baby is given a walker and a plush ball that he plays with both his hands and even throws. The parents see that he plays with all the objects, but when they try to make him say a few words, he does not follow. The child is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which milestone is yet to be achieved by the child in this case?

choices.text: Transfers objects from 1 hand to another

questions.solution:
Option D: Speaks in three-word sentences

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which a 15-months-old child is brought to the physician by his mother for examination.
  • The mother states to the doctor that they bring toys for the baby and the baby is given a walker, a plush ball that he plays with both his hands and even throws it.
  • The parents see that he plays with all the objects, but when they try to make him say a few words, he doesn't follow.
  • The child is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The child still cannot speak a 2- or 3-word sentence because he is only 15 months.
  • A child speaks 2-word sentences at 2 years and 3-word sentences at 3 years.

Option A: Walking with support

  • The child, in this case, can already walk with support.
  • A child is usually able to walk with support from 12 months onwards.

Option B: Transfers objects from 1 hand to another

  • The child, in this case, is of 15 months.
  • So, he can already transfer objects from 1 hand to another.
  • A child usually transfers objects at 7 months.

Option C: Builds a tower of 2 cubes

  • The child, in this case, is of 15 months.
  • So, he can already build a tower of 2 cubies.
  • A child is able to build a tower of 2 cubes at 15 months

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child is brought to the pediatric OPD by her mother, who was normal at birth having normal early development. However, she now presents with microcephaly, regression of acquired language and motor milestones, and abnormal stereotypic hand-wringing movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rett syndrome

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a classical case of Rett syndrome. The hallmark of the disease is the loss of motor skills and language and regression of the previously attained milestones of life. (child starts to lose their skills). Other features of Rett syndrome are:-
    • X linked dominant inheritance
    • Gene involved - MECP2 gene
    • Mostly females (almost exclusively the females)
    • Normal head circumference at birth and normal early development.
    • Deceleration of head growth and acquired microcephaly
    • Loss of purposeful hand movements with the development of stereotypic hand-wringing movement

Option A: Angelman syndrome

  • It is a defect of gene silencing.
  • It is characterised by seizures, ataxia, mental retardation, and inappropriate laughter (happy puppets)

Option C: Asperger syndrome

  • It is characterised by significant social inheritance, nonverbal communication difficulties, and restricted and repetitive patterns of behaviour and interest.

Option D: Metachromatic Dystrophy

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Causes progressive demyelination of the central (white matter) and peripheral nervous system.
  • It is characterised by muscle wasting and weakness, stiff muscles, delayed development, and loss of sight that worsens over time and leads to blindness, convulsions, trouble swallowing, paralysis, and dementia.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of fever and pain behind the ear for the past 2 days. The patient had a previous history of ear discharge and otalgia for which she sought no treatment. On examination, mastoid tenderness, redness, and swelling behind ears causing protrusion of the auricle are noted. On plain x-rays of the mastoid region, there is clouding of mastoid air spaces, and the surgeon planned for mastoidectomy. What landmark surgeon will the look for?
questions.solution:
Option B: MacEwen's triangle

  • The above case is a condition of acute otitis media which leads to the complication of acute mastoiditis.
  • Acute mastoiditis: It is characterized by infection of mastoid air cells by long-term suppurative effusion of the middle Ear that moves into mastoid air cells.
  • Symptoms: same as acute otitis media, including pus drainage, otalgia, mastoid tenderness, swelling behind the Ear causing protrusion of auricle, fever, and impaired hearing loss. On X-ray and CT scans, there are opacifications of mastoid air cells.
  • Treatment: Mastoidectomy.
  • MacEwan's triangle, Aka suprameatal triangle surgical landmark for mastoid antrum.
  • Borders: The mastoid fossa is a triangular-shaped area with superior, anterior, and posterior borders.
    • Superior – Supramastoid crest: Extension of the zygomatic process's upper border of the posterior root.
    • Anterior – Suprameatal spine (spine of Henle): Projection of bone at the posterosuperior aspect of the opening of the external acoustic meatus, immediately inferior to the root  of the zygomatic process.
    • Posterior – Hypothetical vertical line: Tangential to the mid-point of the posterior wall of the external auditory canal.

 

Option A: Spine of Henle

  • The Spine of Henle is an important structure found at the posterior superior lateral edge of the ear canal, which marks the level of the antrum of the mastoid. The temporal line marks the superior border of the mastoid cavity.

Option C: External acoustic meatus

  • The ear canal (external acoustic meatus, external auditory meatus, EAM) is a pathway running from the outer ear to the middle ear. The adult human ear canal extends from the pinna to the eardrum and is about 2.5 centimetres (1 in) and 0.7 centimetres (0.3 in).

Option D: Roof of the zygomatic bone

  • The zygomatic bone (cheek bone) is a quadrangular bone that contributes to forming the skeletal framework of the orbit and cheeks.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male came to ENT OPD with a complaint of dizziness and nausea while waking up from the bed, which began 6 hours earlier. The patient is diabetic and has a family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient developed nystagmus in the Dix-hall pike maneuver. Which of the following is most commonly involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Posterior semicircular canal

  • Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position.
  • There is no hearing loss or other neurologic symptoms.
  • Positional testing establishes the diagnosis and helps to differentiate it from positional vertigo of central origin.
  • BPPV most commonly arises from the posterior semi-circular canal. Much less frequently, the horizontal semi-circular canal.

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV):

  • It is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position. There is no hearing loss or other neurologic symptoms. Positional testing establishes the diagnosis and helps to differentiate it from positional vertigo of central origin.
  • The disease is caused by a disorder of the posterior semi-circular canal though many patients have a history of head trauma and ear infection. It has been demonstrated that otoconial debris, consisting of calcium carbonate crystals, is released from the degenerating macula of the utricle and floats freely in the endolymph. When it settles on the cupula of the posterior semi-circular canal in a critical head position, it causes displacement of the cupula and vertigo.
  • The vertigo is fatigable on assuming the same position repeatedly due to dispersal of the otoconia but can be induced again after a period of rest. Thus, the typical history and hall pike maneuver establish the diagnosis. The condition can be treated by performing Epley's maneuver.
  • The principle of this maneuver is to reposition the otoconial debris from the posterior semi-circular canal back into the utricle. The doctor stands behind the patient and the assistant on the side. The patient is made to sit on the table so that when he is made to lie down, his head is beyond the edge of the table, as is done in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. His face is turned 45° to the affected side.

Option A: Horizontal semi-circular canal

  • The horizontal canal will respond maximum to rotation on the vertical axis. Due to this arrangement of the three canals in three different planes, any change in the position of the head can be detected. Stimulation of semi-circular canals produces nystagmus, and the direction of nystagmus is determined by the plane of the canal being stimulated. Thus, nystagmus is horizontal from the horizontal canal, rotatory from the superior canal, and vertical from the posterior canal.

Option C: Superior semicircular canal

  • It is rarely involved with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

Option D: All are equally involved

  • Only a particular semi-circular involve in a given time.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the ENT outpatient department complaining of headache, hearing loss, and tinnitus. There is no history of fever or any discharge from both ears. Weber's test is performed on examination to check his type of deafness. In the defective right middle ear, weber's test would lateralize to?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lateralized to the right side

In the case of a defective right middle ear, Weber's test would lateralize to the Lateralized to right ear.

Weber's test is a simple and quick tuning fork test used to help differentiate between conductive hearing loss and sensorineural hearing loss. During the test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient's forehead or midline of the skull. The patient is asked to report in which ear the sound appears louder or where they perceive the sound to be located.

In conductive hearing loss, there is a problem with sound transmission through the outer or middle ear, which can be caused by conditions such as middle ear infections, otosclerosis, or perforated eardrum. When the affected ear has conductive hearing loss, the sound from the tuning fork will be heard better in that ear, and the sound will lateralize or shift towards the defective ear.

In the case mentioned, the patient has defective right middle ear, and the Weber's test would lateralize to the right ear, indicating that the sound is heard better in the right ear, consistent with conductive hearing loss on the right side. The reported symptoms of headache, hearing loss, and tinnitus are suggestive of a middle ear issue that may be contributing to the conductive hearing loss in the right ear.

No lateralization → normal hearing or bilateral hearing loss.

  • In normal Individuals: No sound lateralization occurs as both ear's bone conduction is normal and equal.
  • In conductive deafness (seen in the external ear and middle ear disorders): Lateralization of sound occurs in the diseased ear.
  • In SNHL (seen in the inner ear and neural pathway disorders): Lateralization of sound occurs in the better ear.

Option A: Normal

  • If the weber test is normal, there is normal hearing or bilateral sensorineural hearing loss or bilateral symmetrical conductive hearing loss.
  • So, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Centralized

  • In the weber test, it is centralized in normal persons with normal hearing.
  • So, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Lateralization to the left side

  • It occurs due to sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear, or it is due to conductive hearing loss in the left ear.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of bilateral hearing loss over the previous two days. Her complaints are of better hearing whenever she plays music on a loudspeaker. She is vitally stable and has no history of any chronic illness. Her general physical and systemic examinations are unremarkable. What will be the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Otosclerosis

  • The patient mentioned above has clinical features and investigation findings suggestive of otosclerosis.
  • Otosclerosis is the abnormal growth of the bony labyrinth, primarily at the oval window.
  • In otosclerosis, stapes become fixated on the oval window.
  • It leads to progressive conductive hearing loss because the ossicle's vibrating ability becomes increasingly limited.
  • It predominantly occurs in females (20-30 years).
  • There is an increased incidence of pregnancy.
  • It has an autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • It can lead to bilateral hearing loss.
  • Schwartz sign- a pink flamingo sign is a characteristic feature.
  • Carhart's notch- dip present at 2000 Hz in bone conduction.
  • Paracusis Willisii is seen in otosclerosis:
  • The patient hears better in noisy rather than quiet areas.
  • This is due to the reason that a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings.
  • Surgical treatment in otosclerosis: Stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis is the treatment of choice.
  • Here the fixed otosclerotic stapes are removed, and a prosthesis is inserted between the incus and oval window.
  • The prosthesis may be a Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon, or titanium–Teflon piston. In 90% of patients, there is good improvement in hearing after stapedectomy.

Option A: Vestibular Schwannoma

  • Acoustic neuroma is also known as neurilemmoma or an eighth nerve tumour.
  • In most cases, progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom.
  • There is marked difficulty in understanding speech, out of proportion to the pure tone hearing loss.
  • Vestibular symptoms are imbalance or instability. This feature is characteristic of acoustic neuroma. Some patients may get sudden hearing loss.

Option B: Endolymphatic Hydrops

  • Ménière’s disease is a disease of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph. It is characterised by the following:
    • Vertigo
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Tinnitus and
    • Aural fullness.

Option C: Presbycusis

  • Presbycusis is a sensorineural hearing loss related to age.
  • Pathophysiology: Irreversible and progressive damage to the hair cells of the organ of corti that impairs high-frequency hearing.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of nasal discharge and congestion. The attending doctor orders nasal endoscopy to evaluate internal nasal structures. While doing endoscopy, the surgeon approaches an area through which it is difficult to pass an endoscope. The surgeon tells his junior that this is the narrowest part of the nasal septum. Which of the following terms best describes the narrowest part of the nasal cavity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Nasal Valve

  • The nasal valve is formed by the limen nasi and inferior turbinate laterally and the septum medially.
  • The velocity of the air increases as it passes through the nasal valve, the narrowest site of the upper respiratory tract. At this point, turbulent flow is observed in the nasal cavity, with different air layers swirling together. The change from laminar to turbulent flow is paramount as it allows the velocity of the air to reduce, thus allowing prolonged contact of inspired air with the nasal mucosa and therefore allowing the nose to perform its vital functions.
  • During expiration, the narrowest part of the nasal cavity, i.e., the nasal valve area, offers maximum resistance to the nasal airflow leading to the formation of eddy currents that ventilates the sinuses.

Option B: Choanae

  • The Choanae (singular choana), posterior nasal apertures, or internal nostrils are two openings found at the back of the nasal passage between the nasal cavity and the nasopharynx in tetrapods.

Option C: Middle Turbinate

  • Middle Turbinate: It is an ethmoturbinal- a part of the ethmoid bone.
  • It is attached to the lateral wall by a bony lamella called ground or basal lamella.

Option D: Vestibule

  • The anterior and inferior part of the nasal cavity is called the vestibule.
  • It is lined by the skin and contains sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and the hair called vibrissae.
  • Its upper limit on the lateral wall is marked by limen nasi.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female actress visits the hospital for the correction of septal deviation. Your senior doctor asks you to mark the Cottle's line and decide the management. Which of the following best describes Cottle's line?

choices.text: Vertical line is drawn between the nasal process of ethmoid & nasal spine of maxillary crest
Vertical line is drawn between nasal process of frontal & nasal spine of maxillary crest
Horizontal line is drawn between nasal process of sphenoid & nasal spine of maxillary crest
Horizontal line is drawn between nasal process of ethmoid & nasal spine of maxillary crest

questions.solution:
Option B: Vertical line drawn between nasal process of frontal & nasal spine of maxillary crest

Cottle's line

  • A vertical line is drawn between the nasal process of the frontal & nasal spine of the maxillary crest
  • Deviations anterior to this are treated by septoplasty & Posterior to Cottle's line are treated by SMR.

Types of Septal Incisions in Septoplasty

Following are the types of incisions in septoplasty:

  1. Killian's: Cephalic to the caudal end of the septum in the nasal mucosa.
  2. Transfixion: Through and through the incision, close to but caudal to the caudal end of the septum.
  3. Hemi-transfixion: Same as the transfixion incision but on one side.

Option A: Vertical line is drawn between the nasal process of the ethmoid & nasal spine of the maxillary crest

  • It mentions the nasal process of ethmoid, which is not in accordance with the anatomical locations needed for Cottle's line.

Option C: Horizontal line is drawn between the nasal process of the sphenoid & nasal spine of the maxillary crest

  • It mentions a horizontal line drawn between the nasal process of the sphenoid & nasal spine of the maxillary crest instead of a vertical Cottle's line.

Option D: Horizontal line drawn between nasal process of ethmoid & nasal spine of maxillary crest

  • It mentions a horizontal line drawn between the nasal process of ethmoid & nasal spine of the maxillary crest instead of the vertical Cottle's line.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the hospital complaining of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx. The biopsy revealed laryngeal carcinoma. Under the supervision of the senior doctor, a total laryngectomy is planned. Which of the following is best to rehabilitate speech in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tracheoesophageal speech

After a laryngectomy, the patient loses speech completely. Therefore, the methods employed for speech production are as follows:

  • Written language
  • Aphonic lip speech (by trapping air in the buccal cavity combined with sign language)
  • Esophageal speech
  • Electrolarynx
  • Transoral pneumatic device
  • Transesophageal speech
  • Blom-Singer prosthesis
  • Panje prosthesis.

Tracheoesophageal speech:

  • This is the most effective method for voice restoration.
  • An attempt is made to carry air from the trachea to the esophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by the placement of a prosthesis (small one-way valve (Blom-Singer and Panje valve) is made) so that during expiration, some air from the lungs enters the pharynx, hence vibrating the pharyngo-oesophageal segment.
  • The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech.
  • This technique has the disadvantage of food entering the trachea; however, the use of a prosthesis (Blom-Singer or Panje valve) shunts the air from the trachea to the esophagus due to the inbuilt valve, thus preventing problems of aspiration.

Comparison of speech production before and after laryngectomy
Physical requirements Normal laryngeal voice production Oesophageal speech production Surgical voice production
Initiator Moving column of air from the lungs Moving column of air from the esophagus Moving column of air from the lungs
Vibrator Vocal cords Vibratory /pharyngo-oesophageal (PE) segment Vibratory / pharyngoesophageal (PE) segment
Resonators Resonating cavities: nose, mouth, pharynx Resonating cavities; nose, mouth, pharynx Resonating cavities; nose, mouth pharynx

Option A: Regular speech therapy is enough

  • After total laryngectomy, the patient loses speech completely. Therefore, other voice production methods have to be employed, and speech therapy is simply not enough.

Option C: Esophageal speech

  • The patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper esophagus and then slowly eject it from the esophagus into the pharynx.
  • The patients can usually speak six to ten words before swallowing air.
  • The voice is rough but loud and understandable; however, not superior to the results obtained from tracheoesophageal speech.

Option D: Electrolarynx

  • The artificial electrolarynx is used in those who fail to learn esophageal speech.
  • It is a transistorized, battery-operated portable device with a vibrating disc held against the soft tissues of the neck, and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx, which is then modulated into speech.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with left ear discharge, itching, and severe ear pain for the last four days. She gives the history of using cotton buds to clean the ear wax four days back. The following image shows an oedematous narrow ear canal obscuring the tympanic membrane. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute Otitis Externa

  • Otitis externa is a disorder causing inflammation of the external ear canal (EAC).
  • Otitis externa is called "swimmer's ear" because repeated exposure to water can make the ear canal more vulnerable to inflammation.
  • It is a classic case of otitis externa post-self-trauma to the ear.
  • It is commonly seen after minor trauma to EAC skin, like buds/ itching the ear.
  • The most common organisms are Pseudomonas, E. coli, and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It mostly occurs in immunocompetent individuals.
  • The main symptoms are burning, ear pain, purulent discharge, itching, and conductive deafness.
  • Treatment: Common topical antibiotics for otitis externa include:
    • Polymyxin B, neomycin, and hydrocortisone 3-4 drops to the affected ear every 6 hours.
    • Ofloxacin 5 drops to the affected ear every 12 hours.
    • Ciprofloxacin with hydrocortisone 3 drops to the affected ear twice daily
  • Aural toilet, Ichthammol glycerin wick and analgesics may also work.
  • If left untreated, the infection can spread to nearby tissues and bones.

Option A: Otomycosis

  • Otomycosis is an infection of the ear canal caused by fungus.
  • It often occurs due to Aspergillus Niger, Aspergillus fumigatus, or Candida albicans. It is seen in tropical and subtropical countries with hot and humid climates. Secondary fungal growth is also seen in patients using topical antibiotics to treat otitis externa or middle ear suppuration.
  • The clinical features of otomycosis include intense itching, discomfort or pain in the ear, and watery discharge with a musty odour. The fungal mass may appear white or black and has been likened to a wet piece of filter paper.

Option C: Acute Suppurative Otitis media

  • It is an acute inflammation of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms.
  • Here, the middle ear implies the middle ear cleft, i.e., the eustachian tube, middle ear, attic, aditus, antrum, and mastoid air cells.

Option D: Malignant (Necrotizing) Otitis externa

  • Malignant otitis externa is an inflammatory condition of the external ear caused by pseudomonas infection in the elderly, diabetics, or those on immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Its early manifestations resemble diffuse otitis externa, but there is excruciating pain and the appearance of granulations in the ear canal.
  • Facial paralysis is common in this condition.
  • Infection can spread to the skull base and jugular foramen, causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Treatment:
    • Antibacterial Therapy.
    • Decongestant Nasal Drops.
    • Oral Nasal Decongestants.
    • Analgesics and Antipyretics.
    • Ear Toilet.
    • Dry Local Heat.
    • Myringotomy.

questions.text: A sixty-five-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in his right eye. His vision started decreasing a few weeks back, and now he can barely see through his right eye. He had successful cataract surgery in the same eye 1 year ago. The slit lamp examination finding of his right eye is shown below. What is the most likely cause of the patient's loss of vision?
questions.solution:
Option B: After cataract

  • Slit lamp examination shows the formation of a secondary cataract.
  • Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) is also called after cataract or secondary cataract.
  • It is the most common postoperative complication of cataract surgery.
  • The younger the age of the patient, the faster the occurrence.
  • In PCO, the posterior capsule becomes secondarily opacified due to the migration, proliferation, and differentiation of lens epithelial cells.
  • Most patients present months to years after cataract surgery, with a gradual decrease in vision.
  • Symptoms are similar to a primary cataract, such as glare, difficulty reading, and slowly progressive painless blurring of vision.
  • The younger the age of the patient, the faster the occurrence.
  • Types of PCO are:
    • Elshnig’s pearls (most common)
    • Soemmering's ring.
  • Treatment is ND: YAG laser capsulotomy. The wavelength of this laser is 1064 nm.
  • Indications for treatment are:
    • Reduced visual acuity and/or glare.
    • To improve fundus visualization in cases where retinal disease treatment is required.

Option A: Irvine gass syndrome

  • Pseudophakic cystoid macular edema is also known as the Irvine-Gass syndrome.
  • It is one of the most common causes of vision loss following cataract surgery.
  • This is due to the accumulation of inflammatory debris.
  • It usually occurs approximately 4-6 weeks after surgery.
  • Symptoms include; blurry vision, central scotomas, metamorphopsia, and mild photophobia.
  • The patient's symptoms are more suggestive of a secondary cataract.

Option C: UGH syndrome

  • Uveitis-Glaucoma-Hyphema (UGH) Syndrome is a complication of intraocular chafing due to intraocular lens (IOL) implants.
  • It is characterized by chronic inflammation, cystoid macular edema, secondary iris neovascularization, recurrent hyphemas, and glaucomatous optic neuropathy leading to a loss of vision.
  • Surgical intervention is often required as definitive treatment.
  • Symptoms include; intermittent decrease in vision, photophobia, redness, and pain in the affected eye. The patient’s pain may be out of proportion to examination findings.
  • A slit-lamp examination may show raised intraocular pressure, microhyphema or hyphema, or a dislocated or malpositioned IOL.
  • The patient's symptoms are suggestive of secondary cataract.

Option D: Endophthalmitis

  • Endophthalmitis is the most dreaded and one of the worst possible complications of cataract surgery.
  • It is a suppurative inflammation starting from the vitreous, which extends to all the parts of the eye except the sclera.
  • Patients present with sudden onset pain, redness and a decrease in vision.
  • Treatment involves an intravitreal injection of potent antibiotics.
  • The patient's symptoms are suggestive of a secondary cataract.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient was referred to the Ophthalmology department for a slit-lamp examination. On examination, based on Van Herrick's slit-lamp grading, a grade 3 of the anterior chamber was given. This grade denotes which of the following angles?
questions.solution:
Option B: Moderately open angle

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma generally has no symptoms, which is why it is often called the “sneak thief of sight.”
  •  This is especially true in early to moderate glaucoma, where the decrease in side (peripheral) vision is not noticed. Most patients do not have pain, even sometimes when the eye pressure is very high.

Van Herrick slit-lamp grading:

  • It is based on comparing the anterior chamber depth and corneal thickness. It is done by focusing a narrow slit beam at a 60°angle across the peripheral part of the cornea and by comparing the anterior chamber depth to the corneal thickness.

Option A: Wide-open angle

  • Wide open angle is grade 4 according to the Van Herrick grading system.

Option C: Moderately narrow-angle

  • Slit-lamp estimation of the peripheral anterior chamber depth (ACD) by the Van Herick technique is a noncontact approach for estimating angle width and various authors have commented on its sensitivity and specificity as a screening tool for identifying narrow angles as well as angle closure.
  • Grade 3 is for moderately open-angle glaucoma, moderately narrow angle is Grade 2.

Option D: Closed-angle

  • The method involves a narrow slit of light from a slit lamp projected onto the peripheral cornea at an angle of 60⁰ as near as possible to the limbus.
  • The resulting image is a slit projected onto the cornea's surface; the width is then used as a reference for grading the angle.
  • The given grade is moderately open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man from Europe living in India presents to a physician with complaints of gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision for 1 month. He says he could earlier drive the car home by himself but cannot do so now. He is a retired navy officer. He is otherwise vitally stable. The fundus examination is given below. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Given the symptoms described (gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision) and the patient's age, the most likely diagnosis is age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is a common eye condition among people over 50 and can cause significant vision loss.

The best treatment modality for wet AMD, which is characterized by the growth of abnormal blood vessels behind the retina, is Anti-VEGF therapy. Anti-VEGF drugs (such as ranibizumab, aflibercept, or bevacizumab) are injected into the eye to inhibit the growth of these abnormal blood vessels, preserving the remaining vision and sometimes even improving sight. This approach has been a significant advancement in the management of wet AMD.

Therefore, the correct answer is

Option D. Anti-VEGF therapy.

Options A, B, and C are not appropriate treatments for wet AMD. Vitrectomy is a surgical procedure used for conditions involving the vitreous humor of the eye. Macular grid photocoagulation is a technique used in specific cases of diabetic macular edema and might not be suitable for wet AMD. Spontaneous healing is not a realistic option for progressive vision loss due to conditions like wet AMD.

questions.text: A 22-year-old young woman presents with a complaint of red eye and associated pain above the eye for the last 1 month to the ophthalmologist. She also complains of several hours lasting of the red and painful eye that relieves upon sleeping. Examination of the patient reveals that she has an irregular pupil. The patient's mother has chronic open-angle glaucoma, and the patient wants to know whether she has the same thing. Which of the following condition is more likely to be present in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Iridocyclitis

  • It is a case in which the patient presents with red eye and associated pain above the eye from the last 1 month. She also complains that her red and painful eye lasts for several hours that relives upon sleeping. Examination shows that her pupil is irregular. This scenario indicates that the patient has iridocyclitis.
  • In this condition, the iris and the ciliary body have inflammation. The patient in this condition typically presents with pain, red eye, miosis, and blurring of vision.
  • Patients in this condition may have posterior synechiae in which fibrinous adhesions are formed between the lens and iris during chronic inflammation. It can affect the pupil and cause irregularity in it.
  • Iridocyclitis that happens as a result of an injury can resolve on its own in almost 3 weeks. But if this happens due to a bacterial or viral cause, then treating the infection can resolve this condition.

Option B: Conjunctivitis

  • Conjunctivitis is an infection or inflammation of the eye. In this condition, the transparent membrane of the eyes, which is called the conjunctiva, becomes inflamed. Small vessels in the conjunctiva become inflamed and cause the white portion of the eye to become red or pink.
  • Conjunctiva is the protective membrane that is along the eyelid and covers the eye's white part.

Option C: Keratitis sicca

  • Keratitis sicca, also called keratoconjunctivitis sicca, is a chronic condition due to the loss of homeostasis of the tear film. It is a multifactorial syndrome of the ocular surface.
  • dry disease can present with ocular symptoms and visual disturbances. Burning or itching, hyperemia, ocular irritation, photophobia, and blurry vision.

Option D: Chronic open-angle glaucoma

  • Open-angle glaucoma is a multifactorial optic neuropathy. It is a chronic, progressive, and not reversible condition with an acquired loss of the optical nerve.
  • Patients usually present with symptoms in the late stage of this disease due to the silent nature of glaucoma. Common early presentations include only visual complaints

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient comes to the clinic complaining of recurrent episodes of decreased vision in both eyes and an inability to move her legs. She was treated with steroids for similar symptoms 3 months ago, after which her symptoms improved. On examination, vision in her right eye is 6/60, and her left eye is 6/18. Physical examination reveals spastic paraplegia. Her CSF analysis for oligoclonal bands is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Neuromyelitis Optica

  • Neuromyelitis optica is characterized by demyelination and axonal damage of the optic nerve and spinal cord.
  • The clinical manifestations include:
    • Recurrent attacks of bilateral optic neuritis causing impaired vision and retrobulbar pain.
    • Subsequent development of transverse myelitis within days or weeks, causing symmetric paraplegia, sensory loss, and bladder dysfunction.
  • Diagnosis is made with the help of an MRI that shows inflammation of the spinal cord.
  • Treatment:
    • First line: high-dose glucocorticoid therapy for 3–5 days, followed by a taper for 2–8 weeks.
    • Plasmapheresis in severe, refractory cases.

Option A: Multiple sclerosis

  • Early in the course of the disease, it may be difficult to distinguish neuromyelitis optica and multiple sclerosis because both may cause optic neuritis and myelitis as symptoms.
  • However, optic neuritis and myelitis tend to be more severe in neuromyelitis optica.
  • The brain MRI is more commonly normal, and the spinal fluid analysis does not usually show oligoclonal bands in neuromyelitis optica, which are features that help distinguish it from multiple sclerosis.

Option B: Syringomyelia

  • Syringomyelia is a condition in which an abnormal fluid-filled cavity, or syrinx, develops within the central canal of the spinal cord.
  • Nystagmus is the common ocular finding related to syringomyelia.

Option C: Carotid artery dissection

  • Dissections of the carotid and vertebral artery primarily affect young adults and may occur spontaneously or as a result of major trauma (e.g., car accidents).
  • The initial symptoms are usually headaches (temporal and occipital for the carotid artery), while features of ischemia may follow (e.g., stroke) a few hours or days later.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with his mother with a complaint of mild squint observed from the last month. On history taken from the mother, the intrauterine, birth, and developmental history to date are all normal. Even though he was normal on the day of his birth, no deviation was found or observed in his eye. On examination, the corneal reflexes are normal. All other eye parameters are normal except an exaggerated epicanthal fold. According to the given history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pseudo-strabismus

  • In pseudo strabismus (apparent squint), the visual axes are, in fact, parallel, but the eyes seem to have a squint:
    • Pseudo esotropia or apparent convergent squint may be associated with:
      • Prominent epicanthal fold (which covers the normally visible nasal aspect of the globe and gives a false impression of esotropia).
      • Negative angle, kappa.
    • Pseudo exotropia or apparent divergent squint may be associated with:
      • Hypertelorism, a condition of wide separation of the two eyes (i.e. wide JPD), and
      • Positive angle kappa.

  • The above image explains the pseudo-strabismus condition.

Option B: Accommodative squint

  • A form of strabismus, often known as eye misalignment, accommodates esotropia. 
  • One of the most prevalent types of esotropia (crossed eye) in children is refractive esotropia. 
  • One or both eyes may cross when trying to focus, which is known as accommodating esotropia.

Option C: Exophoria

  • Exophoria is a situation where eyes automatically travel outward. 
  • It typically only shows up briefly when performing specific duties. 
  • With the appropriate care, it's not a serious condition and can be resolved.

Option D: Esophoria

  • Esophoria is a condition that causes one eye to turn when covered, similar to exophoria. 
  • The direction in which the eye drifts or turns distinguishes the two situations. 
  • As the eye moves toward the nose due to esophoria, the eye turns inward.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to ER after her brother threw a caterpillar into her right eye. On examination, she has conjunctival redness, swelling and decreased vision. She also complains of ocular pain. The visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Numerous caterpillar hairs are embedded in the periocular skin, eyelids, and the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva of the right eye. Which of the following is a likely complication seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ophthalmia nodosa
