  • Conjunctival inflammatory nodule due to caterpillar hair or tarantula hair.
  • It can lead to chronic conjunctivitis and visually disabling corneal scars, cataracts, vitreous and macular edema.
  • Treatment: Removal of the offending agent and managing inflammation through topical anti-inflammatory agents such as NSAIDs and steroids with antibiotic cover to prevent secondary infections.

Option A: Intraocular melanoma

  • Malignant melanoma occurs typically at the limbus in older adults.
  • It spreads over the surface of the eyeball.
  • Recurrences and metastases occur elsewhere in the body commonly.
  • It is treated by enucleation of the globe or exenteration of the orbit in cases of extraocular extension.

Option C: Pterygium

  • Degenerative and hyperplastic condition of the conjunctiva.

Option D: Pinguecula

  • It is a triangular yellow patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus in the palpebral aperture.
  • It commonly occurs in elderly persons exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • It is seen first on the nasal side.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with recent onset photophobia within 24 hours and a sloughing corneal ulcer. There is a greenish ulcer base. Which of the following can be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pseudomonas

  • Pseudomonas Ulcer
    • Rapid onset & Greenish ulcer base.
    • Produce biofilm that causes resistance.
    • Most common cause of infection in contact lens users.

Option A: Nocardia

  • Nocardia is a rare cause of ocular infections. Ocular infections caused by Nocardia include keratitis, scleritis, conjunctivitis, canaliculitis, dacrocystitis, orbital cellulitis, and endophthalmitis. Corneal infections are the most common.
  • The diagnosis is often missed or delayed as the clinical picture may resemble other causative organisms.
  • Patients often suffer from significant ocular morbidity for a prolonged period before an accurate diagnosis is made.
  • Nocardia infections do not respond to commonly used first-line medications for bacterial keratitis, such as fluoroquinolones. With the initiation of appropriate therapy, Nocardia infections respond promptly and carry a good prognosis.​​​​​​​
  • This patient has a pseudomonas ulcer based on the presentation.

Option B: Herpes

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a very common, lifelong infection that often is asymptomatic.
  • Ocular manifestations of HSV- I and HSV- II include blepharoconjunctivitis, epithelial keratitis, stromal keratitis (necrotizing or non-necrotizing), iridocyclitis, and/or acute retinal necrosis.​​​​​​​
  • This patient has a pseudomonas ulcer based on the presentation.

Option D: Acanthamoeba

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis, first recognized in 1973, is a rare, vision-threatening, parasitic infection seen most often in contact lens wearers.
  • It is often characterized by pain out of proportion to findings and the late clinical appearance of a stromal ring-shaped infiltrate. It is both difficult to diagnose and difficult to treat.​​​​​​​
  • This patient has a pseudomonas ulcer based on the presentation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with a fever and headache. She also complains of vaginal itching and dysuria. When asked, she says that she recently became sexually active. Physical examination reveals tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and red, pustular, painful vesicles on her labia majora. Which of the following additional findings can be caused by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option C: Gingivostomatitis

  • Typical vesicles or pustules or a cluster of painful ulcers preceded by vesiculopustular lesions suggests genital herpes.
  • The pathognomonic findings for herpes infections are painful vesicles.
  • Both HSV-1 and HSV-2 can cause genital herpes, but more than 80% of genital lesions are due to HSV-2.
  • HSV-2 is transmitted by direct contact with the virus with mucosal surfaces or open skin surfaces.
  • Approximately 80% of infected patients are asymptomatic.

C/F:

  • The primary infection presents constitutional symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia.
  • Gingivostomatitis is an oral infection leading to mouth sores and ulcers.
  • Later, genital vesicles may appear that can rupture and leave behind painful ulcers.
  • Other genital symptoms include itching and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Option A: Granuloma inguinale

  • Klebsiella granulomatis also K/a Donovani granulomatis
  • Leads to granuloma inguinale
  • It is having a Beefy red ulcer
  • LF Colonies
    • On CLED: Yellow colonies
    • On MacConkey agar: Pinkish colonies
  • Very mucoid colonies
  • PCR for K. Species
  • NDM-1 (New Delhi Metallo -Lactamase): Resistance to all types of Antibiotics.

Option B: Neonatal pneumonia

  • It is caused by Chlamydia trachomitis
  • Serogroups A, B, Ba, C: Causes TRACHOMA
  • They are known as TRIC agents.
  • Mx Strategy
    • S: Surgery
    • A: Antibiotics
    • F: Face clean
    • E: Environmental Clean
  • Serogroups D-K: Causes
    • Inclusion Conjunctivitis
    • Infantile Pneumonia
    • Genital Chlamydiosis
  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1 -L3 Cause Lympho granuloma venereum

Option D: Gummas

  • It is caused by Treponema pallidum infection
  • Causes syphilis
  • Stages include
    • Primary: Hard, painless chancres, Painless Lymph adenopathy.
    • Secondary: Rashes over the palms & soles are present, and Condylomata lata lesions are seen (Most infectious lesion of syphilis).
    • Tertiary syphilis: Having Gummas (skin lesions), Cardiovascular complications, Neuro syphilis features.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of vaginal discomfort for the past several days. She also complains of mild itch and painful intercourse. She had menopause three years ago. She uses estrogen creams for her symptoms, but that does not seem to work. On examination, the introital mucosa and labia minora have a whitish-pink appearance. Abnormal wrinkles and a small tear on the right labia minora are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lichen sclerosus

Lichen sclerosus (also called lichen sclerosus et atrophicus)

  • Most common in postmenopausal women and causes itching of the anogenital region.
  • It can occur in all ages/sexes, anywhere on the skin.
  • The tissue may be so fragile that minor trauma may cause petechial bleeding or fissures, as seen in this case. The patient described here has an early disease.
  • A definitive diagnosis is made by biopsy.

Option A: Candidiasis

Candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida. It can affect various areas of the body, including the skin, mouth, throat, and genital area. In the case of vaginal candidiasis, symptoms may include intense itching, white plaques or patches in the vaginal area, and pain or discomfort, particularly during sexual intercourse or urination. Fissures or small cracks may also develop in the affected area.

The diagnosis of candidiasis is usually based on clinical symptoms, and in some cases, a healthcare professional may perform a microscopic examination or culture of the affected area to confirm the presence of Candida.

Treatment for candidiasis typically involves antifungal medications, such as topical creams, suppositories, or oral medications, to eliminate the fungal overgrowth and alleviate symptoms. It's important to follow the prescribed treatment course and maintain good hygiene practices to prevent recurring infections.

Option B: Estrogen deficiency

Estrogen deficiency refers to a decrease in the levels of estrogen, a hormone primarily produced by the ovaries in females. Estrogen plays a crucial role in maintaining the health of the vaginal tissues, among other functions. When estrogen levels decrease, the vaginal mucosa may become thin, dry, and fragile, leading to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, pain during intercourse, and an increased risk of vaginal infections.

In the given scenario, the patient is using estrogen, which suggests that estrogen deficiency is less likely as a cause for her symptoms. Estrogen replacement therapy is often prescribed to alleviate symptoms of vaginal atrophy and improve the health and lubrication of the vaginal tissues in menopausal or postmenopausal women.

Option C: Lichen planus

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that can affect the skin, mucous membranes, nails, and hair. It is characterized by the development of flat-topped, purplish, itchy papules or plaques. Lichen planus can involve various areas of the body, including the oral mucous membranes, vulva, and hair-bearing skin and scalp.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old Bengali male presents to the clinic complaining of painless nodules over the face. The face is erythematous, and the surface of some of the large nodules is discolored. On examination, multiple nodules are noted, as shown below: 



Sensations are intact, and the PPD test is negative. He gives a history of insect bites in the past while he went to the jungle for work. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cutaneous Leishmaniasis

  • This patient with a history of insect bites followed by the events leading to ulceration in a resident or traveler to an endemic focus strongly suggests Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL).
  • Leishmaniasis is a group of infections caused by intracellular protozoan parasites belonging to the genus Leishmania, family Trypanosomatidae, order Kinetoplastida.
  • Leishmaniasis is a complex of vector-borne diseases caused by a heterogeneous group of protozoa belonging to the genus Leishmania; it is transmitted by sand fly vectors.
  • Clinical manifestations range from cutaneous ulcers to systemic multiorgan disease.

The basic key points are leishmaniasis are listed below:

  • Depending on the extent and severity of involvement, infections in the human host can be classified as
    • Cutaneous leishmaniasis - New world – L.braziliensis, L.mexicana and Old world – L.major, L.tropica, L.aethiopica, L.infantum
    • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis – L.mexicana, L.aethiopica
    • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis – L.braziliensis, L.aethiopica
    • Visceral leishmaniasis – L.donovani, L.infantum
  • Most commonly present as papules or nodules at the site of insect bites enlarge progressively to form plaques that show central ulceration and crusting and heal with scarring.
  • Post-Kala Azar dermal Leishmaniasis: Hypopigmented lesions over the trunk & Nodular lesions over the face in cases of treated or healed visceral leishmaniasis.
  • Demonstrating amastigotes in material obtained from a lesion remains the diagnostic gold standard.

Option A: Leprosy

  • Hypopigmented, hypo aesthetic plaques with surfaces showing loss of appendages, dryness, and thickened peripheral nerves are characteristics of leprosy. This patient has normal sensations. This choice is not the right answer.

Option B: Chronic Fungal infections

  • Varied morphologies with swelling, induration, pus discharge, and nasal architectural disruption are characteristics of chronic fungal infections caused by various fungi, including rhinosporidiosis, mucormycosis, and actinomycosis.

Option D: Cutaneous tuberculosis

  • It slowly enlarges infiltrated plaque with expanding edge and healing with scarring at other ends. This is not transmitted by an insect bite.
